review: The director’s cleverly symbolic visuals are undercut by a jumbled script that pales to Hitchcock’s “Vertigo.”

name: Decision to Leave
review: Visually masterful, Decision to Leave is an enigmatic and seductive thriller about that inexplicable feeling called love. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: This is one of the year’s most dismaying and repellent movies.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is all the more impressive because it’s a film of restraint and nuance. It combines the suspense of classic Hitchcock with the longing of a Wong Kar-Wai love story, making it a cinematic dream come true.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook puts a ravishing spin on a timeless story of romantic obsession and a detective who falls for his suspect.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This is one of best film of 2022 from one of the Best Storytellers in cinema Park Chan-wook. This detective thriller murder mystery has excellent pacing and editing, great wide open-lens cinematography, along with a powerful cast this is A MUST WATCH!

name: Decision to Leave
review: While the case is a slow burn ... [DECISION TO LEAVE] delivers a clever payoff—and a disturbing denouement. Gradually shattering, it engulfs little by little, growing sadder and more unsettling with each wave.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook ratifies (once again) his mastery of mise en scène, directing actors and achieving a beautiful, heartrending, and ultimate ending.  [Full review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: It’s not as immediately gripping as his previous work, but it lingers like perfume.

name: Decision to Leave
review: ...a frustrating and completely lackluster mystery that feels so much longer than its endless 139 minutes.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Any negatives are simply minor details as the vast majority of Decision to Leave is excellent - it looks great, it sounds great, and it IS great.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The brilliantly fetishistic and formalistic Park Chan-wook dials the freakiness back (just a little) for this beguiling romance.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park does it the hard way, building up a complex psychological and intellectual relationship in which sexual desire feels like an emergent characteristic rather than a starting point.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Complex storytelling and stunning visuals elevate this haunting noir tale of obsession, desire, and murder.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is a mesmerizing mystery to fixate on.

name: Decision to Leave
review: In opting to spin a story whose soulfulness matches up to his characteristically virtuosic craft, Park internalizes the dizzying thrills we expect from his movies

name: Decision to Leave
review: One of the year’s most tantalizing films.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It’s a twisted tale of yearning and desire, an erotic thriller in which nobody gets naked.

name: Decision to Leave
review: What Park does is so remarkable because this film never feels as though it's hampered by tonal shifts. He's not trying to marry two disparate threads together. Death is the catalyst for love.

name: Decision to Leave
review: For a director who has long made a career of scrutinising even the basest impulses of the human heart, Park Chan-wook finally grapples with the consequences of leaving matters unresolved.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave deftly uses a Korean-Chinese language barrier to heighten the romantic tension between the leads.

name: Decision to Leave
review: In Park's hand, our mundane everyday technology - smartphone, smartwatch, Bluetooth, etc., becomes something sensual, ASMR and highly hypnotic.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Come for the mystery, but stay for Park's dazzlingly delirious web of obsession and lies that paints a haunting portrait of a policeman's singular, self-destructive focus on something unsolvable ultimately has nothing to do with the crime.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A neo-noir love story so dizzying you’d swear you’re experiencing “Vertigo.”

name: Decision to Leave
review: It has been named South Korea’s entry into the Best International Feature Film category. Hoping to earn that country another Oscar nomination. Even if that does not work out you can be assured that it is a fantastic film.

name: Decision to Leave
review: One of the most impeccably made movies I've seen in 2022. And it's one I think on a second and third watch I could easily go from liking to loving

name: Decision to Leave
review: It seems as if Park has evolved as well, with his latest film Decision to Leave he's made a surprisingly tender film that isn't as dark or as twisted as the rest of the features in his oeuvre, but is still as masterful and moving.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The film lingers over the second murder case a bit too long, as if we needed a complete rerun of the first in order to get all the ironies, but the questions set up on its shifting ground are intriguing.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook returns with a dizzying noir starring Park Hae-il and Tang Wei, but this tribute isn't as good as the original...

name: Decision to Leave
review: If Decision to Leave isn't as viscerally powerful as some of Park's other work, its meticulous, stately compositions are still stunning works of art, and its characters are likely to stick with viewers even as certain plot details fade.

name: Decision to Leave
review: As a police thriller, it has a few moments of Hitchcockian suspense that twistily examine platitudes of obsession, guilt, and the aftermath of domestic violence, but it loses the intrigue effect in a somewhat uneven second half. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: Good thrillers dole out information artfully, keeping us on the edge of our seats as we solve the case along with the detective. But rarely does a thriller contain as much densely layered visual information as Decision to Leave.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook is not an obtuse, inscrutable filmmaker but he doesn’t make it easy for viewers, either. His ending will launch a hundred theories. Alas, there is a correct answer -- if you’ve been paying attention, that is.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park’s treatment of these genres and character tropes revives them in a tricky way that keeps the viewer at an intentional distance, trying to see clearly through the unspoken language of desire between Hae-joon and Seo-rae.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Some may get lost in the intricacies of the plot machinations, but the knockout performances and crisp writing by Park and Seo-kyeong Jeong make this film one of the finest of the year.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Features two amazing performances, and is loaded with beautiful shots.

name: Decision to Leave
review: …an adult drama that happens to take place in the world of police-work, but is more of a dark romance than a cop thriller…

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave features a sensationally smouldering performance from Tang Wei

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave transforms a familiar scenario into a deeply poignant tale of forbidden love. In the process, Park refreshes tired tropes to craft a unique cinematic experience. This is not your average good-guy-falls-for-the-femme-fatale noir.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Challenging in all the right ways and one of 2022's best films.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The best romantic comedy since 'Gone Girl,' or at least 'Phantom Thread' in its snickering, sinister implication that the only unsolvable mystery is the human heart.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Possibly the sexiest movie of the year and certainly one of the best.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Every detail is meticulously crafted, resulting early and often in the sense that viewers are in the hands of a master filmmaker.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A big part of the movie's allure is trying to piece together its knotty human puzzle while navigating the shifting emotions and shaky morality. It's made even better with Park's precision and DP Kim Ji-yong's arresting visual language as our guide.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A police procedural with impeccable heat and a stellar labyrinth of crime and passion, with a staggeringly good performance from Tang Wei as the femme fatale Seo-rae.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Kim Ji-yong’s visually stunning cinematography renders the architecture of locations a palpable presence: cramped apartments and police offices, expansive landscapes, movement from the city to the sea.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave refuses the mysterious femme fatale box in which the director/writer tries to confine her by telling the story almost entirely through the eyes of the detective who falls for her.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave features plenty of the hallmarks that make Park Chan-wook films so compelling while instilling a level of patience in the proceedings to keep this Hitchcockian mystery feeling somewhat grounded.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park’s willingness to court a lot of momentary confusion about who’s who and what’s what will be a little much for some. I feel this way: When the filmmaking and the acting’s on this level, Park can zag around all he wants.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It’s cleverly constructed, features surprising wit, and has that “will they, or won’t they?” undercurrent that keeps us invested. The couple’s attraction is palpable, despite all the factors pulling them apart.

name: Decision to Leave
review: An impeccably crafted puzzle box of a film, Decision to Leave cements Park Chan-wook’s place in cinema as our modern master of suspense.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The context and setting of Decision to Leave are South Korean, with strands of the nation’s history woven in, and there might be familiar notes of Hollywood influence in the visual style — but the outcome is distinctly Park Chan-wook.

name: Decision to Leave
review: As we stagger around looking for hard facts, we fall under the spell of (their) strange relationship. Park Chan-Wook’s elaborate, masterful story tricks us and stays just out of our grip, teasing us into helpless submission

name: Decision to Leave
review: Hae-joon teeters on the knife's edge of obsession and love. Decision to Leave asks the question: Is the thrill of love in the meeting or the leaving? Leave it to Chan-wook to answer that question with another -- does it matter in the end?

name: Decision to Leave
review: [Seo-rae and Hae-jun's] collision, their romance, and the tragedy that surrounds them no matter how much they try to escape it, makes for the kind of enrapturing storytelling worth obsessing over.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A monumental thriller that places you in masterful hands, Park Chan-wook's "Decision to Leave" is a stunning romantic mystery of sweeping panoramas, sly wit, dizzying details and steep-drop emotions. It adapts noir's analog pleasures into a digital age.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park never makes clear the film’s true protagonist or antagonist, criminal or victim. Instead, he leaves us with an excruciatingly ambiguous puzzle about love, innocence, and truth.

name: Decision to Leave
review: “Decision to Leave” is a mature, sinuous romance constructed upon a tightly focused murder mystery.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave does not disappoint with its haunting, engrossing painterly portrait of longing interspersed with intrigue set against a murder-mystery backdrop plus breath-taking cinematography

name: Decision to Leave
review: We’ve met Hae-jun’s type before: the rare policeman with a conscience, who strives to do the right thing even when circumstances conspire against him.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Swoony, witty romantic murder mystery about a cop falling for his prime suspect, that plays with our perceptions like shifting sands on the shore

name: Decision to Leave
review: One of the smartest, most satisfying murder mysteries in years.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park puts his own distinctive spin on the story, with dense, fragmented storytelling and distinct visual flourishes. And lurking under those reflective surfaces may be the most sincere love story he’s ever told.

name: Decision to Leave
review: There probably a good story somewhere in the two plus hours but it desperately needs to be pared down and focused.

name: Decision to Leave
review: [Park Chan-Wook has] done wonders with a story many many peers have made far less of, enlivening familiar tropes with a restless devotion to variety, atmosphere, and a certain wry circumspection that could hardly feel more natural.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It’s the work of a master, made with the characteristic directorial flair and élan that we have seen in Oldboy and The Handmaiden.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is another winner for Park Chan-wook and it is quite frankly the romantic comedy of the year. Tang Wei and Park Hae-il are brilliant as the enigmatic murder suspect and the hapless detective.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The film feels a bit like a true-crime noir and would make a perfect double bill with countryman Bong Jin Ho’s Memories of Murder.

name: Decision to Leave
review: That you’re never quite sure how Decision to Leave will resolve, until the finale frames, is a huge part of its allure.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This is a director who knows exactly what he has doing and may well rank as both one of the finest films of the year, and within Park Chan-wook’s illustrious filmography.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The narrative is structurally audacious, and regularly deploys flashbacks and clever cuts, and scenes within scenes. It’s also the most melancholic film of Park’s career...

name: Decision to Leave
review: You know how a snippet of a song you loved when you were young might creep into your head, just a line or a few notes? That’s what Decision to Leave does.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is one of those movies where the viewer can tell the person making it is having a lot of fun, and the feeling becomes delightfully infectious.

name: Decision to Leave
review: An uncomfortable, challenging joy.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Nobody will say this is Chan-wook’s crowning achievement, but it’s an amazing film worth sticking around for.

name: Decision to Leave
review: With so many night scenes, Decision to Leave is almost literally noir. But Tang gives it a vintage femme fatale vibe, smoothly playing a poker-faced “Who, me?” suspect who holds all the emotional cards.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Sadness is the bottom line in this loop the cryptic loop from Oldboy’s Park Chan-wook.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is a subtle masterpiece from Park Chan-wook, braiding a heart-stirring tenderness into a murderous thriller.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A delicious femme fatale thriller with mystery, tragedy and more than a few deadpan laughs.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook's 11th film is his most inscrutable, his most romantic--and his best.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Senselessness takes the reins, and the narrative curveballs threaten the premise, but the dark destiny approaches with its carnivorous jaws... [Full review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: This is one of Park’s funniest films, with characters who behave foolishly and laugh at each other, even during typically sharp action scenes. Dodging obvious beats, it also denies us deep emotional engagement.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Intriguing as it is, I found the story too confusing, and the leading figures' supposed passion too remote, for the end result to feel all that rewarding.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave fits perfectly within the director’s meticulously assembled canon. His twin obsessions are lust and caution – and with apologies to filmmaker Ang Lee, Park has mastered both of those fixations.

name: Decision to Leave
review: ...this combination of sensuality and the sensory experience makes it so profound.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Is there a more elegantly wanton director than South Korea’s Park Chan-wook?

name: Decision to Leave
review: What we’re left with, ultimately, is a fragmentary and occasionally alienating journey that nevertheless provides some genuinely lovely sequences...

name: Decision to Leave
review: Tang Wei and Park Hae-il give mesmerizing performances and the tension that exists between their characters is elevated by their fabulous chemistry.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Murder meets investigation meets love meets emotional drama. That may not sound like an innovative formula, but in Park’s capable hands it proves more than satisfying.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Exquisitely intricate aesthetically, emotionally, psychologically and thematically... as spectacular as it is sophisticated.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Chan-wook’s film uses the crime genre as a frame in which to explore the complexity of human relationships and Wei is marvellous as his opaque femme fatale.

name: Decision to Leave
review: [Park] is especially adept at blurring the edges of past, present, and future along with subjective points of view.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park’s latest, Decision to Leave, may be his most compelling work yet -- faintly disturbing, extremely sensuous, elliptically plotted and elegant.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park... doesn’t subvert so much as twist noir’s language into intricate new configurations and then meticulously peel them back.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The fluid editing maintains the frenetic pace even as a second layer of the story unfolds.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It doesn’t just encourage a rewatch, it almost demands it.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This is one of the most intriguing, sexy and just plain lovely films to arrive in a long time. It’s also baffling, long and sometimes obtuse. The one balances the other.

name: Decision to Leave
review: That the film can be all of those things -- bleak and fatalistic, faintly damning of love's foolish quest -- and have its heart-rending romantic ending, too, is a testament to Park's undimmed talent. Decision to Leave is one of his best.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Rest assured, there are jaw-dropping foot chases and skirmishes, but Decision to Leave is mostly Park Chan-wook at deconstructive play.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook of Oldboy and The Handmaiden takes Hitchcock's Vertigo for a spin in Busan, and the result is spellbinding.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook doesn't make simplistic movies, and this churning mystery is packed with his usual blend of jagged humour and offbeat violence, plus an understated but seriously heated noir-style romance.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park’s ability at the movie’s end to balance closure for one character and indeterminacy for another may be the most striking thing in a quietly striking film.

name: Decision to Leave
review: At once needlepoint precise, and as woozy as 3am.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Hae-il and Tang Wei have such potent, simmering chemistry that even when they’re just eating across from one another, they’re riveting.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Another movie in which style overwhelms substance.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A spry police procedural fused with an achingly intense romance, Decision To Leave keeps you off-kilter throughout, in the best possible way. Make a decision to see it.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook crafts a mix of suspenseful police procedural and sweeping romance that, like a crashing wave, knocks you off balance and submerges you under the disorientating nature of the affairs of the heart.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The two leads are mesmerizing to watch, and after experiencing this glorious film one understands why Chan-wook won the Best Director award at this year's Cannes Film Festival.

name: Decision to Leave
review: At over two hours, Decision To Leave is an intricate and challenging thriller – thought-provoking and with style to spare.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Compared to the brutal, exacting nature of his most renowned work, the Korean director’s latest film is more like a trip to the spa.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It's one of Park's least seedy works to date - this might be the first of his films you could watch with your parents - but that newfound maturity when approaching his usual thematic obsessions does make it considerably less exciting.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The alluring visuals and devastating performances drive Park’s beautiful vision.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Even the most expositional passages of this elegant, tricky murder mystery brim with quietly stunning craft.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-Wook returns with two murder mysteries for the price of one in this romantic thriller that plays out like Double Indemnity mixed with Insomnia by way of Twin Peaks.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is utterly enthralling, and a reminder of what a filmmaking force Park Chan-wook is. Easily one of the best films of the year.

name: Decision to Leave
review: An alluring, exciting, and often very funny thriller – one that should linger on the mind even as the mist sets in.

name: Decision to Leave
review: DECISION TO LEAVE is a taut thriller with more than enough twists and turns. Park Chan-wook has created a good, old-fashioned detective film noir imbued with humor and subtle touches of sophistication.

name: Decision to Leave
review: I did not find DECISION TO LEAVE all that intriguing. The suspense the movie generates is minimal.

name: Decision to Leave
review: ...has a musical sense of misdirection.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook has whipped up another of his twisty, Hitchcockian thrillers...Park Hae-il and Tang Wei perform an exquisite dance of meaningful looks and tricky translations, the latter’s motivation calculated to play two ways...

name: Decision to Leave
review: The bar is high for Park with his first film in six years... That Decision to Leave is merely excellent rather than perfect is a testament to his impeccable talents and creative consistency.

name: Decision to Leave
review: While it lacks the urgency of some of Park’s earlier work, Decision to Leave is a skillfully constructed expression of Park’s core themes and a compelling tragic romance story wrapped in a film noir mystery.

name: Decision to Leave
review: When Decision to Leave homes in on the enigmatic, unorthodox connection that develops between its leads, it’s as alluring and provocative. But Park’s hyper-maximalist style muddies details and needlessly complicates what is a straightforward mystery.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave earns a place among the best films of the last decade.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The film is a box of secret compartments; just when you think you’ve got it all figured out, one more panel springs open.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A genre work of superior, silken craftsmanship, so sinister, serpentine and sexy as to be downright swoon-worthy.

name: Decision to Leave
review: [Park Chan-wook's] perspective is unmistakable in exploring the dark and twisted ways in which people relate to each other... So sumptuous, wrong, and fun.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Nearly every frame of the film is so exquisitely shot with such volcanic chemistry between Park Hae-il and Tang Wei, one hopes they never have to leave these characters

name: Decision to Leave
review: 'Decision to Leave' is complex and twisty, and it certainly lost me a few times, but it comes together so expertly, with every move planned so intricately, that it's as deeply satisfying as a Hitchcock thriller.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave plays with any viewer's preconceived notions on how the story is going to end. The pacing sometimes becomes too slow, but this well-made movie skillfully blends noir, romance, and mystery with talented acting.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The ambiguity of what is really going on is what makes the film so tantalizing.... "Decision to Leave" is a stunning achievement that ends by deliberately raising more questions than it answers.

name: Decision to Leave
review: While it's not as original or intense as some of Park's previous films, it's the work of an extremely talented filmmaker telling an interesting story that should especially appeal to fans of classic film noir, tragic romance, and Alfred Hitchcock films.

name: Decision to Leave
review: If the erotic thrillers of the past explored the dangers of lust, Park Chan-wook explores the risks of longing. His take on the genre isn’t just sexy; it’s playful and mordant and convoluted -- and it begs to be rewatched.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave doesn't feel like the boldest or most indelible work of Park's career; his catalog goes too deep, and too wonderfully weird, for that. But it's a delightful rabbit hole to tumble down nonetheless...

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is a sensual puzzle box — and one of the year’s best films. Tang Wei is sensational.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Packed with the kind of cinematic ingenuity that Park has built a legacy on.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The seeds of Hitchcock are present, but in Park’s guiding hands, a full 30 years into his career, they bloom into something wildly fun, surprisingly melancholy, and wholly unique, as he uses a murder mystery as a Trojan horse for a tale of longing.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The mystery of [the] relationship clearly appeals to [the filmmakers] more than the particulars of its two-pronged plot. The film is better for that attention.

name: Decision to Leave
review: These may be classic genre formulations, but you can tell from “Decision to Leave,” a love story by turns sprawling, despairing and invigorating, that Park feels them on a molecular level.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This elegantly pulpy fiction merely reminds you that folks merely see what they want to see, and tend to turn a blind eye or ear when it’s convenient for them to do so.

name: Decision to Leave
review: One of the many pleasures of the feverish “Decision to Leave” is that the director Park Chan-wook clearly had as much fun making the movie as you will have watching it.

name: Decision to Leave
review: With Decision To Leave, Park expands his formidably-deep skill set.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The film's epic length means that the plot can be difficult to follow, but overall this is a thrilling take on a familiar genre.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It lulls the viewer, along with the protagonist, into a misty, dreamlike delirium until you’re not even certain of what’s right in front of your face.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is an extravagant and hopelessly romantic thriller that weaves past and present into something entirely its own.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park piles case after case and plot twist onto plot twist in a convoluted detective story, making it seem more complex than it really is but never losing the vibe central to noir romance: a man and a woman doomed by desire.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is fantastic. This has everything you want in a cinematic experience. The craft and attention to detail is on point. The editing and transitions are absolutely outstanding. It is one of the best movies of the year.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park and co-writer Jeong Seo-kyeong don’t choose an overt, physical hedonism where other stories have gone. Instead, 'Decision To Leave' has a slow, gravitational pull that draws these two characters together.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A cold, clunky and overwrought thriller.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park weaves a web of intrigue, intimacy, and evil that is as seductive as it is harrowing. And remarkably, within all that darkness, there's a determined thread of comedy that urges us to grin even as our jaws drop in shock.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The results, however, pale in comparison to his masterstrokes, even if the film itself still works overall. But then perhaps standing up to the likes of Oldboy and The Handmaiden is no small task.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Having been twisted into bewildered bits by the convolutions of Park’s narrative, I was astonished, toward the end, to find it brushing against the tragic.

name: Decision to Leave
review: There’s much more afoot than steamy encounters and a cliched story. There’s even laughter too. You’ll be thinking about the ending for days.

name: Decision to Leave
review: With its clever script and engaging performances and twists, Decision to Leave cements its place as an international feature contender at next year’s Academy Awards and one of the most engaging films to come out of this year’s New York Film Festival.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave proves once again that Park Chan-Wook is a master filmmaker, even if it may be his least accessible film.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park adds to his filmography of complex adult relationships in genre settings. If it's cop drama you want, Decision to Leave delivers that and much more.

name: Decision to Leave
review: We’ve essentially seen this kind of film before. But we haven’t seen it look or feel quite like this, with the cultural and technological contexts of modern-day South Korea filtered through such playful direction and restrained romance.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Given all this praise, it's pretty remarkable that Decision to Leave arguably isn't on the same level as Park Chan-wook's previous work. That, however, is more a testament to the director's skills than an indictment of the film itself.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is a finely crafted film, with stellar performances from Park Hae-il (charming, and perfect as a detective torn between emotions and duty) and Tang Wei (also perfectly cast, lovely with a depth that’s just below the surface).

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave is a virtuoso performance, using all of the skills that Park has acquired in his quarter-century of filmmaking, but showcases the hungriness of an artist who’s never content to just rest on his laurels.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park Chan-wook places all the pieces on this impressive table before sitting us down for a sumptuous meal that proves himself once more to be a fascinating director who can blend all of these ingredients together and make it all look effortless.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This is Park’s Vertigo.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It's a slower-moving film than some of Park's more high-octane stuff, but its determined deliberateness eventually yields up some third-act treasures that seem very much worth it.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Done on the playful side of over-the-top, causing us to let our guard down just enough for some serious stuff to grab us by the heart.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park, novelistic and dense and stirringly achingly beautiful to behold, is firing on all his master filmmaker cylinders here

name: Decision to Leave
review: Throughout, one often feels the plot machinations working against Park Chan-wook’s poetry, though in a few cases poetry wins out.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A pretty nifty piece of genre work, a thriller that’s expertly made even if it doesn’t quite hum like the best Park films.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Taking the form of a romantic cat-and-mouse neo-noir, the film never burns, but sizzles and smolders, opting to enhance passion and sorrow to the detriment of thrills and violence.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Shows a fresh restraint and a canny understanding of genre convention: not just how to follow the rules, but where and how they can be broken in the same movie.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave doesn't work well as either a romance, a melodrama, or even a detective story. It's a movie that could only really possibly appeal to people who really, really love film noir.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The bittersweet ambience that marks so many of his best films is here in full force, marking Decision to Leave as yet another key film in Park Chan-wook’s ever-growing, impressive filmography.

name: Decision to Leave
review: … a morally complex film and an immersive dive into the psyches of its protagonists.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A swoony romance with a gloriously sharp edge

name: Decision to Leave
review: Too bad for all the arresting visuals and some worthwhile moments, [Decision to Leave] feels like a missed opportunity, especially given the fact that Park Chan-Wook is calling the shots here.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Influenced by Hitchcock's Vertigo.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Wrapped in the investigation of an unusual death, a detective becomes enamored with the main suspect. While it may be too sentimental for some, I deeply enjoyed this intimate look into the lives of our two main characters, and how the other fills a need.

name: Decision to Leave
review: "Decision to Leave" was certainly the most entertaining and slick genre film at Cannes, and among the few in this year’s competition where a woman really held all the cards.

name: Decision to Leave
review: There’s a satisfying pay off every single time, which makes the whole film feel as tidy as Hae-jun’s character and as cunning as Seo-rae.

name: Decision to Leave
review: With its many twists and turns and scene-stealing performances from its lead actors, Chan-wook’s latest work will undoubtedly surprise, delight and move audiences in ways they wouldn’t expect.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Pure entertainment cinema with a GOD LEVEL mise en scène. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: Ultimately, Decision to Leave is like a beautiful airport novel of a film. It is far cleverer than it needs to be and is so acted with sly charisma.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Every frame is like a painting, with hints to character motivation and plot twists.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A look at Decision to Leave, a middling yet watchable film from the legendary master Park Chan-wook – a cop/criminal love story that falters but occasionally fascinates.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It’s no coincidence that illusions and conundrums appear in a Park Chan-wook film. The filmmaker has mastered the ability to conjure elaborate plots that blissfully unveil themselves as the details accumulate, and “Decision to Leave” is no different.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This device doesn’t just tell us about Hae-joon’s creeping obsession, but it casts it in a sexual dimension, and delivers a hit of pure cinematic pleasure given its immaculate execution...

name: Decision to Leave
review: A cracking romantic thriller.

name: Decision to Leave
review: While Park Chan-wook may be subverting expectations with his narrative, his technical prowess continues to shine just as strongly as ever. "Decision To Leave" is a visually stunning experience on numerous levels.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The plot reads like a Hollywood erotic thriller from the early ’90s – a Shattered or Basic Instinct – Park isn’t here for the lurid thrills or wild twists.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The narratively explosive mind behind Thirst and The Handmaiden suggests twists to boot, but the real shock is that Decision to Leave doesn’t play like most Park films to date.

name: Decision to Leave
review:
There is no narrative pulse beyond [Chan-Wook's] visual domain and no matter how beautiful some images are, the film does not move forward.

name: Decision to Leave
review:
A party for fans of the art house style.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Park takes his time - 138 minutes - and [still] has a hard time solving a rather prosaic plot with sometimes incomprehensible dialogues – or is it the subtitles? [Full review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: While unquestionably elegant, Decision to Leave hits a dry spell in the last hour, but even while doing so remains a complex web of need and greed worth revisiting.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Tang Wei pulls off miracle work, making her character the beguiling figure that Hae-jun sees her as, a mysterious and unexplainable femme fatale.

name: Decision to Leave
review: An accomplished and intelligent unravelling of a good man and the complexities and frailties of human relationships. While it may not be a classic, it is captivating in a way few films are.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A fascinating and exquisitely directed film about desire, regret, and love.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Its themes of impossible romance and the internal conflict between desire and morality make it a captivating addition to Park's filmography...

name: Decision to Leave
review: A master filmmaker mines cinema’s glamorous past in a nostalgic neo-noir you don’t so much watch as surrender to.

name: Decision to Leave
review: An hypnotic architecture exercise. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Decision to Leave
review: Those who crave the Park of old, from films such as Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance and Oldboy, may be sorely disappointed. But those looking for a complex (albeit sometimes convoluted) story about longing and obsession will be in their element.

name: Decision to Leave
review: When this particular puzzle gets solved, it’s with a tour de force of reconstructive staging, up there with the artisan’s bravura of Parasite.

name: Decision to Leave
review: It’s a gorgeously and grippingly made picture and Tang Wei is magnificent.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Decision to Leave finds South Korean director Park Chan-wook at the absolute top of his game as he breathes new life into a not-so-classic detective story.

name: Decision to Leave
review: This picture demonstrates that, even without the extreme shock tactics of some of his earlier work, Park can craft a deeply satisfying and potentially commercial thriller.

name: Decision to Leave
review: A world-class artist at the top of his game.

name: Decision to Leave
review: At the peak of his powers, full of wit and melancholy, Park Chan-wook creates the platonic ideal of the romantic, elaborate noir thriller.

name: Decision to Leave
review: Is it as strong as some of his other films? No, but the characters make taking the entire 2:18 minute ride through to the end worth it.

name: Decision to Leave
review: The brunt of Park’s clockwork finesse is articulated through editing, blocking, and his ability to coax luscious detail out of the functional setups most filmmakers would surrender to the script.

name: Aftersun
review: [There] are gaps in Aftersun that are left to the audience. [… Charlotte] Wells has a keen eye for detail and feelings, one she uses to build moment upon moment into a towering emotional crescendo.

name: Aftersun
review: The Situationists and the Sex Pistols may have had nothing good to say about cheap holidays in other people’s misery, but Wells finds a wealth of beauty and heartache in this one.

name: Aftersun
review: Events play out at an unhurried pace, but the film certainly leaves a lasting emotional impression.

name: Aftersun
review: Delicate and not rushed, the full brunt of this film’s impact didn’t strike me. However, the final scene does wrap a deft bow around the lingering mystery.

name: Aftersun
review: A tremendous film. Something that looks at a hard topic like depression in a very beautiful and human way.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s not just a wrenching family drama but a fascinating meditation on memory, the poignant dance between past and present, and the experience of looking back on childhood with the perspective of an adult, seeing things we didn’t notice before.

name: Aftersun
review: What works tremendously in favour of Aftersun is the extent to which screenwriter-director Charlotte Wells is able to trust her audience to fill in the details.

name: Aftersun
review: It combines the worst elements of a slow-moving art film and a found footage film. While there is clever camera work in the film, especially in the last scene, I found the visual elements of the film to be too repetitive and not illuminating enough.

name: Aftersun
review: The delicate portrayal of how social and financial pressures impact the children of those at the sharp end of them, is what ultimately makes Aftersun so haunting and difficult to forget.

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells has produced something that will have us talking for years and years to come.

name: Aftersun
review: A hypnotic and mesmerizing quiet slice of life.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells is masterfully using the cinema form for a powerful, intimate discourse on memory and connection, as profound as Hirokazu Koreeda's 'After Life,' but subtler. It's a beautiful achievement, worthy of many viewings.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a ripe, sensitive and slightly mysterious drama film served by great actors and crystallized by a rigorous staging and a deeper sense of observation.

name: Aftersun
review: This father-daughter drama is a lyrical, impressionistic childhood reminiscence that weaves past and present to create the textured experience of memory.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a sharply drawn memoir that captures moments of happiness shared by a father and daughter, a time that will be replayed in the mind for years to come.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is an acquired taste for those who like to watch raw dramatic emotions.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun takes a fond look at parenthood, but doesn't hide the inherently hard moments of life. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: Well acted and respectable for its heart, but the structure of the story and narrative feels too laissez-faire for my tastes.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a film about belonging, aching loss, and making memories, and you will find yourself taking deep dives into personal pools of these elements, looking for your share of the sun.

name: Aftersun
review: Steven Spielberg mustered the courage to confront his childhood trauma only five decades into his career (and after the perpetrators of it had both passed). Charlotte Wells has achieved something just as majestic with her first movie.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun's warmth is so all-encompassing, it takes a while for the underlying sadness to make its presence felt. In this wistful, ultimately wrenching film, time slows down and speeds up. The biggest tragedy, however, is that it doesn't stand still.

name: Aftersun
review: The fact that this is Charlotte Wells’ feature film writing and directorial debut is stunning. Her vision is laid out meticulously, is so well-paced, and it has one of the absolute best final scenes/images of the year.

name: Aftersun
review: The pathos in Aftersun is staggering. From the opening frame, there's a lingering emotional ambiance that suggest something meaningful is about to take place. And it very much does.

name: Aftersun
review: A poetic, contemplative, elegant film with a heartbreaking story of the strong bond between a father and his daughter, this one packs quite the emotional punch.

name: Aftersun
review: Anchored by two outstanding lead performances, “Aftersun” snatches the past, turning a faded Polaroid into a tangible web of contentment and the inexorable ache of loss.

name: Aftersun
review: An ordinary film would lead toward an explosive ending, but despite the mounting tension there is nothing plot-driven about this subtle, piercing, small wonder of a film...

name: Aftersun
review: Things are sunny on the surface, but a melancholy truth lies beneath, obscured through Sophie’s young eyes. When it finally bubbles to the surface, it packs a heartbreaking punch.

name: Aftersun
review: More evocatively, the film reflects on the things we never truly know about our own lives, and about the people we have loved and thought we knew so well.

name: Aftersun
review: Undeniably an inspiring watch, but it's almost inevitable to walk out with emotional wounds and an empty feeling in your soul. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun maintains the airs of an ephemeral memory – a fleeting moment in time that simultaneously feels incredibly vivid yet hauntingly undefined.

name: Aftersun
review: At worst, Aftersun will be the stunning piece we look back on in twenty years, knowing it was the announcement of special stars.

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun
review: An adult's emotional introspection; she recalls strong childhood memories to give them a more profound and serene interpretation. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun
review: Leaving much to speculation, Aftersun doesn’t promise any more than it can really offer, keeping its proceedings at a watchful distance even at the points where it seems most obliged to share and give.

name: Aftersun
review: Beneath the luminous surface of a summer film, one of the most devastating movies of the season emerges. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: It doesn't have much plot but the 2 lead performances are very likable and sweet and you find yourself rooting for this pair.

name: Aftersun
review: A film about paternal estrangement that goes much further than that. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: Nostalgia through memories. "Aftersun" is one of the few movies that have been able to convey those sensations, those images that make up our childhood memories. In fact, it's that quality that gives the film its dreamlike tone. Full review in Spanish.

name: Aftersun
review: Each viewer who sees “Aftersun” will have a moment where it all clicks into place. And that moment won’t be the same moment for the person sitting next to you.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s strangely moving, and a joyous examination of a father/daughter relationship, but it’s ultimately too ambiguous and ephemeral to be game-changing.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s a complex and affecting drama about the vagaries of memory and the uncertainties of family dynamics.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells leaves the details unspoken via a formally fluid, sensorial experience. All we really know for certain is that their love for each other was undeniable—Mescal (unforgettably vulnerable) and Corio's performances ensure it.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells’ use of visual texture doesn’t just help capture her story. It resonates through that story in all directions, echoing through the medium itself, as if to turn the camera back on the nature of images, and the way we perceive them.

name: Aftersun
review: A notable study about broken dreams and sundered futures. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: Beautiful and small and enormous.

name: Aftersun
review: First time writer-director Charlotte Wells very nearly did an excellent job with “Aftersun,” but she didn’t trust herself to get her point across, and overdoes it so badly the whole movie spoils.

name: Aftersun
review: Told with such delicacy, such empathy, that it’s impossible to leave it unchanged, "Aftersun" is bruising in effect, haunting in what it leaves us shouldering.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun will be a movie memory to ruminate on and revisit for years to come, a perfect, personal film.

name: Aftersun
review: What Charlotte Wells achieves is curious, strange, and welcome...

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells’ debut is a memorable one... The soft touch of idealism meets the hard grasp of reality in a tight and unrelenting grip. Mescal is quite terrific.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells captures with her images, truthful and painful, certain and elusive, an ambiguous atmosphere of enjoyment and melancholy. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun
review: Wells knows exactly what she’s doing, and her storytelling is as precise as it is piercing.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells’ direction is remarkable in its confidence and clarity. Aftersun is a visual marvel; it recreates those slightly crappy childhood holidays with precision and care, affection even.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells' ability to capture the innocence of her past self, from a more mature and grown-up point of view is what makes her film into such an unusual piece of filmmaking.

name: Aftersun
review: Writer-director Charlotte Wells's feature debut Aftersun is a sublime example of how an opaque style can be wedded to an ambiguous storytelling technique without cost to psychological truth.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a little gem -- restrained, subtle, sweetly melancholic, and the interplay between Mescal and Corio has the unerring ring of truth.

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun
review: For all that Aftersun can be described as gentle, contemplative and even beautiful, it’s also the kind of film that feels as if it’s teetering on the edge of a cliff.

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun

name: Aftersun
review: This is an experience you won’t forget in a hurry.

name: Aftersun

review: One of the most beautiful and affecting films I have seen this year.

review: Aftersun captures the poignant beauty of ephemeral joy—moments our memory can miraculously suspend in time.

name: Aftersun
