review: Wells avoids the commonplace, complacency, and demagogy to achieve something truly particular, with a degree of intimacy, tenderness, and subtlety that make this first feature film a surprise and revelation of the year. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: This mesmeric debut will make you want to stay suspended in its sun-baked setting with its two captivating lead characters for far longer than the runtime. A triumph of new British filmmaking.

name: Aftersun
review: The film feels like an embrace of the past, acknowledging that it’s still always present due to how we’ve retained certain memories of those we were closest to. Charlotte Wells has crafted a stunning debut about fathers & daughters I won't soon forget.

name: Aftersun
review: Memories carry with them beauty and pain in equal measure. Charlotte Wells’ assured debut is a work of bittersweet art that will now be another we carry with us for when we need it.

name: Aftersun
review: An ode to cinema as a machine for remembering.

name: Aftersun
review: A penetrating portrait of a daughter’s search for a father that, as a child, she barely knew...a memory piece that points to mysteries that viewers must ultimately figure out for themselves.

name: Aftersun
review: This is a gentle moment, a story of growing up through the eyes of a child, and a film that captures the whimsical, yet romantic glow of the love we can have for our parents.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a stunning debut and one of the best films of the year. One that will leave its mark and stay with you for a long time. Similar to that unwanted but inevitable holiday sunburn!

name: Aftersun
review: Though it succeeds in a number of ways, Aftersun truly triumphs thanks to the two actors at its center.

name: Aftersun
review: The acting is very naturalistic, but the story is coming-of-age familiar … and moves with the pace of a snail stuck in glue. For me, there wasn't enough "there" there, but for folks with unresolved issues with absent fathers it might resonate louder.

name: Aftersun
review: We see a Polaroid of father and daughter begin to develop but never come fully into focus, a powerful visual metaphor for Wells’s exploration of identity and a relationship that is just in the process of forming...

name: Aftersun
review: Thanks to Wells’s evident confidence, this story, constructed slowly and focused on small moments, is more mesmerizing than most...

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells' promising debut feature plays with memory as a tool and lets its story unfold in dream-like waves.

name: Aftersun
review: Every moment, every snippet of dialogue, every detail down to the smallest role or the tiniest detail in the background feels like a vibrant slice of real life.

name: Aftersun
review: Much like Normal People, Aftersun lives and dies by the chemistry between the two leads, and [Paul] Mescal and [Frankie] Corio are never less than fully convincing as father and daughter.

name: Aftersun
review: A summer vacation with no defined time frame, and where the absence of answers and words give rise to a double emotional catharsis. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: The film moves at a languid pace, but Wells repays your patience with a rich and melancholy experience.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is practically the definition of a "small" movie, but it sneaks up on you.

name: Aftersun
review: I don’t want to oversell it — plenty have already — because it’s a clear-eyed poem of remembering, made from material usually treated as heart-tugging prose.

name: Aftersun
review: Drenched with beautiful moments as Scottish writer-director Charlotte Wells gives us a glimpse of the close bond between a father and daughter. Paul Mescal & Frankie Corio are terrific.

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells’ moody story of a father and a daughter on vacation is raw and authentic. Her use of a naturalistic camera sets a sincere tone that’s uniquely engaging.

name: Aftersun
review: Cheers to Scotland’s Charlotte Wells for making the best movie of the year by a first-time writer-director. And cheers to Paul Mescal and young  Frankie Corio for bringing this unforgettable father-daughter story to such funny, touching and vital life.

name: Aftersun
review: Beyond the fine performances, there is the expressive look of it. Wells and her cinematographer, Gregory Oke ("Raf"), turn concrete images into abstract beauty that slowly resolves into rapturous visual splendor.

name: Aftersun
review: Emotional, beautiful, and heartbreaking, Aftersun is perfection. In the moments of love and laughter, Wells is able to capture the sadness creeping in...

name: Aftersun
review: It’s all elisions, ellipses and lingering looks that build to an almost overwhelming emotional force.

name: Aftersun
review: Don't miss this trip.  Through careful nuance and routine occurrences, Wells threads colossal and timeless messages.

name: Aftersun
review: An exercise is subtly playing with our emotions and expectations

name: Aftersun
review: 'Aftersun' is about memory and flows like it. It may not be the movie you expect, but it’s worthwhile.

name: Aftersun
review: Frankie Corio gives a great performance as Sophie, one of those amazingly natural turns that makes it seem as if no acting is happening.

name: Aftersun
review: We’re on childhood time, and the clock ticks according to Sophie’s biorhythms, somehow slowed down by unspoken worry about her dad.

name: Aftersun
review: Scottish feature debut filmmaker Charlotte Wells crafts a tenderly experimental and “emotionally autobiographical" diary of her father who died when she was just 16.

name: Aftersun
review: At times feeling like a junior high riff on Morvern Callar, it’s a subtle and beautiful film that uses “Under Pressure” in a way that simply owns it forever

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is lyrical without ever being obtuse, and it's a film that flourishes when attention is paid to details.

name: Aftersun
review: From its gut-wrenching script and stirring cinematography to brilliant performances from the always-spectacular Paul Mescal and newcomer Frankie Corio, Aftersun is a special one.

name: Aftersun
review: A stunner, a heartbreaker on love, grief and the random moments in life that solidify into haunting memories.

name: Aftersun
review: A tribute to father-daughter relationships and the feeling of looking back on your childhood and realizing what your parents were going through, how much they loved you, and how you'll never really know who they were.

name: Aftersun
review: 100 minutes of vaguely hinting at issues the film is far too discreet to reveal made for a slice-of-life drama more affected than affecting, in my book.

name: Aftersun
review: There is a time, probably somewhere around 11, when your kid no longer wants to hold your hand...

name: Aftersun
review: “Aftersun” stirs powerfully inarticulate emotions of what has been given and what is owed – what we had that we missed knowing we had and what we hold on to because it’s the only thing that’s left.

name: Aftersun
review: Mysteries lurk at the edges of the obliquely observed, tenderly banal events.

name: Aftersun
review: Starring Frankie Corio and Paul Mescal, Charlotte Wells’ feature debut is an emotional high-wire act, masterfully conducted with artistic vision and grounded in human nuance.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s a beautiful finale, so sad and so appropriate. You’ve never heard anything like it. But then, you’ve never seen anything quite like Aftersun either. So it fits.

name: Aftersun
review: A heartbreakingly beautiful look at an 11-year-old girl’s fond, complex memories of her father.

name: Aftersun
review: A memory movie, not just a movie about someone’s memory but a movie about memory itself, presented in a flickering, sometimes kaleidoscopic fashion, present mingled with past, layered with understanding and regret.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s hard to explain exactly how writer-director Charlotte Wells’s feature debut, “Aftersun,” pulls off the wave of emotion it instills in the viewer.

name: Aftersun
review: [T]he film's collective emotional impact is staggering.

name: Aftersun
review: Mildly charming.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a beautiful debut film about fathers and daughters seen through the lens of memory.

name: Aftersun
review: Plays like a surgically precise dismantling of one’s heart. Aftersun is a richly textured father-daughter drama with hidden depth that will instantly have one combing through the memories again

name: Aftersun
review: A film to be experienced — just go with it — the full impact of “Aftersun” comes as the credits start to roll, and the processing begins.

name: Aftersun
review: …melancholy and mysterious.  Wells has also unearthed a huge discovery in newcomer Frankie Corio, who gives an amazingly assured and sensitive performance as the 11 year-old Sophie.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun cuts you in two with such emotional intensity, such impressive dramatic force, that I could only sit and fight back the inevitable tears.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s a movie that hinges on your ability to put a big portion of yourself into it. For me that requires a deeper connection – one that comes from an understanding of the characters that (for one reason or another) I never had.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is perhaps the most formally intricate and complex film I’ve seen in 2022, and it rewards contemplation beyond its emotionally eviscerating effect.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun has more to offer than the usual. What it lacks in answers, it more than returns in grace.

name: Aftersun
review: You feel deeply for these characters, even after only a few scenes, and Wells aptly sucks you into their world.

name: Aftersun
review: The subject's thoughts count more than the plot.

name: Aftersun
review: The astonishingly assured directorial debut of Charlotte Wells, a Scottish filmmaker who sourced much of the script from her own autobiographical details.

name: Aftersun
review: It's best if viewers know up front that Aftersun is mostly a series of 'slice of life' flashback scenes shown through videos taken during a family vacation in Turkey in the 1990s. What's more intriguing is the melancholic mystery behind these flashbacks.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells masterfully weaves the past and present together, and it’s in the exploration of one’s memory where the drama is at its best.

name: Aftersun
review: Paul Mescal is a quiet revelation in Charlotte Wells' exquisite feature directorial debut.

name: Aftersun
review: The performances here are quiet marvels.

name: Aftersun
review: A work of masterful and almost unbearable melancholy.

name: Aftersun
review: With two masterfully understated performances and a rich visual texture, this incisive two-hander explores subtle father-daughter dynamics and the fragility of generational bonds with tenderness and offbeat charm.

name: Aftersun
review: Though any honest summation can't do it justice, Charlotte Wells's tender feature debut is the kind of revelation that movie fans dream of finding: not a wow so much as a guaranteed piece of emotional ravishment.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells, in her first feature, embraces the inherent messiness of it all perfectly. This is a collage of emotion pieced together from photographs, a souvenir rug, shaky home videos... the mind, of course, and the horrible/wonderful songs of that summer.

name: Aftersun
review: I wept buckets, because writer-director Charlotte Wells so honestly realizes Sophie and Calum, and the potency and poetry of their father-daughter connection.

name: Aftersun
review: In a mood-forward film, the prevailing sense is one of girlhood taking its last untroubled breath. Among other things this means agreeing, for a little longer, to overlook all the things about your dad he would prefer that you not see.

name: Aftersun
review: An act of imaginative empathy.

name: Aftersun
review: Frankie Corio may be the breakthrough star of the year.

name: Aftersun
review: A beautifully sculpted and quietly shattering first feature from the Scottish writer-director Charlotte Wells.

name: Aftersun
review: A remarkable, moving debut feature from Charlotte Wells.

name: Aftersun
review: t’s deeply felt, a warm embodiment of a liminal time in life when our conceptions of ourselves and our loved ones come pinging into focus while also, somehow, drifting into new confusion.

name: Aftersun
review: The power of the film comes from its embrace of the basic and universal fact of loss.

name: Aftersun
review: Naturally deconstructing childhood nostalgia with a resounding rawness, Aftersun is a profound slice-of-drama that marks a compelling debut by writer/director Charlotte Wells.

name: Aftersun
review: Evoking the early works of Lynne Ramsay and Andrea Arnold, writer-director Charlotte Wells leaves much of the subtext up to your imagination and just allows the actors’ performances to tell the real story.

name: Aftersun
review: The ambition in [Wells's] script would be hard for any actor to pull off, but the beating heart of Aftersun comes in the form of its two leads, whose chemistry together could fool anyone into thinking they had known each other their entire life.

name: Aftersun
review: Mesmerizing...but is unnecessarily obscure and overdoes the whole “understated/unstated” thing.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun feels like a combination of memory and hallucination, but rooted in truth.

name: Aftersun
review: This is a tough story that’s presented with beauty and grace, and it respects that not all searches have answers.

name: Aftersun
review: A spellbinding, genuinely heartfelt and refreshingly un-Hollywood slice-of-life.

name: Aftersun
review: Rumors of something remarkable have circled around “Aftersun” since its première, at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, and guess what? The rumors are true.

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells has delivered something emotionally unique with her debut feature Aftersun. Grounded by staggeringly understated performances from Paul Mescal and Frankie Corio, there is never a false note in this devastating family drama.

name: Aftersun
review: For a movie so obsessed with the details of daily life, then, it was that much more disappointing when it pulled a punch at its end to merely suggest tragedy, instead of actually showing it.

name: Aftersun
review: Our brains tend to obscure, distort and falsify as well as heighten, protect and heal, depending on how you want to remember that moments or person in your life. Aftersun, is a poignant and deeply personal examination of those memories.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells demonstrates an impressive ability to show restraint which isn’t common in debut films, and shows her deep understanding not just of the craft but of what she wants to say.

name: Aftersun
review: The effective blending of the past and the future paired with Mescal and Corio's beautifully natural performances make Aftersun a movie that will stick with you long after it's done.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun, the splash-of-cold-water debut from Charlotte Wells, is where the falsehoods of movies and memories meet. The results are nothing short of masterful.

name: Aftersun
review: 'Aftersun' pushes you to want to solve its questions while imploring you to savor the moment. It’s a delicate dance life does on its own

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a soul-shaking cinematic achievement with one of the best depictions of depression ever to hit the silver screen.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a melancholic and compassionate look at the love between a father and daughter. A directorial debut that triumphs as one of the year’s most important cinematic experiences.

name: Aftersun
review: Anchored by stellar performances from Paul Mescal and Frankie Corio, filmmaker Charlotte Wells’ debut is empathetic and strikingly realized. It’s also got a late-film needle-drop for the ages.

name: Aftersun
review: Both Paul Mescal and newcomer Frankie Corio are more than up to the task to bring Wells’s poetic meditations to fruition, and it's their collective efforts that ensures the ending devastates us with the weight of its impact.

name: Aftersun
review: Although it feels more like a short film coaxed to feature-length, what an incredible way to start a career.

name: Aftersun
review: I didn’t want Aftersun to end—and the desire to preserve and extend moments into infinity is what the movie is all about.

name: Aftersun
review: A thoughtful, compassionate, and visually arresting meditation on love, memory, and the passage of time.

name: Aftersun
review: A father and daughter resort holiday, viewed through a prism of wistfulness and regret, takes on magical meaning in this arresting feature directing debut by Scotland’s Charlotte Wells.

name: Aftersun
review: After all is said and done, it is films like Aftersun that will stand the test of time long after we are gone.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun’s slow and steady buildup culminates in its final 15 minutes, giving way to a surprisingly sharp and affecting end.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a revelation, and Wells deserves all the accolades that will hopefully continue to come her way.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells' extraordinary film shows just enough without telling us anything directly, an incredibly potent way to register grief and loss, and to display how much we will still never know about the people we love dearest.

name: Aftersun
review: ...a small-scale premise that’s employed to predominantly (and distressingly) tedious and underwhelming effect...

name: Aftersun
review: … a beautiful film that heralds the emergence of a major cinematic talent.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a film you follow by feeling.

name: Aftersun
review: For the most part, it’s a quiet film touched with melancholy and calm even for its category of nostalgic reverie, a quality which makes the occasional intrusions of the present, tinged with frustration and loss, cut all the deeper.

name: Aftersun
review: Although quiet, the film builds to an emotionally devastating climax involving a Queen song that you’ll never hear in the same way again.

name: Aftersun
review: Deftly constructed and utterly heartbreaking, Aftersun announces Charlotte Wells as an eminent storyteller of prodigious powers.

name: Aftersun
review: A melancholy floats an inch above the surface -- the water sparkles a little too bright, that diamond sheen that's gone right before you can grab it

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells’ feature debut showcases the assured hand she had already demonstrated in her short film work and enhances it further to balance tone and pace throughout a touching story of a daughter and her troubled father on holiday.

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells uses Aftersun to show us what it’s like to unlock that box that we all keep away in a hidden dark corner of our minds. What it’s like to admit that our perfect childhood memories are just afterimages of the brightest moments.

name: Aftersun
review: “Aftersun” isn’t just an honest movie about the way that we remember the people we’ve lost — fragmented, elusive, nowhere and everywhere all at once — it’s also a heart-stopping act of remembering unto itself.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a tender look at how we remember our loved ones.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun turns a simple and familiar story into a hypnotic and exciting audiovisual experience. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: It may come on like another artfully made, ominous-seeming coming-of-age film, but it gradually deepens into remarkable exploration of memory and family and that difficult moment where parents become real people in the eyes of their children.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is directed with a sure hand and immense empathy.

name: Aftersun
review: What makes Aftersun such a revelatory work is the way these inner emotions are never spelt out in dialogue, and instead are wholly expressed visually or through performance.

name: Aftersun
review: An assured, aching, vibrant debut by Wells, “Aftersun” is a shattering remembrance of a father by his daughter.

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells has struck gold with her young discovery, Frankie Corio, who delivered one of the best and most lived-in performances in the festival’s entire lineup.

name: Aftersun
review: A film that positively hums with atmosphere and glows with its maker’s promise.

name: Aftersun
review: Thanks to Wells' wonderfully human characters, astute direction, and stellar performances, "Aftersun" truly is about the little moments that seem insignificant at the time but become the precious stuff we treasure as adults.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is both a rich sensory experience and unbearably sad. It’s also one of the best debuts to play at the Cannes Film Festival in years.

name: Aftersun
review: Mescal's balanced portrayal of a hearty sufferer grounds the story with paradigmatic believability.

name: Aftersun
review: A moving, confident, striking, altogether splendid film.

name: Aftersun
review: Aftersun is a flawless debut from the Scottish filmmaker. What she does next will be of great interest.

name: Aftersun
review: What really sets the film apart is the way it subtly communicates an enormous sadness lurking just beneath the surface.

name: Aftersun
review: A beautiful little anti-history. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Aftersun
review: A genuine triumph of a film. With natural and nuanced performances Aftersun is a bright star in the cinematic sky, a film of real beauty.

name: Aftersun
review: The performances are extraordinary, managing to capture a naturalism which is utterly convincing. It’s difficult to think of a father/daughter relationship portrayed so touchingly and apparently allergic to cliche.

name: Aftersun
review: The saving grace is Corio who, in a superb and memorable debut film performance, brings some much-needed naturalism and grace to proceedings.

name: Aftersun
review: The intention of those big, intense moments is to do justice to the magnitude of some very personal and powerful emotions. In that regard, “Aftersun” is a tonic — particularly at a festival where art films are generally cold and polite

name: Aftersun
review: An exquisite revelation, Aftersun, produced by Barry Jenkins, is the type of movie from which you don’t walk away the same person.

name: Aftersun
review: It’s a film of such restraint, oblique observation, and poised naturalism that the wallop of this feeling is quite unexpected. It heralds Wells as someone with a Joanna-Hogg-like career path beckoning right ahead, paved by a sensibility all her own.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells’ measured but relentless probing, her careful peeling away of the layers of this intimate piece, mark her out as one of the most promising new voices in British cinema in recent years.

name: Aftersun
review: Wells’s movie ripples and shimmers like a swimming pool of mystery; the way Wells captures mood and moment, never labouring the point or forcing the pace, reminded me of the young Lucrecia Martel.

name: Aftersun
review: The very subject of Wells’ feature is the gap between the sensory detail of a sun-drenched vacation and the unknowable interior lives of the characters. The result is a spellbinding duet by Mescal and Frankie Corio.

name: Aftersun
review: Charlotte Wells’ sensuous, sharply moving debut shows that no amount of pool time and fruity drinks and Macarena dance-alongs can keep either the past or future at bay.

name: Aftersun
review: While this is not explicitly autobiographical, it certainly feels like a very personal piece of work, and all the better for it. Oh, and the 1990s pop soundtrack is a joy.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: “Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down” is, at its core, a love story skillfully told in an inspiring and utterly heartwarming manner.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down is a profile in resilience and another solid documentary from Julie Cohen and Betsy West.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Moving and inspirational, Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down should be required viewing for anyone facing seemingly impossible challenges. This documentary has some politics, but it's more of a story about courage and becoming stronger after major setbacks.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Infused with the energy that is Gabby herself, it is a riveting documentary

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: If the documentary leaves you with one thing, it’s that Giffords is truly one of a kind. There won’t be another like her. Anyone should be inspired, moved, and empowered to join her fight to restrict the reach of guns after watching this movie.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: This film does an exceptional job not only illuminating Gabby Giffords’ “relentless positivity” and work post-injury but also showing that the controversial conversation of quote/unquote gun control ... is a bipartisan conversation on public safety....

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Gabby Giffords certainly won't back down, as directors Julie Cohen and Betsy West show us in this uplifting, even joyful documentary. With interviewees including President Barack Obama, Julie Cohen and Betsy West take us on an inspiring, hopeful journey.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: No matter what political party you are affiliated with, you can’t help but admire the woman and her compelling life story.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The first hour especially doesn’t cut any corners showing just how life-altering Giffords’ injury was and just what a miracle it is that she’s even alive to tell the story.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Julie Cohen and Betsy West have made a resonant documentary, one the reflects its subject’s optimism, which remains firm despite everything that’s happened to her. Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down is essential viewing.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Current events make this documentary as relevant now as ever and the spirit of forgiveness and determination showed in this documentary will hopefully resonate with all who see it.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Cohen and West have never been ones to shy away from stories centered on strong women while illustrating how one voice, one person, one vote can make huge strides in or democracy if we are brave enough to follow through.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Giffords will inspire you -- and if you know anyone with aphasia, give you some encouraging tips.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: This is simply one of the most remarkable times I've spent watching a movie this year.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Respectful, very emotional, calibrated-for-inspiration and smartly structured documentary on Arizona Congresswoman Gabby Giffords.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: A story that will sadly always feel relevant in the cycle of gun culture and Republican roadblocks. This is one remarkable story of a survivor but a reminder that there were casualties that day and so many more since.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: It’s probably not surprising that it hits with a wallop, but it’s a more sincere movie than an expressly manipulative one by nature.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: An inspiring, intense doc [that] promotes empathy and perseverance.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The film’s editor deftly assembles Giffords’ complex history, juggling both her and her exceptional husband with aplomb. But “Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down” might have benefitted from a bit more rearranging.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: In Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down, it’s not so much about learning deeper details about who the former Arizona congresswomen is, but just witnessing the unstoppable powerful strength of a person who wouldn’t let a world of gun violence defeat her.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Gabby Giffords won’t back down, but your emotional walls probably will.  Heartbreaking and inspiring.  Bring tissues.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: This documentary is about resilience and advocacy, but most of all it is a love story.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Gabby Giffords wouldn’t quit on herself or her constituents, so why should we slow down on the issue of gun violence? Won’t Back Down is compelling portrait of one woman whose light cannot be extinguished.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The movie packs an infuriating punch, because it shows how much vibrancy and radiant ease Giffords lost to her injury.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: “Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down” never fully escapes its branded-content vibes, but as a parallel love story and back-to-battle story, it succeeds...

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: There couldn’t be a timelier documentary these days than Gabby Giffords Won’t Back Down.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down poignantly says as much about the struggle to stem gun violence as it reveals the struggle to live again.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: A film about grit. It's a film about feminism, change-making, and defying adversity.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Even during more analytic or crusading sections, the documentary’s mood never strays from inspirational.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The up-close-and-personal material, particularly in observing Giffords in every stage of her recovery thus far, is the most compelling element...

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The movie is perfectly timed to hopefully make that change if it gets out there. In that sense, it’s just as important a film as RBG.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: This story gives us all hope to do what we may not even believe possible simply by not backing down.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: You walk away from this documentary admiring Giffords and fully appreciating why she was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom last week.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Directors Julie Cohen and Betsy West do this sort of documentary really well.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The movie inspires and motivates.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The film and the ticktock of recovery it follows are at times difficult to watch. At the same time, watching feels almost necessary in an age when mass shootings seem to have become all too common.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: As the story of a marriage and as a document of one woman’s resiliency in the face of a devastating blow, this is an inspiring film.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: It’s a celebration of Giffords’ spirit — she remains passionate, enthusiastic and kind of goofy — and the work she’s done since the shooting to try to prevent gun violence.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: It's a beautiful film about a beautiful soul.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Giffords’ story and recovery remain incredible...

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: While it doesnt necessarily break any new narrative ground and is perhaps a bit too generalized in its latter half, the film is a compelling portrait of the Giffords and a depressing reminder of just how little weve actually accomplished since 2011.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: The documentary is instead most tactful when it focuses on Giffords and Kelly, and their shared spirit that can inspire us all.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Certainly, seeing the strength of someone like Giffords in the face of overwhelming odds (the bullet smashed through her skull and entered the brain!) should inspire us all. If that is not a compelling reason to catch the flick, I dont know what is.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: An undoubtedly inspiring film, although theres not a ton of new information in it for those who know Giffords story.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: It takes a first-rate intelligence to hold two opposing ideas in mind at the same time, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote. In a film that suggests what might have been and what is, Giffords proves first-rate.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: A truly inspirational offering an almost verite kind of fly-on-the-wall account of what can only be termed as a comeback story like no other.

name: Gabby Giffords Won't Back Down
review: Harrowing, sad and inspiring in equal measures...

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares, Kathryn Ferguson’s stunning documentary on the rapid rise and fall from worldwide fame of Irish singer Sinéad O’Connor, comes at an auspicious time. We’re living in a moment where women singers who were previously vilified by...

name: Nothing Compares
review: The film ends abruptly without delving into the subsequent years for the artist... But with such a compelling subject at its heart, it's a noteworthy omission in an otherwise deeply intimate portrait.

name: Nothing Compares
review: The greatness of Ferguson’s film isn’t so much in the craft of the film, although it is engaging, but instead it’s in the choice to focus not on the moments that made her famous and instead focus on the lead up to these moments.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares may not always favourably compare to other, more nuanced music biodocs, but it is a vital look at the life and work of an artist too often equated with a few seconds of paper ripping on a television variety show.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It becomes a fascinating portrait of fame under fire and reluctant, self-hating stardom.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares artfully relives the most intense part of Sinead O'Connor's career, with bracing commentary from O'Connor today.

name: Nothing Compares
review: The lack of on-camera interviews in Nothing Compares focuses attention on the evocative visuals.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Ferguson’s film gives a clear and moving account of the singer’s rise, and told me many things I didn’t know.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Powerfully told and elliptically crafted, Nothing Compares ably connects Sinead O’Connor’s past and present to one powerful stretch of her nearly 40 years in music and unflinching expression of self.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares doesn’t spend much time on Classic Albums-style deep dives into how this guitar riff came together or what inspired that ballad, preferring an emotional snapshot to a traditional rock-doc portrait.

name: Nothing Compares
review: If you take away anything from this fascinating and fabulous, powerful and potent documentary, it’s that O’Connor made mistakes, but also broke the ice for a succession of outspoken artists over the ensuing three decades.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Never mind the familiar documentary techniques. ... This film is an argument: a case for the defense. And the argument is a good one. ... Love wins — and love is, to all appearances, all that has ever been on [O'Connor's] mind and heart.

name: Nothing Compares
review: "Another entry into the ever-growing pantheon of films about women who are owed an apology, Nothing Compares is extremely effective at laying out how Sinead O’Connor found her moral conviction, and why she never abandoned it."

name: Nothing Compares
review: Whether you’ve forgotten the details or didn’t know about them to begin with, Nothing Compares is here to remind us of what it really meant to have no f---s left to give in pop culture -- and the price at least one person paid for it.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Meaty and mesmerizing... It's a film that feels both overdue and timely.

name: Nothing Compares
review: An excellent documentary... The sense that I got is that she was an artist and activist very much ahead of her time.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Director Kathryn Ferguson and editor Mick Mahon find their strongest rhythms when observing the singer’s career through the prism of her homeland and the pull-and-tug of Catholicism, which lingers over her music like a haunting spectre.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It provides a thrilling snapshot of a brave, inimitable talent. It’s a bit of a triumph.

name: Nothing Compares
review: The story of [O'Connor's] life and career is told in Kathryn Ferguson’s documentary...in which the filmmaker uses O’Connor’s experiences to paint a poignant and moving portrait of the fiery feminist icon.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It’s small wonder that she effectively torpedoed the stardom she never much wanted anyway.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Insightful, respectful and thorough.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It’s hard not to admire her fearless honesty. Sinéad had principles and stuck to them, and all of the issues she protested about have now entered the mainstream.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It becomes a fascinating portrait of fame under fire and reluctant, self-hating stardom. And then suddenly the narrative just dies.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Shines a light on a huge talent who fought against sexism, racism and sexual abuse in the Catholic Church.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Her enormously engaging dry wit — a humour unique to Dublin, perhaps — keeps the film lively through its darker valleys. She is never painted as a mute victim. She remains an engaged presence.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Would this ever happen to a male pop artist? Who knows? But she did open the door a bit for other female singers to express themselves as artist and also be a sentient being worthy of thought, opinions, ideas and emotions.

name: Nothing Compares
review: One of the best indicators of the effectiveness of a music documentary is when after watching it you cannot wait to listen to the artist involved.

name: Nothing Compares
review: What Nothing Compares proves is Sinéad O'Connor's courage and integrity.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Ferguson is very effective in helping us to understand O’Connor’s complex character, shaped partly by the horrific emotional and physical abuse she experienced from her mother as a child.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A bracing guide to a brilliant individual who declined to conform.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Director Kathryn Ferguson presents a different side to Sinéad O'Connor, framing her as a trailblazer and perhaps the first spokesperson for the MeToo movement.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares is as powerful as its subject.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It’s certainly worth revisiting the rise and fall of Irish musician Sinead O’Connor given the current sociopolitical climate.

name: Nothing Compares
review: This film dares the world to go back and analyze the persecution O’Connor received and ask why. It also challenges the idea of protest music and its exclusion from the mainstream.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Her story is extraordinary, from a bleak childhood to early stardom to enormous controversy. Raw and poignant, it’s about O’Connor’s amazing voice and the trouble it caused.

name: Nothing Compares
review: At once empowering and alarming, Nothing Compares reminds us how wonderful raw talent can be and that we must appreciate it and the person with the gift.

name: Nothing Compares
review: “Nothing Compares” plunges viewers into the chaos and controversy surrounding a singer who has at times been talked about more than heard.

name: Nothing Compares
review: As an intimate, often infuriating portrait of an artist and era, it's hard to argue with the raw power of the story on screen — and the timeliness of it too, no matter how long overdue.

name: Nothing Compares
review: [Nothing Compares] wants us to think about the way O’Connor’s influence is reflected in today’s outspoken female performers.

name: Nothing Compares
review: [W]hile Ferguson's film serves as a fine biographical account ... it's better, perhaps, as an act of setting the record straight.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Not a comprehensive documentary biopic, but nonetheless provocative, invigorating and well-edited.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A worthwhile appreciation of the artist.

name: Nothing Compares
review: She influenced so many women and female artists to stand up for themselves and their rights, and it’s great this doc brings that influence to light.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It presents the artist and activist as a woman, though tormented by her own demons, ahead of her time, and a lightning rod for society’s discomfort with a woman who refused to abide by its cultural norms.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A bracing, eye-opening, straight-no-chaser documentary appreciation

name: Nothing Compares
review: Despite some messy implications towards the latter portion, "Nothing Compares" is a focused musical documentary that reveres its subject in a non-heavy-handed manner.

name: Nothing Compares
review: ...an affecting look at how fame and celebrity can truly be dangerous for someone ill prepared to stand under such an invasive spotlight.

name: Nothing Compares
review: O'Connor was very outspoken about race schisms of Black people in England.  When artist like Bob Dylan made music opposing hierarchy all the time -  the masses embraced him.  Yet my girl Sinéad was disrespected for the sheer fact she was the wrong gender.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Kathryn Ferguson’s documentary Nothing Compares makes several mistakes in its noble mission to recover the mostly unhappy pop career of the Irish-born singer Sinéad O’Connor.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It's an honest film that does great by her as an artist and shows her as an even greater person.

name: Nothing Compares
review: This documentary is comprehensive and meditative, but it doesn’t spend enough time on her mesmerizing voice and earthy performances.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Think of this documentary as a package of the greatest hits... The meat of the film shows in glorious detail how Ms. OConnor burst onto the global stage like a beautiful alien in the early 90s.

name: Nothing Compares
review: You cant come out from watching this movie without thinking that OConnor got the rawest of raw deals because she dared to stand out from the crowd, but its useful and uplifting to see her true impact acknowledged and celebrated like this.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares mounts a compelling argument for the reassessment of yet another intense, intensely interesting musician demonized far beyond the scope of her actions.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Shame on the Prince estate for refusing to allow her shattering rendition of the title track to appear in the film.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A feminist portrait that presents us with a celebrity who has remained true to herself and suffered the consequences.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares is a sturdy assembly of archival footage and interviews that shows O'Connor's equal aptitude for being a star and lightning rod.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Although Ferguson's intentions are praiseworthy, the ensuing product of the filmmaker's admiration falls short of greatness.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares is a bold re-examination of O'Connor's all-too-brief window of wider influence, and a searing critique of the sexist and conservative backlash that led to her retreat from public life.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Though O'Connor's beautiful rendition of "Nothing Compares 2 U" is never heard in the movie as a result of a rights issue with Prince's estate, its absence serves as an eerie structural void, giving this fairly conventional bio-doc an admirable weight.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares is one of the most important documentaries made in years, and it serves as a timely reminder of the dangers of censorship, which is spreading more rapidly today than it was three decades ago when the universe turned against O'Connor.

name: Nothing Compares
review: More than just another typical rock star documentary, Nothing Compares is a challenging work that observes O'Connor's musical and cultural legacy through social, political and sexual frameworks.

name: Nothing Compares
review: The focus of Kathryn Ferguson's first feature-length film is O'Connor's ahead-of-the-mainstream courage, and her outrage.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Ferguson's Nothing Compares is as bold as her iconic subject.

name: Nothing Compares
review: An empowering documentary about an artist who wasn't afraid to speak and show her truth.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It would be cool as hell if Nothing Compares inspired even just one up-and-coming artist to stick it to the man the way Sinéad O'Connor did.

name: Nothing Compares
review: By honing in on a specific time frame but contextualizing it within Sinéad's life, the film allows us to get to know the subject intimately.

name: Nothing Compares
review: There were obviously outspoken musicians before O'Connor, but the film draws a direct link between her activism and the later activism of many other female musicians.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares reckons with the idea of whether O'Connor, her ideas, and the way she used her platform as a soapbox were before her time.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A Compassionate Look At Sinéad O'Connor's Pop Stardom Rise And Fall

name: Nothing Compares
review: The treasure trove of material impresses, with copious contemporary television interviews supplementing the performance and music-video footage.

name: Nothing Compares
review: An enriching experience.

name: Nothing Compares
review: In part through the artist's own words, Ferguson reveals O'Connor as an insightful, emotionally damaged artist with unshakeable integrity.

name: Nothing Compares
review: What the film [reveals] anew is an artist far more principled, talented and enduring than her critics and many of her contemporaries.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Vital viewing on society's road to enlightenment; a path O'Connor still travels herself.

name: Nothing Compares
review: In terms of the fame by which the pop stratosphere defines itself, Sinéad O'Connor was a fire that went out too fast. "Nothing Compares" makes you see it's still burning.

name: Nothing Compares
review: [A] vital testament to the bravery and significance of this preternaturally gifted, much maligned and embattled artist.

name: Nothing Compares
review: Nothing Compares thoughtfully reckons with the intertwined cycles of adulation and controversy which have defined Sinéad O'Connor's musical career, offering compassionate insight into a most singular artist.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A fascinating insight into a very singular person.

name: Nothing Compares
review: It's a potent film that explores the roots of the brilliant but troubled Irish singer, but it also turns her recent years into an afterthought, bypassing many of the highs and lows of the last two decades.

name: Nothing Compares
review: A powerful reclaim of the history and legacy of O'Connor, whose rebellious spirit and drive to speak against injustice inspired generations to come. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Nothing Compares
review: One comes away from Nothing Compares fully understanding that this was an artist that really did have nothing to lose.

name: Nothing Compares
review: This is a noteworthy document that fans and naysayers should take a look at and by the end when you discover why her most well-known song is left out of the movie you may be ripping up the picture of a certain artist who shall not be named.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Jenkins' film doesn’t play like your standard biography. It’s more intimate than that, more personal and far more revealing than most works about the jazz giant.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Armstrong’s smiling image was important to him. I wish this documentary had been less interested in preserving that, though, and more focused on helping us understand the totality of a titanic artist and a fascinating man.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Some stunningly crisp archive footage, particularly of old American chat and variety TV shows, combines with previously unheard personal recordings to create this rounded portrait of one of jazz’s most influential players.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: While he was internationally recognized and revered for his musical skill and legacy, he had strong opinions about the civil rights issues in his homeland. Archival footage and never-before-heard home recordings of his opinions illuminate these points.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Sacha Jenkins’ engrossing and informative documentary Louis Armstrong’s Black & Blues reintroduces one of the 20th century’s most towering and beloved cultural icons to a new generation.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: It’s a must for Armstrong fans, and for those new to Satchmo, a great introduction to a jazz icon.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Focuses on Armstrong's personality, his legacy and cultural impact, and the way he used his fame and influence to break down some of the first barriers caused by racism.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: While other self-narrations could pull a punch, Armstrong’s openness is refreshing.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: It has something new to say, and says it with poise, polish and compassion.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: By mining out a large array of archive footage, Jenkins crafts a more full-bodied picture of an artist that is perhaps only known to a younger generation as the gravelly singer of “What a wonderful world.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: It’s easy to see how the director was influenced and inspired by the great Louis Armstrong to generate Jenkins’ own creative, filmmaking version, of jazz

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Armstrong will always be remembered fondly for his musicality, but having his opinions on various topics and societal issues so prominently displayed allows us to hear him loud and clear, and maybe for the first time ever.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Black and Blues’ forensic examination gives a three-dimensional portrait of the man known affectionately as “Pops” and “Sachmo”. No-one is one thing, particularly in show business, and Jenkins’ well-researched film shows the beauty in complication.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Though the director Sacha Jenkins’s biographical portrait of Louis Armstrong is blandly conventional in its form, its wide-ranging material is inspiring and illuminating.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: This picks some very specific spots, but his relationship with civil rights leaders... All of that is really fascinating.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: A deeply affecting and mesmerizing documentary.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: …joyfully but soberly investigates Armstrong’s immense artistry and complicated legacy.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: “Louis Armstrong’s Black & Blues” is an involving, well documented look at the professional and personal highs and lows of a genuine American treasure.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Enriched by Armstrong’s own mighty library of writings and tape recordings, the man that emerges is intriguingly complex: doggedly apolitical yet politically engaged.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Refreshing documentary on the gravelly-voiced great pioneering Black jazzman Louis Armstrong.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: With Armstrong's soaring sound and story of survival, Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues is sure to resonate with film viewers.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: This movie could have been twice as long and still not covered what it should have, but as is, it still manages to pack a punch and make its case for Armstrong being one of music’s greatest talents.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: One of the film’s tantalizing paradoxes is that even as Armstrong remains a holy 20th-century icon, the film is likely to open many viewers’ eyes — for the first time — to who he really was.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: A graceful overview of one of the 20th century’s greatest artists, Louis Armstrong’s Black & Blues puts politics, musical appreciation and personal history into one attractive package.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: What the documentary does... with focus and flair, is explore Armstrong's multifaceted experience as a Black American musician who came of age right along with the 20th century, enduring the worst and somehow embodying the best.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: The angle that director Sacha Jenkins contemplates is a deeper portrait of the man nicknamed Satchmo, who transcended his roots to become a beloved and almost symbolic icon for the better angels of our nature. W/Jenkins interview. Pops has the chops!

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: As you’d expect, there is wonderful musical footage as well as some unexpected revelations.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Armstrong preferred to keep his dissatisfactions to himself, becoming a symbol of change rather than a spokesperson of it. That tension comes to vivid life in Jenkins's worthy account...

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: “Black & Blues” isn’t a straightforward biography so much as a collection of engaging anecdotes and keen observations, meant to spark a renewed appreciation for someone too often misunderstood.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Even if you think you already know everything about Armstrong, Jenkins will show you more, or at least illuminate new facets of well-known facts.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: It's biographical jazz that permits digressions and gives itself the freedom to jump around as it pleases.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Weaving together a remarkable collection of archival footage, Jenkins probes Armstrong’s turbulent personal life and triumphs over adversity while enabling his legendary gravelly-voiced charisma to command the spotlight.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues presents a vital conversation and a fine biography without allowing one mode -- or one side of the conversation -- overtake the other.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Louis Armstrong’s stature as a musician and entertainer needs no burnishing but Sacha Jenkins’ archival documentary reminds us of his complex relationship to racism.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Armstrong's life, along with his infectious laugh, hoarse voice, and way of singing that became the norm, is analyzed and reconstructed with absolute attention to detail, an unavoidable documentary for lovers of jazz and Satchmo. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: There are many marvelous moments in the documentary.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: An unprecedented look at a man who endured blind hatred, crushing poverty, and bitter misunderstanding — yet who could, at the end of his life, sing with convincing authority, “What a Wonderful World.”

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Provides a nuanced, sympathetic rebuttal of the crude accusations of Uncle Tom-ism that Armstrong faced... There is less insight about his musical development, however. That is the high note that eludes an otherwise well-made and enjoyable documentary.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: This latest 'Jammie' from director Sacha Jenkins practically takes the fabled jazz musician and all-around showman from cradle to grave with a fascinating assortment of personal letters and audio recordings left by the performer himself. (mini-review)

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: By foregrounding... Armstrong’s voice, and mining an archival mother lode of audio and video interviews and clips, Jenkins delivers a bountiful portrait of one of the 20th century’s superstars — on Armstrong’s own terms.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Mr. Jenkins does a good job of a difficult thing, establishing why Armstrong was a musical genius. Also, why he lost favor during a period of civil-rights legislation and increasingly black activism.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Like one of Armstrong’s great solos, it feels packed with dynamics, sprinkled with astonishing high notes, and immensely pleasurable.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: With access to Armstrong’s voluminous archives comprised of audio tapes, clippings and letters, director Sacha Jenkins ("Bitchin': The Sound and Fury of Rick James") sketches a picture of a man who was far more complicated than his public image.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: With all that's been said, reported and written about Louis Armstrong over the decades, it's shocking how eye and ear-opening Sacha Jenkins' new documentary about him is.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: A mesmerizing documentary that takes us behind the iconography of the jazzman and shows us, in his own words, the vibrant human soul who lived there.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: I would watch Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues again and again for the music alone, but thanks to the magnificent work of Sacha Jenkins there are a myriad of other reasons to watch what is unquestionably one of the year's very best musical documentaries.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review:
Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues reveals the iconic entertainer in a brilliantly artistic format. 
Sacha Jenkins presents the jazz master using collages, archival footage, and his own words. Armstrong is front and center for a remarkable experience.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: The magical sounds Satchmo created gave people joy and so will this deeply affecting bio/doc.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: For the first time on film Armstrong is allowed to toot his own horn, as it were, allowing his ideas as much as his music to flourish.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: The filmmaker shows a profound understanding of the subject matter, including political aspects that are highly relevant decades later.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Sacha Jenkins eloquently shares the story of a legend that we barely knew as a musician or a man.  Louis Armstrong blazed a trail in jazz, but had a side that will surprise, elate and leave audiences with a different kind of respect for his legacy

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Watch this documentary especially if all you know of Louis Armstrong is “What a Wonderful World.” You can catch up with the rest of the grooves later.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: Jenkins is undaunted by the complexity of his subject, plunging ahead with swagger and not worrying if we have unanswered questions at the end.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: With this tuneful, tender documentary, director Sacha Jenkins convincingly makes the case that there was no more significant music figure in the entire 20th century than Louis Armstrong.

name: Louis Armstrong's Black & Blues
review: A doc that will make you appreciate Armstrong, the man. Someone far too complex to reduce to any one thing.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande

Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The two leads are terrific in a witty sex-positive bedroom farce that seduces and satisfies.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A very likable sample of a periodic rarity, a first-rate film actress making a serious film about female sexuality with as much frankness and even nudity as the era will permit.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This little film is one huge step forward in sex positive cinema. I honestly want to recommend it to everyone, no matter how experienced they may be with sex already. Everyone can learn something from this.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Daryl McCormack graced us with stellar performances...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: More than a mere philosophical exercise, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is sweet, sexy, and certainly the new favorite film of Father Intintola from The Sopranos.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Hyde splashes the story with sincere, touching, and sparkling moments that invite empathy, approaching emotions not yet discovered with caution.  [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: If we ever had a preconceived idea of ​​the patterns that govern a relationship, it's very likely that this film will transform it, with its risky subject, experimental tone, and theatrical style. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Leo tells Nancy he is there to fulfil her fantasy, but she is compelled to keep digging obsessively in search of reality.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: An unconventional, “march to its own beat” film that slowly lays into you, story-wise. The beginning is simple and interesting enough for most proper age groups to digest it, which helps the buy-in factor when the tone gets more serious.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A tennis match of gestures and talks, and if it reaches fruition is because the performers escalate towards similar heights: he, with forced and yapping gallantry; her, with the dramatic flair of wearing her emotions on her skin. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Never mind 'Good.' It's Great.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson shines… becoming a revolutionary, subversive, and necessary character.  [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The pleasure of this film isn’t really in identifying with Nancy’s sexual awakening … It’s the way Leo and Nancy anticipate and evade each other’s judgments, as the power balance shifts back and forth between them.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: There's not a wrong note between McCormack and Thompson.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: a riveting encounter between two strangers, illuminated by brilliant performances from Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack… takes an adventurous route to depict an older woman’s search for sexual pleasure

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sex comedies have rarely felt so lived in, so comfortable, so earnest or so nuanced, or like such a release.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a deeply sensual film.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson's winning nature as a performer helps sustain this two-hander with good intentions and a wobbly tone.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: You could call Brand’s script an exercise in delayed gratification except that it elevates the delay itself into an entertaining and perceptive exploration of eroticism and its many subtleties.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: With a complete lack of visual spice, it might've been better as play.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: There is simply not enough information about Nancy to explain how a woman of her age, education and relative attractiveness, living in an open society and working as a professional educator, could find herself in such a sexually unfulfilled situation.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: In increasingly puritanical times where sex and even mature conversations about sex are almost absent from mainstream cinema, it is so refreshing to be gifted a film that treats the topic with the respect and joy that it deserves.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The most seductive element of “Good Luck to You, Leo Grande” is the honesty it brings to Nancy and Leo in the first two acts. It isn’t until the clunky final chapter that a frustrating sense of artificiality creeps in.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Deftly handled direction from Sophie Hyde and a thoroughly impressive dual performance from Emma Thompson  and Daryl McCormack enlivens an electric script, tackling taboo sexual subjects with wit, flair and welcome realism.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Hilarious and heartrending, this might just be the best movie of the year so far.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson is a one-woman whirlwind as a retired schoolteacher with desires above and beyond the classroom.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film connects with its audience through laughter and pain. However, character development isn't as convincing. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Predictable and suffocating in an enclosed setting where two protagonists, face to face, run their lines towards an inexorable, calculated exercise of reciprocal catharsis. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Nothing boils, either literally or metaphorically, because everything's made just right so it doesn't scorch, and then, a delicious, warm infusion can be enjoyed. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A somewhat naïve, politically correct, and sentimental contemporary reversal [Rom Com] in the vein of Pretty Woman and The Graduate, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande sustains itself on two extraordinary performances. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: ... An intimate and personal experience that's particularly insightful and charming. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Strenuously overacted, the film is more interested in being topical and “sex positive” than engaging and original.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The feature film investigates the sensuality and intimate desires of the characters, doing it in a respectful way, without falling into the explicit.  [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sophie Hyde delivers a thoroughly charming (and thoughtful) two-hander with Good Luck to You, Leo Grande...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: I like the title they went with, but I have no idea how they resisted not calling it Let’s Talk About Sex, because that is 80% of the movie.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It certainly helps if you like dialogue-heavy films but, if not, don’t be put off, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is brave, funny, sensitive, and challenging - but oh so good at the same time.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Leo Grande is a compelling coming-of-age tale that lets us peer into the fragile, fractious process of confronting shame about sex, and a woman's journey...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Nancy Stokes is a retired religious education teacher, mother of two adult children, and recently widowed. You might think that sex would be low on her list. You’d be wrong. And it would be particularly wrong to miss this smart, sweet, funny film.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grand is that rare film that marries goodness and mercy with womanly wit.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The result defies mass media expectations of poster girls, instead providing a rare cinematic opportunity to deal with reality.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck has worthwhile ideas to explore about sex, aging and body acceptance.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson dazzles in this poignantly honest, tenderly erotic dramedy, aimed at mature audiences.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Viewers who accept the film's staginess will be rewarded, though, because Brand and Hyde give the actors opportunities to shine while avoiding the largest potential pitfalls in the material.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: An entertaining comedy with great performances from the leads that affirms both body and sex positivity.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Although this is primarily a two-hander, we don’t feel trapped, because the company is enjoyable and the banter entertaining.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This wholly sex-positive film is itself as unpredictable in its subtleties as it is powerful in its exploration of compassion, body image, ageism, and outdated social ideas about pleasure.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It's alternately riveting, amusing and hard to watch. Never before have we seen such a compelling portrayal of a middle aged woman’s sexuality.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The compositions are of professional quality and the simple luxury provided by the art department–the movie is set mostly in a chic but practical hotel room–add texture.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Critics are fawning over Good Luck to You, Leo Grande for its “brave” sex positivity. But the crowd-pleasing comedy is actually anxiously prescriptive, and it relies on an angelic and selfless sex worker to teach a middle-aged woman how to love her body.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson makes it all work by jumping in without restraint, giving a top performance...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Full of honesty and humanity, utterly lacking in shame over a basic human need, the female experience of which is almost universally ignored onscreen. Light, funny, diverting. So why was I bawling?

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: "Good Luck” reveals itself to be not just an exchange of bodily fluids, but an exchange of ideas offering insights into the power of intimacy and human connection.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It’s the film’s frank and honest discussion of sex and female desire that makes Leo Grande so enjoyable.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: ... does it all with true empathy and a pleasantly warm regard for the joy of sex.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Fairly corny with a constructed feel to it--and a bit script-y--but still a solid comedy/drama with substantive themes elevated by the two  leads.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson...radiates an honesty that is as endearing as it is insightful.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A smart and irresistible adult comedy driven by Emma Thompson's sensational performance. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This is a fearlessly raw performance, and Thompson never overplays her hand.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sophie Hyde’s well-lit modern interiors look crisp enough to be engaging without overwhelming the foreground where we’re frequently viewing our half-clothed characters sharing their innermost secrets, though not their names.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film supposedly bypasses the ickiness of a conventional prostitution story by putting female pleasure at the centre of the action. But it’s still a kind of pleasure that depends on cash changing hands.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: he strength of Leo Grande is that it’s about how sex can lead to self-discovery and self-acceptance.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck is a two-person show, and its success hinges on the chemistry between Thompson and McCormack; thankfully, that chemistry is easy and abundant, as Leo and Nancy quietly change one another’s lives in this honest, intimate dramedy.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sophie Hyde’s [film is] delightful -- and sneakily radical.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film is playlike in structure and works because of its capable leads, delicately meted emotional rawness and a vulnerability well mixed with moments of giddy whimsy and palpable passion.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson unapologetically illustrates the beauty of embracing sexuality with a younger man in all its awkwardness, intrigue and vulnerability.  This a strong-willed rally cry to embrace your body will all the lumps, pooches and flaps with pride.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: I thought it would be just two-dimensioned but I was wrong. The bond that develops between the two characters as Leo frees Nancy’s hidden spirit for adventure in a sweet and charming way.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film does Disneyfy the sex industry slightly, but the dialogue is pretty good, and Thompson and McCormack bring compelling naturalism to their roles.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson makes it crackle, and McCormack gives as good as he gets with a graceful turn as a young man harbouring some serious baggage.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The observations are insightful and sharply important, as are the bravely transparent performances from the two lead actors.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande presents a compelling contrast to the scores of coming-of-age movies. Because it’s not about misguided youth blossoming into self-actualization. It’s about self-actualization after a life of regret.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson is operating at a level we haven't seen from her since at least Angels in America... It's further proof, if you needed any, that she's one of the greatest screen actors of all time.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Given the habit of cinema to depict the sex industry as nothing more than an exploitative hellscape, it’s very welcome to see it used as the backdrop for a genuinely sweet comedy.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A film with a refreshingly frank view of sexuality is quite a rarity. It’s even rarer that the script, direction, and performances all mesh so well together in a breezy 97 minutes! The chemistry between the two leads is wonderful to watch.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a sentimental film from writer Katy Brand that shines even brighter thanks to the film’s limited setting.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It's like a really well-written play... It's disarming, surprising, and thought-provoking.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: You can know all about sex and nothing about pleasure, and that’s the distinction that Good Luck To You, Leo Grande explores with a keen eye and a big heart.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Manages to keep one foot firmly on the floor of enjoyably progressive entertainment even as it dances around a peculiarly British minefield in which anxiety and openness about intimacy collide.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: GOOD LUCK TO YOU, LEO GRANDE tackles one of the last taboo subjects: the sexuality of older women.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sex Work Is The New Black Mammy. And elephants in the room of invisible blackness, the 'happy slave' to only fulfill the white characters, the sexualized black male caricature - and buying a sex toy instead of all the cash spent on this pointless movie.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: ...if you can find better than Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack you’d just be showing off. Wouldn’t you? The characters they portray are beautifully broken and their onscreen duet is magnetic in its dissonance.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Where some viewers will immediately implode with pearl-clutching outrage hellbent on voicing warped decency and unfair determinations, others will be ignited by the possibilities of this premise and the talent involved.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: 'Leo Grande' features a pair of truly grand performances in a two-hander of four acts (and sorry if we're talking both theatrical and sexual connotations here).

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack are incredibly winning in this warm and authentic tale of contentment vs. fulfillment and the never-ending anxiety of chasing just a little bit of pleasure for oneself.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson has always been a terrific actor, but she reaches a new plane here, a place where her vulnerability as a person and her confidence as a performer mesh into something glorious.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: In a very British fashion, eroticism is undercut by constant embarrassed comedy. The nation hasn’t moved quite so far from Carry On as the film pretends.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Not as taboo as you might think, but more of a character study with a fantastic and vulnerable performance by Emma Thompson.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: An anti-romcom skillfully treading the line between loveliness and raunchiness while busting through Hollywood conceptions about leading ladies of a certain age.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Fronted with phenomenal chemistry and performance from Thompson and McCormack, its intimate subject matter explodes on screen, challenging a variety of stigmas while welcoming its audience to enjoy the experience.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a dramedy shot during the pandemic that demonstrates, with the right actors and the right story to tell, you don’t need much more than a stylish hotel room to make magic.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The story evolves in predictable ways but McCormack and Thompson keep things real.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Those expecting a feel-good sex-positive film won’t be disappointed, but “Good Luck To You, Leo Grande” is a deeper and richer film that’s about more than how Nancy got her groove back.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to you, Leo Grande is gently empowering in its lack of judgment. It’s a refreshing alternative to a discourse frequently dominated by puritanical avoidance.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Director Sophie Hyde and writer Katy Brand beautifully explore aging women’s desires and needs and what it means to finally love yourself. Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack’s chemistry is intense and each give brilliant performances.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson lays herself bare in the dramedy Good Luck to You, Leo Grande, but it's the emotional aspects that deserve the most attention, in this funny and sensitively told two-hander.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande attempts to see its two leads as the humans they are while also giving us glimpses of the types they might be tempted to see each other as.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It could have been a two-hander play, rather than a movie, and banal framing, lighting, and camerawork do nothing to help the claustrophobic blandness.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sometimes hard to watch but impossible to turn away from.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
