review: This sobering treatment of what some women may want takes a while to hit its stride, and features a winsome Emma Thompson, managing to land the fluctuations of her characterization even when the narrative feels like a lasso.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It's a relief to see a film so frank about sex, and so open to sex's complexities, especially when so much of current cinema is sexless to a disheartening degree.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Refusing to be defined by romantic comedy cliches, this intimate and powerfully acted character study sprinkles gentle humor throughout its exploration of aging, sexuality, and self-esteem.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A masterclass of acting, writing, and directing (Kate Brand), flawless, realistic and challenging.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson continues to evolve as an actor in ways that most stars could only dream of.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Brave and frank little film about two different generations exploring bedroom secrets.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It’s a therapy of the most intimate.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: An only occasionally amusing two-hander that makes a serious point about female sexual liberation and argues for the legalisation of prostitution.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film is intimate without feeling particularly deep or complicated. Not that it needs to be.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The screenplay has its share of uneven moments, especially during the second half, but Thompson’s performance never wavers.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This movie knows it’s selling a fantasy of its own. But it’s hard not to warm to that fantasy, or to embrace its still-rare vision of a woman learning to articulate and satisfy her most human impulses.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: We may be stuck inside one stuffy hotel room, but thanks to smart, funny writing and two excellent performances, "Good Luck to You, Leo Grande" is a lot more engaging than your average Covid-era filmmaking exercise.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Not only is it about accepting others for who they are, but – and most importantly – it’s about accepting oneself.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Has a true sense of human nature about sex, & its climax (har har) is the strength of the film, as all the factors with the odd couple come to a (shut your mouth) necessary conclusion. Eminently discussable, if the people in the room can be honest. Emma!

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck To You, Leo Grande is the sex-positive crowdpleaser the movie landscape needs right now.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A nicely realized film...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The real intimacy of the film is the sense of discovering the real people behind a transactional façade.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: These two people are better off for having known each other, and we're better off for having spent a little time with them, too.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: ...the feel-good movie of the year, and not at all in the way that I might have at first suspected.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: McCormack’s assignment is to hold his own against an international treasure, and he’s up to the challenge, refusing to reduce Leo to a Ken doll delivery system of late-middle-age sexual fulfillment.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson is truly better than ever and brings to life a complex and evolving person with humor, grace and a sharp edge. McCormack, meanwhile, is a star in the making.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A winning duet....It works because Katy Brand’s writing is skillfully calculated and Sophie Hyde’s direction adept, but mostly because the lead performances are expertly gauged, and complement each other so nicely.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Empowerment is only one piece of the puzzle, which together forms a refreshingly nuanced portrait of sex work, desire and self-perception.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: "Leo Grande" is about emotional and physical honesty, and Thompson gives her all in seeking those truths. Bravo.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It’s a movie about private encounters that just may be a public good: sex ed, or life ed, for grownups.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a body-positive charmer from a delightfully fresh perspective. Cinema rarely explores the wants and needs of older women. The film embraces honest sexuality from an all-encompassing viewpoint.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: There is genuine chemistry between the two leads and McCormack is insanely charismatic while Emma Thompson is very Emma Thompson but also world class.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Leo Grande is a quiet film that makes a case for private pleasure in conventional terms. That shouldn’t be revolutionary. But right now, it is.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: As the characters get more intimate, so too does the film, with McCormack and, especially, Thompson cutting through the film’s more mechanical execution to deliver rounded portraits of people yearning for human connection in a judgmental world.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Director Sophie Hyde, working from a smart, nuanced script by Katy Brand, provides just enough space and pace for Thompson and McCormack’s chemistry to combust, seemingly in real time.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Any time a film is able to depict a bond between two people that feels this truthful, it's worth celebrating.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It’s a lighthearted comedy that takes on some pretty heavy material in a delicate yet impactful way. A film about a woman in her sixties, bare-breasted, aiming for the best orgasm of her life will make some people uncomfortable.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: With a fierce honestly and a dry wit, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande asks us all why we can't enjoy touch, sex, pleasure, the way we want (safely, consensually), with or without strings, as human needs demand.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande, so touchingly performed by Thompson and McCormack and sympathetically directed by Sophie Hyde, was written by the earnest comedian Katy Brand, a former evangelical Christian.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: more of a dual character study than the sex positive comedy it appears to be on its surface…McCormack…has a real breakout role here, the actor constantly teasing and intriguing us as he goes toe to toe with the two time Oscar winner.  He’s magnetic.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A tart and tender probe into sex and intimacy, power dynamics and human connection.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Even though Emma Thompson is one of the most charming performers ever to go before cameras, there's only so much she can do.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Truthfully, the film is almost not a film at all, but a stage two-hander director Sophie Hyde works hard to give big-screen zing.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The evolution of her confidence - both personal and sexual - is beautiful to behold, and Thompson depicts this ever so delicately, making Nancy's progression feel plausible and never finding herself hitting a false beat.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Hyde is basically making a filmed play, but there's vulnerability presented here that's remarkable to behold at times.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It provides Thompson with one of the best roles of her career, bringing a beautiful and personal honesty in playing a woman who feels the tug and pulls of her emotions in a world that repeatedly defines what women should do and how they should behave.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson and McCormack are fantastic enough in their own right and together that it would be interesting to watch them read the phone book in a hotel room for that amount of time.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This drama was undoubtedly very inexpensive to make, but it's incredibly rich in the themes and messages it seeks to convey.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sophisticated respect for sex work bursts through every dialogue exchange in Good Luck to You, Leo Grande, as Nancy and Leo get steamy and thoughtful. It's very lighthearted, funny, and wholesomely erotic

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande demonstrates that sex can be exciting and humorous and pragmatic and transactional all wrapped up into one.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It's witty and sexy, funny and touching, and explores the topic of sexuality and acceptance in later life with grace and gentleness without losing any of its incisiveness.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Two fantastic performances and some non-icky sexual politics.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson and McCormack have irresistible chemistry together, and offer riveting performances in this funny, candid movie.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Hyde and Brand are dealing with issues of consent beyond the physical realm. What happens on-screen in this room is a fantasy despite whatever real work is being done within its constraints. Nancy removes her public persona as Leo puts his on.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Overall 'Good Luck to You, Leo Grande' is a great film. It’s super sexy, it lightens the heart, and the main subjects are body image and ageism.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: But despite the single setting, the film never feels constrained or claustrophobic. Against the blandness of these humdrum visuals, the performances absolutely pop.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande hardly reads like a project worthy of much interest, instead choosing to play things safe with a subject that requires anything but.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson and Daryl McCormack, along with Katy Brand’s script, make sweet, vulnerable, and benevolent music together.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film abounds in honest and at times disarmingly off-the-cuff moments that are borne out of character contrasts.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The title of Good Luck to You, Leo Grande has the name of the gigolo in this comedy/drama, but the movie's more fascinating story arc is with Nancy Stokes, the woman who hires Leo. Emma Thompson, who plays Nancy in the movie, gives a stellar performance.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck To You Leo Grande is sweet and vulnerable. It explores sex, sexuality, and sex work as what it can do for people...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A film of convincing performances and progressive attitudes toward sexuality and body types

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: There is duly a slightly theatrical feel to proceedings, but such is the quality of both the acting and writing, it never feels stagey.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Brazenly explores an older woman’s sexuality in a way that’s frank and explicit, both verbally and visually. Many will see Thompson’s nude scenes as brave or daring. But doesn’t that speak to the exact societal expectations the film is trying to shatter?

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Consistently enjoyable due in part to both actors, particularly the luminous Emma Thompson that has one of the better final moments of the year. Essentially a two-character filmed play in execution; the dialogue is smart, sexy and compassionate

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson gives a brave performance in this ultimately endearing story

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: An affecting exploration of an outwardly self-assured woman gaining an altogether more internal sense of confidence.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: As much as I wanted to enjoy this modest production about the most immodest thing of all, sexuality, I couldn’t help but feel a little let down.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film is deeply knowledgeable about the fact that sex and pleasure can be two very different things. To a depressing degree.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A very modern, forward, and entertaining treatment of a subject the movies have more often than not been too squeamish to address: older women’s sexuality.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Our voyeur into two individuals’ candid exchanges of shame and chaos is redirected towards its end on a positive note of intimacy and positivity -- an onscreen manifesto of loving being human and loving being women.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film has a wonderful, empowering sex positive attitude and its so genuine about it.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Inevitably, there is a slight air of the stage about this and an emotional gear change at the midway point doesn't quite feel fully earned but the actors so fully inhabit these roles that they carry you with them.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: While it would be incredibly easy for a film like Good Luck to You, Leo Grande to sink into the void of just being an average comedy, the final result here is something nearly remarkable.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Comedy writer Katy Brand hits a nerve that women of a certain age will understand -- and possibly men too.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Both leads backstories are conflicted yet simple. There are no great reveals or revelations, no a-ha moments. In this way Good Luck to You, Leo Grande elevates above a premise that couldve easily become too cute by half.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson is a tour de force in Sophie Hyde’s Good Luck to You, Leo Grande...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Deliciously appealing.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: It's a front-row seat to watch Emma Thompson do her thing while at the top of her game. But then again, when isn't she at the top of her game?

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: To say that Emma Thompson is marvelous here is an absolute understatement.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompsons comic timing hasnt been so sharp since The Tall Guy, which had a similar joke about sneezes.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson is dynamite, playing up the line between prudish schoolmarm and flesh-hungry horndog and how these dueling attitudes fight it out within her, and McCormack... makes a swell intro to what should be a larger mainstream audience.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Leo Grande wins out in the end, for being as charming as it is, but among all the cute healing there is a sense it could be a little more if it wanted to.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A smart, incisive and occasionally quite sexy look at two opposites forging a genuine human connection under the most unexpected of circumstances.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This is one thoughtful upstart that delivers a rare, healthy, much-needed message: Give yourself the freedom to enjoy sex.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: What separates Good Luck to You, Leo Grande from other films of this premise of few characters and locations is its excellent camerawork.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A two-hander between one of the best actresses of our lifetimes and a total unknown (unless you watch the Irish soaps) who burns through the screen with the impact of a new Marlon Brando.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Directed by Sophie Hyde and written by Katy Brand, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a frank and good-natured movie about trying to come to terms with yourself, your history, and your body, and Thompson and McCormack give subtle, generous performances.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a spellbinding piece of filmmaking, an acting masterclass, a celebration of the written word, and a powerful cinematic plea for self-acceptance and self-love.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson and McCormack have such a lovely, fine-tuned chemistry as two people who are in such different places in their lives but have more common ground than you would expect.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Hyde did a stellar job showing the insecurities women have about sexuality, aging, femininity, and worth, and the ways men can relate to these themes in their own way.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The role of Nancy serves as a greatest hits compilation for Thompson.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A movie starring the peerless Emma Thompson as a go-getting widow looking for good sex? You have to show up for Sophie Hyde's earnestly sex-positive dramedy based on this premise alone!

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Emma Thompson is sensational in a part that relies on her voluminous nervous energy.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sophie Hyde's Good Luck To You, Leo Grande isn't about grief per se. It's a disarming dramedy about sexual awakening, body positivity and female pleasure.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A wonderful film that doesn't overcomplicate things and reminds us not to either ...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Both a body positive and a sex positive affair, Good Luck To You, Leo Grande strives in its attempt to ultimately be a film that celebrates the act of sex but, more importantly, salutes the ramifications of such.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The premise of Good Luck to You, Leo Grande may sound crass but it's actually an exquisite examination of relationship dynamics through clever wordplay.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A beautiful movie about desire and pleasure, this is the rare crowd-pleaser that's still willing to take risks.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: "Emma Thompson hires a male escort" is a high enough concept that it could be a big studio raunchy comedy. Of course, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande, which premiered virtually at the Sundance Film Festival, classes it up considerably.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film steps into uncharted territory and Thompson has the guts to help convey the message.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson is extraordinary as she navigates the various insecurities that come with inexperience, age, and general repression, and McCormack is a charming and understanding match for her.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson delivers an award-worthy performance in a new film. But it’s a testament to her talent what she accomplishes in Good Luck to You, Leo Grande.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A lovely film, one that relies so heavily on the brilliant script by Katy Brand, and the brave performances by both actors.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Katy Brand's screenplay sparkles, avoiding Hollywood clichés as both sides of this sexual exploration talk and act like real people rather than stereotypes.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson is a neurotic wonder. She delivers a tremendously layered performance. And it's nice to see the tables turned and a dude viewed as a sex object. McCormack handles it with aplomb.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson has never been this vulnerable and her glow and energy alongside McCormack's suave Casanova presence will melt your heart.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: If you thought the "sex worker with a heart of gold" genre had fully blown its load, then director Sophie Hyde's latest endeavor will surprise you.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Given the number of movies made about men hiring sex workers, it's nice to see this kind of exploration, too, made both without judgement and with a good deal of humor.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is utterly charming, thoughtful in its character development, and in the exploration of its themes about sex & self-love.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A talky charmer of a movie: sweet, thoughtful, honest, and saucy without ever feeling performatively provocative.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A film about the pleasure that every human being deserves, about the perception that one has about their own body, and about female sexuality. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A refreshing, intelligent bedroom drama, Good Luck To You, Leo Grande is a quietly hilarious study on emotional and sexual intimacy carried by two powerhouse performances.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A tender coming-of-late-middle-age drama with a quietly radical idea of self-acceptance at its center.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This is some of the finest acting Thompson has done, not lacking in vanity but grappling with it, as a character, an actor, a woman, and a human.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: This is Thompson at her best, a witty, dazzling. and above all brave performance that will undoubtedly be talked about.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A psychological conversation piece titillated by the potential of sex.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The sex? It eventually arrives in a rapid-fire montage of multiple positions that’s supposed to be daring and audacious but is oddly reminiscent of the absurdist puppet bonking in Team America: World Police. Like the entire film, it means well but ...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The film may be as dodgy as it is ground-breaking, but the chemistry between the two actors is undeniably grand.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: The cast and crew, led by Australian filmmaker Sophie Hyde, have put so much care into making the most within the piece's limited confines that one could hardly deride the final product as stagy.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Breaking down taboos around our attitudes to sex on screen is a laudable project, and one that the British two-hander Good Luck to You, Leo Grande gets at least half right.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Thompson's courage is in allowing herself, an Oscar and Emmy winner with lots of other accolades, explore an intimate world we don't see in films nowadays.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A simple movie that is both inspiring & powerful. Thompson & McCormack have incredible chemistry that delivers heart, humor, & important lessons about loving yourself.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Despite a sterling effort from Thompson, neither the comedy nor the character arcs are fully satisfying.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: A touching little two-hander that does right by its title character...

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Intimate in every sense, Good Luck to You, Leo Grande represents an affirming, immensely likable British comedy-drama.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Despite some moments of sentimentality and naivety, it is really watchable and conceived with a flair for commanding the audience's attention.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande is a showcase for Emma Thompson, and rightly so.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Hyde uses the hypnotic dance of two masterful performances to address themes of female sexual repression with sensitivity and honesty. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: Sophie Hyde's bracingly sex-positive "Good Luck To You, Leo Grande" is a refreshing exception to typical depictions of female sexuality in mainstream film.

name: Good Luck to You, Leo Grande
review: McCormack is a true discovery, as he delivers a sweet, charming, funny and sexy-as-hell performance that rises to the level of Thompson, who is staggering in her vulnerability here, and still the sexiest she's ever been.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is such a fascinating film that can either be watched with a bowl of popcorn or a notepad and pen and a glass of wine.

name: Official Competition
review: A biting satire... an Oscar-worthy send up of Oscar-worthy films.

name: Official Competition
review: With career-best comic performances, Cruz, Banderas, and Martínez wring laughs from the most subtle looks and gestures.

name: Official Competition
review: If there is one ingredient that gives this film its peculiar appeal, it’s the spectacle of actors playing actors.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is – like the film-within-a-film it focuses on – overwhelmingly an actor’s picture and Cruz, Banderas and Martínez are at ease throughout.

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz, with her cascading curls, hipster eyeglasses and eccentric outfits, has a ball with the highminded, driven Lola as she pushes her actors to increasingly absurd degrees.

name: Official Competition
review: While not on the level of Robert Altman’s The Player, Official Competition is an observant send up of the self-importance of the festival circuit. Cinema buffs may squirm at the derision, but few can deny the accuracy of this caricature.

name: Official Competition
review: It’s comedy with an edge, a more than satisfying ending and a haunting final image.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition features lots of talk about creativity and commerce, art and life, but with its offhand absurdities and low-key critiques of pretension and vanity, it’s also laugh-out-loud funny.

name: Official Competition
review: All in all, Official Competition is a fun and mature look at the film industry, or more specifically, the individuals within it and their motives.

name: Official Competition
review: [A] playful and intelligent film.

name: Official Competition
review: For most of the runtime, the viewer enjoys the weird and idiosyncratic behaviors on display—made all the better because they’re brought to life by three incredible actors.

name: Official Competition
review: I enjoy that Official Competition really sends up that kind of brooding artist persona.

name: Official Competition
review: This movie-making industry satire is witty, intelligent and saved from potentially unbearable navel-gazing by the warmth, talent and sheer charismatic chemistry of Cruz and Banderas.

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz's eye-catching sartorial style is marvellous, and the cast sends up the industry, and themselves, magnificently.

name: Official Competition
review: The directors/screenwriters,  Gastón Duprat and Mariano Cohn, take the challenge to bring to life a deeply intelligent script. "Official Competition" will make you think about your internal demonds, your ego and the (...). [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: Gaston Duprat and Mariano Cohn’s Official Competition may be yet another satire on filmmaking, but it’s the rare iteration that’s nuanced enough to understand that self-awareness does not equal absolution.

name: Official Competition
review: It dismantles the lofty ambitions of cinema as great, important and significant, a monument on the cultural landscape. Instead, it shows us art for ego’s sake, and it has a lot of wickedly spiteful fun doing so.

name: Official Competition
review: This is a marvellous film, witty, eccentric and full of hidden depths. Cruz delivers a lovely turn as the inscrutable, free-spirited Lola, and Antonio Banderas’ Félix is a sublimely subtle comic creation.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is being touted as “biting satire”. But herein lies a problem. None of the characters has been drawn to create any empathy, while the script feels bitty, giving us a series of point-proving pay-offs.

name: Official Competition
review: [Cruz] has rarely been stronger on screen, as an idiosyncratic martinet who nonetheless finds moments of genius and tenderness between her leading men. A blast.

name: Official Competition
review: Joyful, with outstanding performances, but for such a sharp, witty script it’s a shame the momentum fizzles out towards the end.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a wicked satire on the art of fine filmmaking, which allows three great actors to have a hoot — along with the audience.

name: Official Competition
review: An uproarious comedy that’s also deliciously well-performed... this Spanish-language gem cleverly gets away with being both roast session and sneaky celebration at once.

name: Official Competition
review: Mariano Cohn and Gastón Duprat adeptly keep the comedy deadpan and timed with enough precision to prevent the film feeling like a long sketch from a TV variety show.

name: Official Competition
review: The gags and targets are too obvious to generate big laughs, but the darker turns the film takes, together with the changing registers of the performances (what starts as farce veers more towards tragedy) redeem it somewhat.

name: Official Competition
review: You’d watch this dream team share the frame in anything, let alone one of the year’s most riotously funny comedies.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition appears at first to be a standard movie-business takedown à la The Player, but it has far more faith in the art form than that. Among its tastiest pleasures is the chance to see Cruz and Banderas sparking together on screen at last.

name: Official Competition
review: It’s a very funny film, sending-up human absurdities without being too mean. Cruz is a talented comedian, but she smartly plays it straight-ish here.

name: Official Competition
review: By the time the film reaches an unexpected climax, any empathy for their endeavour becomes lost, and Official Competition becomes a flat satire, despite the actors’ best efforts.

name: Official Competition
review: Simply impossible to look away from... As Lola, Cruz is a 'find yourself someone who can do both'-kind of marvel.

name: Official Competition
review: You know how most of the foreign language movies we get in the US are weighty, meaningful dramas? This one isn’t that. This one’s enjoyably silly.

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz, Banderas and Martínez are fantastic in this hysterical satire on the film industry and the battle of egos between artists. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: It remains a fun Spanish comedy but the blunt way it is told means it is not quite a classic filmmaking parody.

name: Official Competition
review: While the film pokes fun at the pretensions of filmmaking, it careful to keep matters grounded; the shenanigans might be heightened for comic purposes but they feel real enough so that when things go to extremes they hit home.

name: Official Competition
review: An absolutely hilarious (and freely silly) tangle of ego and creative chaos, and I'm not just talking about Penelope Cruz's hair.

name: Official Competition
review: It's a particularly European -- or in this case, Argentine-European -- approach to showbiz satire that's resistant to taking sides in debates over the ethics of art and performance, an ambivalence that's as satisfying as it is slippery.

name: Official Competition
review: In between the comic highlights, the script succeeds in planting some surprisingly revealing insights about the vanities and illusions of the theatrical life. It’s a very clever film.

name: Official Competition
review: The mood du jour is lights, camera, crazy in a Spanish masterclass on how not to make a movie.

name: Official Competition
review: Like many satires Official Competition feels like it could only have been made (and maybe fully appreciated) by people who love what is being mocked.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a bit long and could have used some more of the offbeat humor that it excels at. But overall, it’s a worthwhile journey into pulling back the curtain satirically on movie magic.

name: Official Competition
review: A silly but funny film.

name: Official Competition
review: You’ve seen most of these jokes before, but never quite like this.

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz gives a great performance.

name: Official Competition
review: The actors involved are obviously game to poke fun at themselves. It is a bitingly funny journey through the filmmaking process.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a sneaky movie—an elegant, seemingly detached objet d'art that nonetheless delivers some of the biggest laughs I've had all year.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition drags on for a little longer than it should, but this slightly offbeat comedy/drama has some sharp observations about how celebrities can be coddled and exploited in the movie industry.

name: Official Competition
review: A feast for actors about actors.

name: Official Competition
review: The film attacks the three protagonists' clashing egos and lands in a fun, fascinating, and uncomfortable [farce]. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: As the art of filmmaking takes a punch in the face, audiences will love the pummeling and laugh themselves silly.

name: Official Competition
review: Penelope Cruz is a beast as Lola.  From the styling of her character to her off the rails portrayal of holding the audience captive alongside co-stars Antonio Banderas and Oscar Martìnez who are equally brilliant as they collectively blaze the industry

name: Official Competition
review: Boasting some of the funniest sight gags alone, the best of them all may just be Antonio Banderas reacting towards and even instigating the egotistical attitudes that sometimes becomes the story we remember within art.

name: Official Competition
review: A sly, witty and perceptive take on the foibles of actors and filmmakers, with a trio of outstanding performances brilliantly complementing and supporting each other.

name: Official Competition
review: A lacerating — yet, oddly, still loving — satire of how movies are made.

name: Official Competition
review: Penelope Cruz is on fire with this role, showing off her chops spectacularly as a film director whose manipulations come back to bite her, and overall the film is an absurd and farcical trip, the artistic vision of a movie within a movie outside a movie.

name: Official Competition
review: For movie lovers, this hilarious comedy is a Master Class in satire seeing actors and their director put their egos center stage in an outlandish, outrageous exaggeration of the film business.

name: Official Competition
review: You can tell Cruz, Banderas and Martinez are all having a blast in Official Competition completely selling out to the absurdity and willing to be part of the joke. Their willingness to go all-in is quite infectious.

name: Official Competition
review: What’s unexpected about the film is the length to which Cuevas, Félix and Iván manipulate each other -- in cruel, witty and inventive ways.

name: Official Competition
review: Oscillating between a dark comedy and drama, it examines the quirks and eccentricities of its characters as they clash toward one shared goal.

name: Official Competition
review: A clever stab at the entertainment industry, the filmmaking process and some examples of the egocentric players that form it. Includes top-notch performances from Penélope Cruz, Antonio Banderas and Oscar Martinez. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: “Official Competition” is an observant lampoon that will work best for movie buffs.

name: Official Competition
review: A riot. It’s primarily an insider comedy about making a movie, but the strokes are broad enough that anyone can play.

name: Official Competition
review: It’s a tour de force by Cruz with the guys there to support her mission – not that she needs it.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition pulls back the curtain to let us glimpse creation, in all its messiness, at work.

name: Official Competition
review: Sharply written and consistently funny, Official Competition (horrible title, by the way) may be a notch too acerbic for casual moviegoers. But for those of us who read the trades and know an actor or two, it’s catnip.

name: Official Competition
review: Chronicle humans at their worst... with visual wit and from a wry remove.

name: Official Competition
review: Not only one of the best films of the year and one of the best satires I've seen on art, it's also a sharp reflection on the human inability to accept different perspectives when you're sure you're absolutely right. Full review in Spanish.

name: Official Competition
review: Fascinating and subtly hilarious.

name: Official Competition
review: Makes for a delightful satire and is always entertaining.

name: Official Competition
review: This intriguing black comedy from Spain pits Penélope Cruz, Antonio Banderas and Oscar Martínez as a daring director who casts antagonistic actors in her latest film.

name: Official Competition
review: It satirises, with a certain subtlety, the egotism of the actors and the vanity of the entertainment industry, with three more than pleasant central performances by Antonio Banderas, Penélope Cruz and Óscar Martínez. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz, Banderas, and Martinez are having a ball here, relishing the opportunity to take the piss out of the ‘types’ they’re playing. Each of them drolly underplays, and are crackerjack at doing the physical comedy as well as the wordplay.

name: Official Competition
review: This is like comedy for the mind. But whatever you want to call it, it’s intellectually satisfying, in that it presents a skewed but unified vision of reality.

name: Official Competition
review: “Official Competition” might not say anything new or groundbreaking about art imitating life or unorthodox filmmakers, but at least it features three prominent actors at the top of their games.

name: Official Competition
review: A very funny, sometimes thoughtful examination of the ways the tensions of real life can end up informing a film project.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a twisted and oddball satire on moviemaking, ego, and the creative process. The banter is like something out of The Odd Couple, if only The Odd Couple had been written by Edward Albee instead of Neil Simon.

name: Official Competition
review: Its dark humour might be best suited to that rarefied [film] fest-mosphere, but it should still manage to find fans at the multiplex who are looking for something a little meta, a little subtitled and a little rough.

name: Official Competition
review: Cast makes this limp comedy about actors and filmmaking worth while.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition puts ego-driven film stars under the microscope and the result is brilliantly, uncomfortably, and scathingly funny and real.

name: Official Competition
review: There is much to appreciate in the situations, even if the writers (Cohn and Duprat, joined by the latter’s brother, Andrés) aren’t quite as witty as they think they are. In that, they have a lot in common with their characters, at least.

name: Official Competition
review: Penélope Cruz and Antonio Banderas make the most of showbiz types in a satire about making movies.

name: Official Competition
review: I’d call Official Competition’s satire wryly amusing rather than belly-laugh producing, but no complaints from this quarter -- that’s exactly the tone the directors Mariano Cohn and Gastón Duprat are going for, and they pull it off very nicely indeed.

name: Official Competition
review: We get a clash of creative personalities combined with the nuts and bolts telling of how-to-make-a-movie that ring real.

name: Official Competition
review: As much fun as Cruz is clearly having, and that’s a lot, Banderas may be having even more.

name: Official Competition
review: Poking fun at the process of making a prestige film, this Spanish comedy has a consistent bone-dry wit.

name: Official Competition
review: Three incredible performances make this hilariously dark send-up of the film industry entertaining from start to finish, though it might not be every viewer's cup of tea.

name: Official Competition
review: A sly satire of cinema that also manages to be a showcase for the comedic chops of its stars: Penélope Cruz, Antonio Banderas and Oscar Martínez.

name: Official Competition
review: Penélope Cruz underscores that she can just do anything. She is so funny in this.

name: Official Competition
review: Everyone is so, so funny in this. I love this stage of Cruz's career.

name: Official Competition
review: OFFICIAL COMPETITION is definitely my kind of movie. It’s darkly entertaining with incredible acting --- and writing.

name: Official Competition
review: OFFICIAL COMPETITION is rich with many ironies piled on top of one another, but it would be inadequate and a disservice to the clever script to try and explain the intricate scenarios within.

name: Official Competition
review: The Player may have been rotten to the core, but this leaves a little room for humanity and it’s there, as Iván and Félix battle for our sympathies, that it succeeds.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition may not expand your view of filmmaking. But the movie proves entertaining and funny and Cruz and her two compatriots work at levels that fill Official Competition with enjoyment.

name: Official Competition
review: Cohn and Duprat are deliberately, deliciously playing into this discussion of talent vs. fame.... Banderas gives a sly, knowing performance that shows he knows exactly how vainglorious Félix can be

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz slyly pits a pair of egomaniacal actors against each other...in this satirical bonfire of hubris.

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz, Antonio Banderas, and Oscar Martínez continue to prove how versatile they are as actors, shifting from comedy to drama on a dime and making it all work seamlessly.

name: Official Competition
review: The satire hits the bull’s-eye in a film that’s a send-up of arthouse pretensions, and a darn good arthouse film.

name: Official Competition
review: A coy satire that makes welcome use of biting meta-commentary and self-reflexive critique.

name: Official Competition
review: All three actors are clearly having a blast with this satire of actorly egos and vanity projects, but it’s Cruz who truly dazzles.

name: Official Competition
review: Mariano Cohn and Gastón Duprat (who also collaborated on the script) have a sharp eye and brilliant timing, and often manage to wring laughs just from the sight of a character picking up an object, or leaving or entering a room.

name: Official Competition
review: Although it feels repetitive in stretches, the film’s intriguing character dynamics complement the broad yet mostly amusing banter and industry jabs.

name: Official Competition
review: “Official Competition” is nicely balanced, and the poiser-in-chief is Cruz, whose portrayal of Lola goes way beyond simple wackiness.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition does indulge in superficial satire, but Messrs. Duprat and Cohn have devised some plausibly, and hilariously, bizarre scenarios to go with a smart central insight about the nature of film.

name: Official Competition
review: This is really one person’s showcase, and whether by design or simply default, Cruz slips Official Competition into her slim-suited pockets and walks away with the film.

name: Official Competition
review: It may be biting at the hand that feeds it, but these are gentle nibbles at an industry everyone involved clearly loves enough to make fun of.

name: Official Competition
review: While not a film full of twists and turns, there are enough sharp jabs at the industry to leave several bruises while chuckling at how things play out.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a barbed examination of bloated self-esteem that takes a solid joke and runs with it in comically clever and smartly critical ways.

name: Official Competition
review: Strap in for a steady stream of gags, a few visual if you pay close attention, some more predictable than others. The dryness of the humor is so consistent that the film as a whole can be tonally described as droll.

name: Official Competition
review: with more than a few dark twists and a heart that is laughing at both itself and the world that created it, Official Competition is quite a satire, one that finds its heart of darkness hidden in the absurd reality of high-art cinema.

name: Official Competition
review: At the heart of the smart and spiky “Official Competition” is the question of what makes art “good,” as well as the futility of applying such a banal label to something that can be moving, transportive or challenging.

name: Official Competition
review: Bolstered by an incredible cast, the film offers commentary on filmmaking as an art & the lengths the characters will go to outshine each other.

name: Official Competition
review: I haven’t laughed out loud so much in ages.  Whoever chose Penélope Cruz’s explosion of a frizzy, red wig deserves a trophy for that one contribution to this film alone.

name: Official Competition
review: A terrific character study of ego-driven individuals trying to figure out how to play in the same sandbox.

name: Official Competition
review: Despite the underwhelming finale, Official Competition is an entry impossible not to root for. A film full of ambitions and exciting themes that never fails to keep cinephiles invested. It's undoubtedly one of the Tribeca Festival's unique entries.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a decent amount of fun, even if it could have been more of a laugh riot than it winds up being.

name: Official Competition
review: Consistently amusing, if about a reel too long, it’s a tightly controlled, low-boil send-up of the acting process.

name: Official Competition
review: Hilarious and refreshingly simple, giving the cast room to play as they inhabit insufferable people trying to make magic for the camera.

name: Official Competition
review: A bold, provocative and razor-sharp satire. One of the most wickedly funny satires since The Player and What Just Happened.

name: Official Competition
review: The movie doesn't quite reach the dark heights of comedy because at its heart, there's more love than contempt for its protagonists [Banderas, Cruz & Martínez]. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: It doesn’t pull any punches towards the hilarious ribbing on spoiled and entitled actors from different backgrounds while giving each of its three central performers plenty of outstanding material

name: Official Competition
review: A  dizzyingly inventive lampooning of the film industry and the cult of ego.

name: Official Competition
review: Scathingly funny satire of the international art-house scene—think of it as The Square for cineastes, but only if you then immediately poke yourself straight in the ribs for calling something, “The Square for cineastes.”

name: Official Competition
review: The script by Mariano Cohn, Andrés Duprat, and Gastón Duprat is subtly, and sometimes not so subtly, hilarious. It is a knowing look at how films are made, and in some cases unmade, with all the interdependent conflicting personalities.

name: Official Competition
review: In the end, this is a one-joke movie — a shaggy-dog meta-narrative — but it’s not a bad joke.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is a hysterical examination of the ego that really flexes the power of Cruz, Banderas, and Martínez

name: Official Competition
review: The audience to Official Competition could be limited to those who follow the international film festival circuit, but it understands its audience will not tolerate pulled punches. When this film hits, it hits hard.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is an absurd, darkly funny, if incomplete, portrait of ego in the age of buzzword-centric arthouse filmmaking.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is another film about filmmaking, but it escapes hermeticism by homing in on actors and acting.

name: Official Competition
review: Each [gag] goes on and on until it is no longer funny.

name: Official Competition
review: A pitch-perfect joke that, at times, breaks up the vibes with unevenly inspired sketches. However, it never runs totally out of steam.

name: Official Competition
review: ... Explicit, unforgiving, and cruel portrait of a world heatedly marked by appearances, vanity, dreams of glory, and false pride. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: Cohn and Duprat… shoot like apes with machine guns: indiscriminately, without thinking too much (or at all) about the implications of their actions… or even why they are perpetrating them. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review:
The last few minutes become… macabre, grotesque, and melodramatic. 
[Full review in Spanish]

name: Official Competition
review: There’s all this literal and figurative dead space surrounding a tiny cast that has been and can be funnier than “Official Competition” lets them be.

name: Official Competition
review: ... a sharp satire that doesnt feel like an in-joke amongst filmmakers, exploring the underlying commercial aspects that dictate the creative process and the double standards they involve.

name: Official Competition
review: A hilarious and incisive skewering of vanity projects and the egos which propel them into the ground.

name: Official Competition
review: Co-directors Mariano Cohn and Gastón Duprat craft a meta-fictional criticism of art, wealth, and awards.

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition nails the first assignment of comedies: be funny!

name: Official Competition
review: Argentinian directors Gastón Duprat and Mariano Cohn keep the laughs coming, the pace brisk and the tone jocular, resulting in a fluffy but not altogether unserious exploration of the craft of acting.

name: Official Competition
review: One of the best films at this year's TIFF, its meta storytelling lampoons the world it lives in with absurdist comedy and a powerhouse ensemble

name: Official Competition
review: Official Competition is an escapist delight that asks audiences to reflect upon the power of cinema, but also to reflect upon the hard work that goes into each frame.

name: Official Competition
review: Cruz plays their aggressively eccentric director with a perfect blend of oddball, hauteur and deadpan. One of the many joys of this send-up of filmmaking is that, for all the director’s looniness, she is so often right.

name: Official Competition
review: The direction, and particularly the production design from Alain Bainée, are superb, bringing life to what could be a repetitive sequence of sketches. But the main trio's performances are the highlight.

name: Official Competition
review: Banderas and Martínez play their catty thesps dead straight to generally hilarious effect, while Cruz cuts loose as a fiery artiste prone to dancing the floss in moments of stress.

name: Official Competition
review: A mismatched collective of artists and investors make a film for all the wrong reasons in this cheeky, funny, slightly overstretched showbiz comedy.

name: Official Competition
review: Controlled pacing, visual punchlines, and an insider knowledge of the varied pretensions within filmmaking make this a consistently amusing - if never downright hilarious - vehicle for the well-honed comic sides of two of Spain's most famous exports.

name: Official Competition
review: For viewers willing to go with the flow, the film serves up roughly two hours of sharp reflections deliciously wrapped in entertaining antics.

name: Official Competition
review: Wondering just how far this film will go is half the fun, and directors Mariano Cohn and Gastón Duprat choose their moments to push the tone from sharp observational comedy into absurdity...

name: Official Competition
review: Every line delivery is immaculate, and Cruz in particular, with her ginger frizzy locks, proves that she is a comic behemoth who has too long been laid dormant.

name: Official Competition
review: Seeing Cruz and Banderas show off their comedic chops is definitely a pleasure, and the farcical final scenes will leave viewers on a high.

name: Official Competition
review: Offers comic and visual pleasures alike, plus crisp acting from its lead trio...

name: Official Competition
review: The directors offer a light and breezy big-screen hangout, betting that the actors' megawatt charisma will be enough to carry the show. At least for a certain amount of time, the bet pays off.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes presents a poetic, intensely beautiful story so precise that, at times, it feels staged but instead emerges from hours of painstaking care.

name: All That Breathes
review: Threaded through the main narrative we get glimpses of the sectarian tensions that blight modern India and cause additional anxiety. But wisely All That Breathes avoids trying to lean heavily on metaphors or push an agenda.

name: All That Breathes
review: Director Shaumak Sen and cinematographers Ben Bernhard, Rijo Das and Saumyananda Sahi give the audience a visual treat.

name: All That Breathes
review: It soars as high as the birds it depicts, while telling a compassionate story of two Muslim brothers trying to do their part in making the world a better place. It’s astonishing.

name: All That Breathes
review: Just seeing the work that goes into the help being provided for these birds is never less than fascinating.

name: All That Breathes
review: ... another sample that demonstrates that for certain circles, the only way to digest poverty is to dress it up until it becomes unrecognizable. [Full review in Spanish]

name: All That Breathes
review: Simple in its slow, calm storytelling, but profound in the philosophical points it raised about how we are all connected in the vast ecosystem.

name: All That Breathes
review: In an age when we're constantly reminded of all that's bad, All That Breathes celebrates good things it's easy to forget: the wonder of life, the virtues of compassion and the human capacity to make the world better.

name: All That Breathes
review: These birds are utterly other, while their rescuers represent the best of us.

name: All That Breathes
review: Meditative, truthful film-making that deserves to be seen anywhere the human animal coexists with others.

name: All That Breathes
review: Sen’s mesmerising masterpiece is also a worrying look at how pollution and overpopulation are placing an intolerable strain on the balance between humans and nature.

name: All That Breathes
review: "All That Breathes" is a good movie and an Oscar-nominated one; I just quibble with whether it's actually a documentary. Its use of elaborate cinematic techniques suggests it's less fly-on-the-wall than moments played for posterity.

name: All That Breathes
review: Especially telling is an observation on the loneliness of man as a species, b/c we are sentient. The birds, and the nature around them, are keeping each other company and only we stand alone in our modernity, pollution and war. Man to nature perfection.

name: All That Breathes
review: A documentary that argues for Nature within a larger ecosystem, equalizing humanity with the rats, fungi, and scavenger birds. The lack of human ego on display is inspiring.

name: All That Breathes
review: All things that breathe—humans, animals, vegetation, and the land—are all under God’s dominion. It’s all quite stirring and inspiring without being heavy-handed or sanctimonious.

name: All That Breathes
review: Although the film’s tone is sometimes quietly apocalyptic, its director Shaunak Sen manages to capture stirring scenes of beauty in slow-motion cityscapes, just as he finds optimism and hope in the diligence of his fraternal subjects.

name: All That Breathes
review: “All That Breathes” is the kind of immersive documentary experience other filmmakers, and film lovers, would do well to study.

name: All That Breathes
review: The cinematography in this film is amazing (by Ben Bernhard, Riju Das and Saumyananda Sahi). The cameras seem to capture every bit of life in the city, from the smallest spider, to the horses, monkeys, camels, pigs, goats and cows that roam the streets.

name: All That Breathes
review: Shot in a largely observational vérité style, All That Breathes artfully ties together the social and ecological concerns which plague Delhi.

name: All That Breathes
review: A touching documentary that celebrates the very best of humanity, and is an encouraging picture of two men who are working tirelessly to make this world a better place.

name: All That Breathes
review: Although stunning to look at, and in some moments a marvel to even conceive of such images, it is self-consciously so.... Despite this, Sen manages to capture the humbleness of its subjects and turn that into something compelling.

name: All That Breathes
review: If Sen were to better connect Nadeem and Saud's faith and civic identities with the kites and other animals' desperate fight for balance in an urbanized nature, All That Breathes would be an excellent documentary. All the same, it's a very good one.

name: All That Breathes
review: Without hagiography or sunny optimism, the emphasis on decay serves to emphasize the systemic adversary.

name: All That Breathes
review: ayering urban ecology, spiritual philosophy, politics and distilled character study, All That Breathes is a remarkable, vital work of cinema.

name: All That Breathes
review: A thoughtful, meditative thesis on humanity’s relationship with nature, filmed with the kind of cinematographic beauty most fiction filmmakers can only aspire towards.

name: All That Breathes
review: It is a powerful film both in subject matter and visuals. It is a film that, in the macro, asks us to consider why we differentiate or make a hierarchy of all inhabitants of this planet that breathe.

name: All That Breathes
review: [A] strangely uplifting film, which is more of a meditation on the interconnectedness of life than an assemblage of facts.

name: All That Breathes
review: "All That Breathes" is profoundly empathetic toward all living kind, compelling a radical reassessment of the boundaries many imagine exist between nature and civilization, along with the boundaries we insist on building between ourselves.

name: All That Breathes
review: Stunningly photographed, both from afar and in gorgeous close-up, "All That Breathes" offers a profile of three dedicated men doing what they can to preserve a small slice of nature, to the benefit of us all.

name: All That Breathes
review: Beautiful cinematography and lyrical score.

name: All That Breathes
review: "...magical and deeply upsetting..."

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes is certainly beautiful aesthetically, but its gentleness towards the audience makes it even more beautiful.

name: All That Breathes
review: It occasionally strains. But the basic conflict at play, between the selflessness of these medics, the growing need for their work, and the utter folly of this mission gives it all an urgent undercurrent.

name: All That Breathes
review: Maybe the most beautifully realized documentary in recent memory.

name: All That Breathes
review: It is gratifying to see advances made even as the situation for these birds is worsening. All That Breathes lovingly shows that the brothers may be saving the kites, but that the kites are, more importantly, saving the brothers.

name: All That Breathes
review: “All that Breathes” is definitely informative and succeeds more than it fails, but it could have been so much more.

name: All That Breathes
review: There have been other stories about the amateur medic duo,, but none as lyrical as this documentary.

name: All That Breathes
review: Human and avian subjects share the spotlight in this stylish ecological documentary that’s both insightful and inspiring.

name: All That Breathes
review: One of the most moving and visually striking works of cinema this year

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes blends a verité-style character study with gorgeous nature cinematography while never losing the film’s overall commentary on how man interacts with nature—or merely chooses to destroy it through inaction.

name: All That Breathes
review: ALL THAT BREATHES is a nature documentary that finds beauty within the debris of New Delhi, India, as two brothers rescue injured black kites and ponder the interconnectedness of existence.

name: All That Breathes
review: A subtle, haunting reflection on the meaning of humanity — on the breathtaking kindness and heartbreaking cruelty that define our wounded, intrepid, predatory species.

name: All That Breathes
review: While the brothers speak for themselves and the kites, [Sen] and his cinematographers capture the wild juxtaposition of nature and industry [with] amazing visuals courtesy of multiple slow pans devoid of artifice or intrusion.

name: All That Breathes
review: The film’s photography is skilful, but it might have tipped the whole thing into pretentiousness if the story’s human element had not been so engaging.

name: All That Breathes
review: [A] handsomely photographed and pensive documentary.

name: All That Breathes
review: All that Breathes is a stunningly beautiful film with lead camerawork by the acclaimed documentary cinematographer Benjamin Bernhard. A well-calibrated score accompanies the subtle and atmospheric sound design.

name: All That Breathes
review: A running time of 1 hour and 31 minutes, it's an eye-opening, inspirational and powerful exposé with images that speak louder than words.

name: All That Breathes
review: This oneiric, rapturous documentary eschews conventional reportage techniques, arguably to its detriment at times.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes offers an intriguing, thoughtful look at the ideological and environmental problems tearing the city apart.

name: All That Breathes
review: With the perceptive eye of a skilled documentary filmmaker behind the camera, “All That Breathes” is a moving celebration of the brothers’ selfless sacrifice.

name: All That Breathes
review: A complex, thoughtful, quietly beautiful film about the ecosystem and human community.

name: All That Breathes
review: From exquisite cinematography and craftsmanship of the lens, All That Breathes captures the noble effort to save the Black Kites.

name: All That Breathes
review: Shaunak Sen’s documentary is both otherworldly and humanizing, as if it were bridging a gap between different forms of existence.

name: All That Breathes
review: With immersive cinematography, All That Breathes offers contemplative moments that tell more than just a documentary story about rescuing birds. Viewers can look at the bigger picture of how people's decisions on what to save can affect our ecosystem.

name: All That Breathes
review: Sen takes the chaotic world on its own terms, and quietly uncovers a rich metaphor in the bird's tenacity: somehow, even in this place, life can thrive.

name: All That Breathes
review: Even the smallest and least likely of creatures — rats, snails, insects — are given the cinematic treatment.

name: All That Breathes
review: Shaunak Sen’s terrific documentary was as much of a celebration.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes is a portrait of incredible grace amidst an overwhelming tragedy.

name: All That Breathes
review: Shaunak Sen's All That Breathes is a film as gorgeous as it is ambitious, as stirring as it is terrifying.

name: All That Breathes
review: The melancholy here never feels at odds with the open earnestness of their commitment to their work offering a welcome counterpoint to more prosaic explorations of the changing world from more mainstream entries at Sundance.

name: All That Breathes
review: Its a film with an intimate scope thats about so much more than it first appears to be. You might not know much about black kite birds going into All That Breathes, but youll leave this documentary caring deeply about them.

name: All That Breathes
review: The opening shot is just so beautiful and unforgettable.

name: All That Breathes
review: Delhi’s rapidly worsening air quality and religious violence form the backdrop for All that Breathes, Shaunak Sen’s lyrical portrait of two men who work to save injured and sick birds in the city.

name: All That Breathes
review: As the future heads into uncertain territory, All That Breathes spells out a plea for balance. In this life, everything  all that breathes  is connected: under the skies, through the air, and the Earth upon which we live.

name: All That Breathes
review: Sen could easily just have made an observational documentary about the brothers' day-to-day work or simply focused on the kites themselves but he stretches its wings much further than that.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes is an insightful watch because it recognizes that small steps are still progress.

name: All That Breathes
review: Its one of the most powerful cinematic approaches to the climate crisis yet made.

name: All That Breathes
review: Sen’s All That Breathes documents the all-consuming vocation of brothers Nadeem Shehzad and Mohammad Saud.

name: All That Breathes
review: A soaring visual masterpiece...

name: All That Breathes
review: Although not the flashiest movie by any means, the film does develop a quiet power as it negotiates both its scenes of environmental concerns and the evolving relationship between the two brothers.

name: All That Breathes
review: Humanity comes in its most selfless in All That Breathes, [which adopts] the interconnectedness of nature and mankind as a guiding principle.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes suggests a tentative hope for the future while still recognizing that our current situation is tragically untenable.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathes is not a film that is easily forgotten. Its quiet grace and profound world view will linger long after it's over.

name: All That Breathes
review: What All That Breathes is really about is the hunt for dignity of life in modern India -- an urgent examination of what it means to be a citizen of a country reeling from its own xenophobic toxicity.

name: All That Breathes
review: There is so much life in All That Breathes that you won't be left clamoring for more personality.

name: All That Breathes
review: In an inspired touch, Sen keeps returning to eye-level shots of the wildlife that wanders, surviving and unseen, through Delhi and he reminds us that humans are just one small part of an ecosystem we seem hellbent on poisoning.

name: All That Breathes
review: With a tone more melancholic and charming than one might expect given the various crises at play here, Sen's deceptively casual observational documentary prefers dwelling on resistance and resilience to pronouncements of doom.

name: All That Breathes
review: [A] tiny marvel of a documentary...

name: All That Breathes
review: Saud, Nadeem and Salik are engaging and inspirational individuals. Shaunak Sen's film does justice to their efforts but also allows us to see the bigger picture of a highly connected, complex world...

name: All That Breathes
review: As both a touching testament to brotherhood and a multi-faceted look at the challenges facing modern India, All That Breathes is by turns poetic and unsettling.

name: All That Breathes
review: All That Breathesis a powerful documentary with a message that needs to be felt down deep in the lungs.

name: All That Breathes
review: A masterful tale of how pollution has invaded the air and the human soul.

name: Navalny
review: [Navalny] tries to figure out who exactly was involved, leading to one of the most harrowing and thrilling sting operation calls ever recorded on camera. It's also very funny, only if to see the sheer incompetence of those that tried to kill him.

name: Navalny
review: Part political portrait, part espionage thriller - containing perhaps the most jaw-dropping phone call in the history of cinema.

name: Navalny
review: This is not only a moving portrait of a brave opposition leader, but an inside look at the work of effective investigative journalists.

name: Navalny
review: It's the sort of explosive overview that can change minds in a perfect world and the perfect litmus test for exposing sycophants who readily agree with Putin that it's all just an embarrassing cry for attention.

name: Navalny
review: At once disheartening and inspiring, Navalny is thus a bracing reflection of Russian society and the fraught state of modern democracy at large.

name: Navalny
review: He isn’t flawless, and the film is damning of his realpolitik approach to coalition-building with some scummy far-right politicians, but he’s an inspiring figure for his sheer fearlessness in the face of tryanny.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny warns that the only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good people to do nothing.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is nothing if not efficient in its dramatics.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny knows the power of a compelling narrative and delivers a call to arms...

name: Navalny
review: The fact that it involves one of the most brazen incidents of state sponsored assassination in memory means this is a unique document of a very singular man.

name: Navalny
review: Even when Navalny goes big, there are still moments of levity.

name: Navalny
review: This never-before-seen footage impressed and amazed us because it's something completely unfathomable.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny succeeded in waking up the Russian people and the world regarding Putin and for that, he will go down in history as a revolutionary game-changer, not unlike the way we view our own Founding Fathers. He can and should hold his head forever high.

name: Navalny
review: A suspenseful and inspiring tribute to a Russian freedom fighter.

name: Navalny
review: ... Beyond its welcomed denouncing spirit and the possibility of getting to know Putin's biggest opponent, it doesn't quite delve into darker, more disquieting territories. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Navalny
review: A must-see in our political moment.

name: Navalny
review: ...a rare peek behind a new iron curtain that may be rapidly drawing shut.

name: Navalny
review: Astonishing and downright chilling, Navalny plays out like a tightly wound political thriller with tragic results.

name: Navalny
review: it's a top-of-the-line thriller, complete with an astonishing central sequence that is jaw-dropping in its audacity and profound in its impact on the world. I suspect that this is exactly the film Alexei Navalny wanted.

name: Navalny
review: The movie is mainly a fleet-footed true-life investigative spy thriller on the botched murder operation.

name: Navalny
review: “Navalny” is a doc that exposes a shocking series of events, all of which are too mindblowing to reveal

name: Navalny
review: Daniel Roher’s documentary Navalny is an entertaining and thrilling film about the Russian politician who challenged Putin and paid the price.

name: Navalny
review: I left feeling hollow and angry. Like I’d been manipulated using methods pioneered and perfected under the long-gone Soviet regime of my childhood.

name: Navalny
review: It is after all a political whodunnit nestled within a campaign movie about human rights, which may not sound exciting, but it is.

name: Navalny
review: With talking heads ranging from investigative reporters and Navalny’s family, this was the inside story of a poisoning plot exposed and a chilling look into the moral abyss that is Putin.

name: Navalny
review: Granted fly-on-the-wall access, the film has a jaw-dropping sequence in which Alexey Navalny prank-calls his own attackers...

name: Navalny
review: An emotional rollercoaster of a film...

name: Navalny
review: The laughs kick in early. Navalny does not suffer from false modesty, but he is also smart enough to mock his own swagger... Even the hardships are edged with unlikely amusement.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny’s resistance cell has a small, charmingly ad hoc air about it. But the film brilliantly captures the innate foolishness of his opponents, too -- the absurdity as well as the darkness.

name: Navalny
review: The film was made entirely before the invasion and hasn’t been updated to acknowledge it, but viewed at the present point, it serves not only as an international political thriller but as a kind of elegy to the era of Russian history that has just ended,

name: Navalny
review: Roher has assembled a tense and absorbing look at Navalny and his inner circle.

name: Navalny
review: Central to the documentarys structure, and the way it reveals all the facts about Navalny, is the search for the poisoners and the fascinating spycraft surrounding that quest.

name: Navalny
review: A real-life thriller set against the backdrop of the disinformation wars, Navalny is a lively patchwork of archival and original material, profiling Russias most famous dissident.

name: Navalny
review: It is more chilling and absorbing than any spy fiction, because it’s all real, and ominous, too.

name: Navalny
review: This superb documentary demonstrates, even more dramatically than The Death of Stalin or Chernobyl, how dim Russia’s evil rulers are.

name: Navalny
review: Roher deserves more credit than just being in the right place at the right time ... He assembles Navalny well and draws out figure's charisma in interviews that highlight his leadership skills.

name: Navalny
review: The attitude of Mr. Navalny and his colleagues is fearless, in a country governed by fear. Thrillers are rarely so inspiring.

name: Navalny
review: It offers intimate, sometimes amazing access to the bravery, and human cost, of opposing a despot.

name: Navalny
review: One of those rare documentaries that is vitally important as well as entertaining.

name: Navalny
review: Riveting cinema, a roller coaster of emotions

name: Navalny
review: Navalny successfully doubles as an espionage procedural and a portrait of one man’s war against an authoritarian regime. It balances a magazine-style profile and a probing independent inquiry into a brutal state-sanctioned assassination attempt.

name: Navalny
review: A remarkable, first-hand insight into how a modern-day police state operates, and how any kind of meaningful opposition can exist — as terrifying as it is hopeful.

name: Navalny
review: We... get a sense of Navalny’s personality (confident, energetic, dry-humoured) and his family life, and we see his wily efforts to identify his poisoners.

name: Navalny
review: Spectacularly entertaining. As gripping, as suspenseful as a finely wrought fictional thriller; a sheer delight as a portrait of the man himself. Films dont get much more daring or crucial than this.

name: Navalny
review: The other reason to go see Navalny in a theater, if you can, is for its sheer entertainment value, to be properly immersed in the suspenseful story Roher is telling -- recent history and scarcely believable if this were a Jason Bourne sequel.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is so taut and suspenseful you’d think John le Carré had left behind a secret manuscript that’s only just coming to light now.

name: Navalny
review: This chilling and revealing documentary is a must-see piece of filmmaking and with Putins invasion of Ukraine on our minds every day, Navalnys story has an even more powerful impact.

name: Navalny
review: Whats really good about this documentary is that it doesnt sugarcoat who Navalny is and his past, including excerpts of him talking at far right rallies.

name: Navalny
review: This is undoubtedly one of the most thrilling documentaries to be released this, or any, year.

name: Navalny
review: [Blends] biography, activism and a particularly gripping procedural element...

name: Navalny
review: Navalny already seems like a warning from history three months ago. It’s terrifying that it has already become even more relevant.

name: Navalny
review: As entertaining as Navalny is, its an urgent reminder that he, and the brighter future he represents for a Russia that is on an increasingly frightening path, not be forgotten.

name: Navalny
review: Daniel Roher’s compelling documentary Navalny intimately reveals the consequences of challenging Vladimir Putin’s autocratic Russia.

name: Navalny
review: A documentary that moves with the swiftness and tension of a crackerjack thriller.

name: Navalny
review: Daniel Roher’s documentary Navalny is truly a film for our times. It’s a great way to get yourself up to speed on this case if you weren’t paying attention in 2020, as it provides a nice summary of the events of Navalny’s ordeal and world reaction to it.

name: Navalny
review: Despite some serious qualms, theres value to the film... For uninformed viewers, even a CliffsNotes version of recent history is better than nothing, and if the film brings increased attention to Navalnys plight, all the better.

name: Navalny
review: For so many reasons, Navalny’s story concerns us all.

name: Navalny
review: Although the story of Russian political activist Alexei Navalny has been widely reported in the news, the documentary Navalny is a wild and intriguing look at what went on behind the scenes when he tried to find out who poisoned him in 2020.

name: Navalny
review: It’s a genuinely exciting piece of storytelling, a propulsive real-life quest for truth driven by ingenious tech-geeks and the disarming force of Navalny’s personality.

name: Navalny
review: An astonishing account...

name: Navalny
review: A fascinating documentary about the now-imprisoned Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny...

name: Navalny
review: A brave film about a brave man, made with the urgent purpose of one of Navalny’s YouTube exposés and a vivid sense of what cinema can still achieve.

name: Navalny
review: An exciting and urgent documentary by Daniel Roher... This cinematic portrait of the bravest man on earth will burnish Navalny’s profile and slightly increase the pressure on Putin to let Navalny go free, or at least to let him live.

name: Navalny
review: The film ends with Roher asking Navalny, months ago, in the emptied-out barroom setting of most of their exchanges, What do you think about the wars in Syria and Ukraine? His answer is genial, blunt, startling. Navalnys words are a big, fat f-you.

name: Navalny
review: Real-life intrigue  including Navalnys Russian return after being poisoned  is  more outrageous than any fiction, because his status as martyr is the lubricant that could loosen the iron grid that Putin has on his country and the rest of the world.

name: Navalny
review: While Navalnys story continues, he will continue to live in infamy as Rohers timely film will have his fearlessness and fight embedded in history forever.

name: Navalny
