review: Navalny is a riveting and powerful documentary about the political and social battles worth fighting for...A must-see documentary.

name: Navalny
review: Rohers film is at turns enlightening and emotional...it is also alarming and downright hilarious.

name: Navalny
review: With CNNs resources Roher has created a documentary that is both an active record and testament to democracy.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is a sketch of a brilliant, exuberant politician and a spycraft thriller, with a tragic ending. Who could ask for more absorbing TV?

name: Navalny
review: What comes through most clearly in Daniel Roher's semi-hagiographic documentary about... Alexei Navalny are the particular traits one must possess in order to challenge a power-mad despot like Vladimir Putin.

name: Navalny
review: When this was all happening it made no sense why Alexei Navalny would risk everything to return to Russia. What this film does is present why, in his mind, he had no choice but to return, no matter what the consequences are.

name: Navalny
review: The sequence in which he essentially prank-calls one suspect and tricks him into revealing pretty much everything may well be one of the most astonishing and spellbinding things that you will see in a film this year.

name: Navalny
review: Roher turns the film into a cerebral John le Carre-like thriller...

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is a masterclass in documentary storytelling, Emotional and distrurbing in equal measure, this is one of the most jarring, hard to believe stories ever seen on film.

name: Navalny
review: A shocking recounting of Russian reform leader and Vladimir Putin opponent Alexei Navalnys poisoning.

name: Navalny
review: "Navalny" paints a portrait that takes you beyond the headlines and showcases an impassioned, courageous, and principled man brave enough to stand up to Russia's authoritarian leader, Vladimir Putin  and who nearly died because of it.

name: Navalny
review: They don't make espionage pictures like they used to. Then again, here's Navalny, which could easily pass for a Costa-Gavras political thriller or the next Bourne chapter.

name: Navalny
review: It is potentially a landscape-altering piece of work that transcends film festival fame and stands as a stirring nutshell of humanitarian history.

name: Navalny
review: Watching Navalny, you feel like you are witnessing history. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Navalny
review: Roher is profoundly lucky to have been around when Navalny's harrowing story needed to be told, and so are we.

name: Navalny
review: Even with a foregone conclusion, Roher's movie has the feel of a gripping political thriller. Credit the drum-tight editing by Langdon Page and Maya Daisy Hawke, and the intriguing cast of characters.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is a riveting examination of a seemingly fearless public figure.

name: Navalny
review: A pointed and unnerving must see biopic documentary of the 45-year-old Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny in the aftermath of being poisoned.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny has the flow and tension of a thriller, and it has a central figure whose refusal to bend remains uncompromised even behind bars.

name: Navalny
review: There is something brutally honest about "Navalny" as a high-wire act. The film strikes a singular balance between fearlessness and hopelessness, forcing us to reckon with why he put himself in that position, to not only grieve when he falls.

name: Navalny
review: Offers hope for a brighter, freer future in Russia amid the ongoing shock of state cruelty.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is fearless, charismatic and an agent of history. Roher's timely doc puts us right there with him.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny is a bracing document of the assassination attempt on Navalny's life, as well as his victorious post-recovery effort to unmask those behind it.

name: Navalny
review: It's a swift, inspiring, propulsive film with a dashing and intelligent central figure enacting a drama that he can't possibly win, except for a freak of luck or in the eventual annals of history.

name: Navalny
review: If Tom Clancy or John le Carré fabricated the events depicted in Daniel Roher's documentary Navalny, you'd think it was too on-the-nose.

name: Navalny
review: A must-watch documentary...

name: Navalny
review: Thrilling, intelligent, insightful, and even moving at times, Roher has made the absolute most of his astonishing access to deliver a compelling and crucial documentation of this period of history.

name: Navalny
review: Navalny may not resonate with the same power as something like The Great Dictator, but -- in its timely 21st century context - this documentary evinces a similar understanding of what power fears the most.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi deftly juggles his stories, merging them together in the devastating final minutes of “No Bears.”

name: No Bears
review: Th film demonstrates the way that neorealism can be used to express freedom under even the harshest repression.

name: No Bears
review: The only happy ending here is that Panahi, against the odds, has made another film, and hopefully will be able to keep making them.

name: No Bears
review: Witty and despairing in equal measure, “No Bears” is a fascinating cinematic layer cake of themes, sorrows, and banked fury.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears has many shades and moods, from delightful rural comedy to the most serious kind of social concern. And it has the kind of open ending, somehow very stirring, that qualifies as another hallmark of classical Iranian cinema.

name: No Bears
review: As a character, Panahi is mostly silent; he has little desire to explain himself. No Bears might have benefited from the light touch of 2006’s Offside, although the reasons behind the film’s heavier tone are understandable.

name: No Bears
review: There is a sense of urgency that underlines the film, as though Panahi – and the audience – are on borrowed time.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi is a phenomenal talent, and I don’t use that word loosely. He is endless inventive with breadth and depth. He makes films that engage the intellect and the emotions, those rare gifts that the more I think about them, the more the layers peel back.

name: No Bears
review: In No Bears, as with This Is Not a Film and Taxi before it, Panahi autobiographically prods the very meaning of cinematic intervention and political filmmaking.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears is primarily a comedy. Yet the bureaucracy, suspicion, and paranoia underlining everything here contextualizes it in the bleak everyday realities of an oppressive society.

name: No Bears
review: The story keeps adding more twists and more layers in this movie-within-a-movie-within-a-movie. It is almost like standing between two mirrors and seeing multiple reflections of yourself.

name: No Bears
review: A remarkable achievement in modern cinema, No Bears puts forth a voice and message that is loud, clear and undeniable.

name: No Bears
review: A master class in house-arrest filmmaking from Jafar Panahi.

name: No Bears
review: This film is terrific. What I really appreciate about Panahi... Is that he characterizes himself as something of an accidental disruptor, a curmudgeon.

name: No Bears
review: “This Is Not a Film,” “Closed Curtain,” “Taxi” and “3 Faces” have all been brilliant, but “No Bears” transcends them as both outlawed artistry and a moral interrogation of that art itself.

name: No Bears
review: The folly of unfounded traditions

name: No Bears
review: The oppression that Panahi and his characters endure are, thus, not much more than arbitrary fairy tales: "Things are this way because we say so." Panahi is a warrior, continuing to fight against this authoritarian way of thinking.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi has made a complex, thought-provoking film that raises questions about a filmmaker’s responsibilities and makes you wonder about a society that would put such a gifted artist in jail.

name: No Bears
review: It's a scathing commentary on political and familial oppression packaged as a dual romance on an unavoidable fast-track towards tragedy.

name: No Bears
review: Despite the film's relative simplicity of narrative, it becomes a deep and considered act of self-reflection...

name: No Bears
review: Perhaps what is most remarkable about “No Bears” is how, despite all this heavy-duty baggage, it nevertheless averts despair. The reason for this, I think, is because the director Panahi equates filmmaking, no matter the risks, with freedom.

name: No Bears
review: Part faux documentary, part film-within-a-film, Panahi’s latest follows a series of seemingly incidental events that coalesce into a subtle and unexpectedly devastating investigation of a director trying to create art under oppression.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi has made, paradoxically, a great movie about a medium that often falls short of greatness. You long to see him free, not least so he can make another.

name: No Bears
review: 'No Bears' is a multi-layered film filled with allegory, humour, and a humanistic outlook... All of Panahi’s work is deliberately political. 'No Bears' remind us that art is political and that in Panahi’s case, it is a necessity.

name: No Bears
review: Provocative, engrossing and captivating.

name: No Bears
review: A fascinating, multi-layered fable in which the storytelling techniques of film butt up against the realities of the world.

name: No Bears
review: There’s no way to watch this film without feeling mournful, or fearing for the man who made it.

name: No Bears
review: An effective, personalized allegory for the role of cinema within the Iranian theocratic, authoritarian regime and an incisive, yet humanistic indictment of oppression, from a traditional village on up.

name: No Bears
review: ... a journey of self-discovery with a powerful ending that reinforces the acclaimed filmmaker’s refusal to be silenced.

name: No Bears
review: Iranian Jafar Panahi's No Bears brings to light the suppression of artists in his homeland, who, like him, carry on - a stoic figure shooting, observing, and directing his feature remotely as tensions rise in brutal government suppression and mob rule.

name: No Bears
review: [Panahi's] work has not astonished like this in some time.

name: No Bears
review: Jafar Panahi’s ability to still clearly identify who the real culprits are is an inspiring testament to his clear-mindedness and his unshaken ability to imagine a better, more just world.

name: No Bears
review: You leave feeling like you’ve just seen a truly extraordinary late work produced by one of the era’s greatest working auteurs, quickly followed by the sense of experiencing a sucker punch.

name: No Bears
review: If watching a Jafar Panahi film is something of a political act, then it is also a soul-nourishing one.

name: No Bears
review: Hopefully No Bears is not the final piece of artfully crafted “propaganda” the director is able to make, nor any socially conscious filmmaker currently experiencing suppression in Iran.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi, whose courage and honesty are beyond doubt, has made a movie that calls those very qualities into question, a movie about its own ethical limits and aesthetic contradictions.

name: No Bears
review: Fantastic. The story’s twists and turns are never too much or too little. Panahi’s movie-within-a-movie is about two lovers trying to cross a border so they don’t have to live their lives in secret. It might not be vérité, but it feels authentic.

name: No Bears
review: Disarming in both his methods and gentle screen presence, Panahi proves a ruthless killer when it comes to delivering dramatic blows.

name: No Bears
review: Jafar Panahi’s latest in his series of dissident films is a model of courage and creative invention.

name: No Bears
review: Moving, satirical, and frightening in equal measure, No Bears, the latest from currently imprisoned Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi, is one of the finest and most narratively elaborate films of the year.

name: No Bears
review: It's a fierce critique of small-town traditionalism and religious dogma. But while this is an angry and ultimately devastating movie, it's also a surprisingly playful and inventive one.

name: No Bears
review: Self-reflexivity has become a key fixture of [Panahi's] work, and by turning the camera on himself, he exposes surprising vulnerabilities. There is courage in centering himself as the object of his dissident gaze, as well as an element of self-criticism.

name: No Bears
review: A testament to the power of film to challenge a culture of blind obedience, and also to Panahi’s efforts, as a dissident filmmaker, to build a cinema of defiance against the propagandist film apparatus of the state.

name: No Bears
review: Mina Kavani as Zara steals the show every time she appears on screen, with her sorrowful anger being excellently portrayed and her monologue one of the best parts of the movie.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears has a novelistically detailed eye for the complexities of individual lives under a chillingly cruel regime, but it also finds romance and humanity in the fissures of its painful story.

name: No Bears
review: In this startling work, [Jafar Panahi] places the responsibility on ordinary Iranians to act, even if it leads to heartbreak. Because, as with his latest deceptively sharp-edged meta drama, he knows that not every story can have a happy ending.

name: No Bears
review: Fact and fiction, truth and lies swirl about each other in Jafar Panahi’s latest. The film -- in which Panahi plays a version of himself -- also deals with the age-old conundrum of whether to stay or go.

name: No Bears
review: Filmed in Panahi’s realist style, which included telling conversations that reveal the cant behind the can-and-cannot dos imposed on free thinkers, No Bears morphs from an amusing satire into a blazing critique of censorship.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi goes at his subjects with an irrepressible cinematic verve that extends from the story and the dialogue to the performances and the very presences of the actors.

name: No Bears
review: The director’s bravery and ingenuity -- by continuing to create new work, advocate for himself, and also entertain us -- remains an utterly inspiring thing.

name: No Bears
review: Given Panahi’s own real-life suffering and repression, it is a testament to his integrity as an artist that he looks so critically at himself and so empathetically at those who are indifferent to, or might even support, his imprisonment.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi questions his own cinema and, by extension, that of other creators who seek "social justice" with their images. Their intentions may be good, but they are exempt from the consequences of their search.

name: No Bears
review: An important film that substantiates its story by juxtaposing it with what the director is currently experiencing.

name: No Bears
review: A challenging film, made by a surprisingly self-aware filmmaker, who is using his art to talk about himself, about his country, and about the borders that divide us (and have taken away a lot of his freedom for several years). Full review in Spanish.

name: No Bears
review: I admire Panahi as a brave man and a great filmmaker.

name: No Bears
review: With warmth and precision, No Bear uses its parallel stories to denounce that fear is a threat hung over societies... [Full review in Spanish]

name: No Bears
review: No Bears is, without a doubt, a challenging film, but it also holds big rewards for fans of the auteur’s work.

name: No Bears
review: It’s an enticing premise that No Bears mostly lives up to ... balancing legitimate thriller set pieces with the restrained self-interrogation that’s defined Panahi’s recent, more confined work in order to ask provocative questions.

name: No Bears
review: Just the kind of film that makes the long, sleepless travel to reach a far-away film festival worth every minute of its time.

name: No Bears
review: It isn’t the most thrilling film, but it’s fascinating as a picture of Iran and a portrait of Panahi.

name: No Bears
review: This hugely involving film uses wry humour to capture cultural absurdities that have an impact on two love stories, while further complicating the process of making movies.

name: No Bears
review: A piercingly self-aware portrait of an artist who is not afraid to depict himself and his craft as aloof or insular.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi's subdued filmmaking will appeal to an audience that enjoys the director's modus operandi.

name: No Bears
review: Far from an exercise in indulgent meta navel-gazing, No Bears is a compelling, emotional and humane study of fear, perseverance and resisting oppression through witness.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi’s ninth feature, which premiered at Venice in the weeks after its maker’s incarceration, is a thrilling testament to the maxim that necessity is the mother of invention.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears is another subtly momentous entry in the curious and humbly optimistic filmography of one of our greatest working directors.

name: No Bears
review: A dark postmodern satire about the unexpected film that emerges within a film about making a film.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears is an incredibly poignant and brave statement on both Panahi’s own situation and that of his country, Iran. No Bears has so many layers and says so much.

name: No Bears
review: In spite of travel bans, house arrests and actual imprisonment... Jafar Panahi has managed to create a body of work that movingly describes life in a censorious theocracy. Banned in Iran, No Bears is a subtle and tricky drama within a drama.

name: No Bears
review: Through clever subterfuge, Panahi has continued to direct new movies during his ban, of course--good ones, perhaps none so good as his latest...

name: No Bears
review: As intense a situation as one could imagine, especially knowing that in this instance, Panahi was not able to continue on like the Duke boys of Near Eastern cinema and elude the totalitarian forces tangling him in their grasp.

name: No Bears
review: ... Its very existence is an act of defiance, a metafictional portrait of a dissident artist still at work. It also has a flavour all its own: a complex layer cake of guilt and suspicion, where even a great shot by a master director is a suspect device.

name: No Bears
review: With his latest film, Jafar Panahi suggests that cinema might be a great art worth fighting for, but it may not be able to save anyone.

name: No Bears
review: With the exception of the mournful Closed Curtain, No Bears is the gravest of Panahi’s post-arrest work. His usual puckish spirit is channelled here into a structure incorporating fragmented points of view.

name: No Bears
review: It’s deceptively simple: the more you think about it, the more layers there seem to be and the more you realise how much this film has to say about lives made small by restrictions that can, and do, result in tragedy.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi covered similar ground in This Is Not a Film, Taxi and 3 Faces, but No Bears has an urgency all of its own.

name: No Bears
review: Like Panahi’s recent films This Is Not a Film and Taxi Tehran, this is powerful because of its control, subtlety and diplomatic finesse.

name: No Bears
review: The film’s quiet anger and poignancy is even more acute in the wake of Panahi’s recent imprisonment.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears is one of his most ambitious works yet and while it tackles a number of serious issues, there’s always room for his wry humour.

name: No Bears
review: “No Bears” is one of the year’s best films from one of the most vital filmmakers in the world.

name: No Bears
review: NO BEARS (2022) Review - Balancing a wry sense of humour with the tragic realities of contrasting elements of Iranian life, Panahi has crafted an honest and introspective work that underscores what he stands for as an artist.

name: No Bears
review: Pictures here bear witness, act as testimony not only in capturing it but simply in existing; in the conscious reflexivity of No Bears’ own existence...

name: No Bears
review: If Panahi’s dissident films have to date been journeys of discovery about the subversively liberating, life-affirming power of cinema, “No Bears” is where he slams on the brakes.

name: No Bears
review: With No Bears, Panahi reaches the point of self-reckoning, questioning the social validity of his work and confronting the limitations of art.

name: No Bears
review: The master has left the building, albeit only for a moment. And like any master worth following, he has left behind his most challenging work for us to reckon with in his wake.

name: No Bears
review: The politics and participants’ backgrounds aren’t spelled out for non-local viewers, and many of the nuances absolutely went over my head. More power to Panahi for that; insisting that cultural specificity be insisted on its own terms is a good...

name: No Bears
review: No Bears generally spends less time finding aesthetic articulations of its themes than it does building out an increasingly convoluted plot to support them.

name: No Bears
review: Panahi has not stopped fighting, using cinema as a language to reproduce and further compromise reality, calling the viewing world into account. [Full review in Spanish]

name: No Bears
review: Per usual with Panahi, it takes some time to orient oneself in the happenings of No Bears, arguably one of the director's more complex endeavors.

name: No Bears
review: Even a filmmaker, hounded and deprived, can make startlingly incisive art. Even a political prisoner cut off from it all can make his voice heard all around the world.

name: No Bears
review: The humane light that Panahi strives to use on even his most oppressive characters belies a sharp awareness of the power lines and misinformation that color an atmosphere where no one is easy around telling the truth.

name: No Bears
review: No Bears observes people toiling away at existing while Panahi wrestles with the existential, this juxtaposition providing the cleverly timed comic relief that aids his witty social commentary.

name: No Bears
review: A complex work of novelistic density, this is among the boldest and most accomplished statements from one of the world’s exemplary filmmakers...

name: No Bears
review: Deceptively simple at first, and then accumulating increasingly complex layers by almost imperceptible degrees, No Bears deals with borders both physical and spiritual...

name: Descendant
review: The result is a powerful account of a living history. That which happened doesn't just end because time passes. The consequences and pain reverberate through generations.

name: Descendant
review: [Brown] finds a remarkable network of shared oral history, passed on from one generation to the next, despite repeated warnings to not tell their story.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is one of the most powerful documentaries this year & yet one of the most important to make sure to never forget. The amount of raw footage, storytelling and devotion to these mass of people is so inspiring to see caught on film. A MUST WATCH!

name: Descendant
review: Has the self-awareness not merely to put Black voices at the center, where they belong, but to underline those moments when white people step up and intervene in the situation—sometimes as allies and advocates, sometimes to stake their own claim.

name: Descendant
review: ...an act of documentary journalism aimed at keeping African-American history alive.

name: Descendant
review: An important journey that is hampered, unfortunately, by a lack of focus during the voyage. However, the core story of history, remembrance, and restitution is so compelling.

name: Descendant
review: Boasting a wealth of vivid subjects, this new picture illustrates in clear terms how the country’s past sins still stain communities, the damage perhaps permanent.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant masterfully lets the descendants of the Clotilda survivors take back the narratives and tell the story that they and their ancestors’ oppressors have long kept buried. But this time, we can finally hear them loud and clear.

name: Descendant
review: A thematically rich documentary about the last ship to bring enslaved people to the United States.

name: Descendant
review: Llayered and trenchant.

name: Descendant
review: Brown weaves together a tight, deeply resonant, narrative, entrenching a crucial piece of Black history into the public record – a piece of Black history that’s in danger of slipping away forever.

name: Descendant
review: The notion of misery tourism and the much pricklier subject of reparations both arise in Descendant. This documentary does what some of the best in its genre do: raises more questions than it answers — the kinds of questions we need to be asking.

name: Descendant
review: Brown's knack for storytelling and technical mastery make her latest effort a step above her peers.

name: Descendant
review: We meet so many people in Descendant who could be the primary subjects of their own documentaries, and Brown deftly peels back the layers of all of their stories and makes them heard.

name: Descendant
review: An insightful investigation historical documentary.

name: Descendant
review: A cinemascope examination of how the stories of the descendants of the slave ship Clotilde are seen as an abstraction to be made into something concrete for the white world, equal parts Beloved and Chinatown.

name: Descendant
review: [Descendant] errs on the side of a cautious and tempered optimism which suggests that some rifts are destined to be forever unbridgeable.

name: Descendant
review: What Descendant initially renders into something of a suspenseful hunt for the truth barely lasts for half of the movie -- alerting us to the fact that it is not the only thing on the movie’s mind.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant can feel a bit protracted and meandering. But it makes very vivid just how immediate the legacy of slavery is in parts of the South, and why reparations represent a legitimate means of redressing historic wrongs that linger.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is a triumphant declaration of an important part of African American history that some people literally tried to bury. There's a lot of heartbreak in this documentary, but there's also a lot of hope.

name: Descendant
review: This undeniable, often unbearable ... story is told with dignity, and it rings a bell that may just result in amends for 140 years of injustice related to 400 years before that. Breathtaking.

name: Descendant
review: While it tells a powerful true story, it could have benefitted from a tighter running time.

name: Descendant
review: For older kids and teens, this insightful documentary shares the spirited allegiance of one African American community's activism to preserve its historic cultural heritage.

name: Descendant
review: [A] fascinating film...

name: Descendant
review: A heartfelt and captivating documentary that finds just the right balance between entertaining the audience and provoking them emotionally as well as intellectually.

name: Descendant
review: Weaving together a cross-section of interviews with descendants and community activists, the documentary builds from a sense of outrage to imagine a pathway toward healing, attentive to the complexity of the crime and its reverberation across generations.

name: Descendant
review: Brown... lets audiences make what they will of a rich tapestry.

name: Descendant
review: One of the best films of the year... Brown roves across the land, crowding her film with a wide spectrum of voices for a living oral history that reckons with the long shadow of slavery.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is worth seeing no matter who you are. For viewers like me, however, it engenders the reality that, no matter how hard anyone tries to whitewash history, our stories will forever continue to be told in full, by us and for us.

name: Descendant
review: What you have here with Margaret Brown’s film is a fascinating cultural touchstone, a documentary that morphs into different genres that all work and blend beautifully together.

name: Descendant
review: We’re in for something different here, is the film’s opening gambit. It’s an unspoken promise that Descendent lives up to.

name: Descendant
review: A feat of cinematic non-fiction storytelling, about the importance of storytelling itself.

name: Descendant
review: [T]the film becomes an intimate, thoughtful part of the larger conversation about who gets to tell whose history and why.

name: Descendant
review: If you’ve ever wondered what “holding space” looks like in practice, the director Margaret Brown’s deeply attentive documentary “Descendant” provides moving examples.

name: Descendant
review: Brown knows this is not her history to tell but rather an unfolding story about storytelling she can diligently observe in meetings, get-togethers and intimate interviews.

name: Descendant
review: “Descendant” isn’t just necessary. It’s urgent.

name: Descendant
review: A bit slow-moving at first, the history gives way to a thoughtful conversation about how best to remember this history and honor its victims, while simultaneously highlighting the modern science surrounding identifying the ship.

name: Descendant
review: It is both a highly specific story about one place and a universal tale of sin and survival that is as American as the proverbial apple pie.

name: Descendant
review: With Descendant, filmmaker Margaret Brown finds poetry where most would see the opportunity for a polemic.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is an infuriating and enlightening look at how often white supremacy alters the truth in its favor.

name: Descendant
review: It's a stunning journey into the uniquely American experience of history's unsteady grip on the present.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is a captivating and infuriating look at the injustices that have plagued the ancestors of the illegal slave ship, the Clotilda, for generations.

name: Descendant
review: The movie might have felt more comprehensive and compelling if driven by a single person. Rich community and uncovered history still make this documentary a must-see.

name: Descendant
review: Despite finding Clotilda and the attention brought to Africatown, there is still so much to unpack, and many truths remain buried.

name: Descendant
review: It is, frankly, terrifying to watch. What Descendant demonstrates is how ignoring the real story doesn’t just steal people’s history from them. It impoverishes the future.

name: Descendant
review: With remarkably immediate cinematography and an intimate understanding of its subjects, Descendant becomes an essential ideal of how to tell a communitys story.

name: Descendant
review: If the discovery of the Clotilda can be celebrated as proof of trauma and survival, it also confirms that the same wealthy white family that now owns the industrial plants that spew cancer-causing pollutants over Africatown engaged in the slave trade...

name: Descendant
review: Descendant films the stories from the progeny of the slaves of the Clotilda. The result is a testament to the spirit of a community that refuses to disappear.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is an urgent, powerful look at the Black citizens of Africatown in Mobile, Ala., and how they fight to reclaim the narrative of their generational suffering after the last slave ship is discovered in their backyard.

name: Descendant
review: In tracing the history of Africatown from 1860 to today, [director] Brown and her team broaden their scope and present an eye-opening look at environmental racism.

name: Descendant
review: A yearning for a definitive history is the driving force of this heart-warming doc.

name: Descendant
review: A disquieting film with enduring significance [that] brings a sense of historical closure and validation to its [subjects].

name: Descendant
review: Descendant would already be worth watching for its awe-inspiring investigation into the whereabouts and historical legacy of the Clotilda. But the film's strongest attribute is that it is constructed with an eye toward to the future.

name: Descendant
review: "Descendant" becomes not just a vital account of history, but an example of William Faulkner's maxim that "the past is never dead. It's not even past."

name: Descendant
review: The movie delivers an emotionally jangled, collage-like rush of purpose and urgency.

name: Descendant
review: "Descendant" doesn't provide easy answers for how individuals and governments can begin to grapple with this history, but it begins with the acknowledgment that its history will live on.

name: Descendant
review: A sprawling tapestry of American lives and a buried truth.

name: Descendant
review: Margaret Brown's beautiful, haunting, and ultimately inspiring documentary charts living history just outside of Mobile, Alabama.

name: Descendant
review: Margaret Brown exposes one of America's darkest secrets in this indie doc, and tackles such sensitive matter with dignity and grace.

name: Descendant
review: Margaret Brown's new documentary thoughtfully considers how a victimised community can heal from its inherited trauma, while offering flecks of hope for the future.

name: Descendant
review: What begins as a stirring, fascinating chronicle of the effort to locate and raise the ship turns into an infuriating tale of corporate criminality on the level of the underseenThe Devil We Know.

name: Descendant
review: I found Descendant moving and definitely recommend it

name: Descendant
review: History and the shame it carries transformed into a survivor's tale.

name: Descendant
review: [A] capacious and riveting film...

name: Descendant
review: In "Descendant," it isn't only the power of the story that's overwhelming, but getting to see the effect it has on those who tell it.

name: Descendant
review: 'Descendant' is more than a phenomenal documentary; it is a majestic work of art.

name: Descendant
review: Descendant is essential cinema and the film comes as America continues to face its racist past.

name: Descendant
review: Brown's must-watch filling of a historical gap, a blow against white-led Black erasure, "Descendent," explains to audiences how storytelling can be a revolutionary act.

name: The Janes
review: Since many women in the United States are essentially living in a pre-Roe world these days, this film couldn’t be more timely...

name: The Janes
review: The Janes nevertheless assembles important voices to put an essential story on the record. Ignore any apparent hastiness in the delivery, for it’s too late to return to the way things were before.

name: The Janes
review: The Janes provides a fascinating historical overview of the struggle for abortion access — but also has crucial relevance for the times we're living in, as the fight for reproductive freedom continues.

name: The Janes
review: The Janes is so much more than a mere history lesson. It’s a vibrant, attentive film that emphasizes the collaborative spirit and radical potential of a small community able to do tremendous work on a large scale.

name: The Janes
review: Through individual interviews, a composite image forms of a society touched on every level by half its population’s lack of bodily autonomy.

name: The Janes
review: You don’t watch The Janes for aesthetic pleasure. The palette is sober, and the filmmaking itself is recalcitrant, in service always of its tremendous story. But there is one moment I found indelible...

name: The Janes
review: “The Janes” shows us the reality that many, especially people of color and those of lower socioeconomic status, now face without the constitutional law.

name: The Janes
review: At once historic and timely, The Janes underscores the dangerous and often deadly threat of unwanted pregnancy pre-Roe v. Wade. A compelling and sobering documentary.

name: The Janes
review: You can’t call it “fun” viewing, but following the Supreme Court’s abolishment of Roe v. Wade, the HBO Max documentary The Janes is a vital watch.

name: The Janes
review: Now that the court has returned the country to the harrowing years chronicled in this film, The Janes and the women it profiles is even more compelling and essential.

name: The Janes
review: Vital viewing for anyone interested in the history behind the headlines.

name: The Janes
review: The lesson from The Janes is that, in the absence of justice and political power, there's enormous potential for collective action.

name: The Janes
review: Relevant and timely documentary about the grassroots group that between 1968 and 1973 arranged for and/or performed 11,000 safe, affordable abortions prior to Roe Vs. Wade.

name: The Janes
review: The Janes interviews former members of Chicago’s underground network that helped people secure abortions.

name: The Janes
review: The Janes is a film that you feel in your gut.

name: The Janes
review: The revealing documentary, The Janes proves -- if there were any doubt -- that sisterhood is powerful.

name: The Janes
review: It’s also not that The Janes could tragically have been relevant at pretty much any time in American history since the passing of Roe v Wade that makes it so good. Although it helps. Rather, it’s that The Janes is a good story well told.

name: The Janes
review: The real power of the documentary lies... in the interviews it features with some of the women who were involved with the organization and who helped make this safe abortion access possible and available to the women of Chicago.

name: The Janes
review: While the production value may be lacking in comparison to other historical documentaries, The Janes is still an excellent viewing experience about women who went up against laws to help other women.

name: The Janes
review: There were two documentaries about the underground Chicago abortion group at Sundance this year. This documentary is the only one you need to see.

name: The Janes
review: In this sobering HBO documentary, the group members recall their achievements with admirable candor and great heart.

name: The Janes
review: This documentary could hardly be timelier...

name: The Janes
review: While some aspects of that history should have been examined more introspectively, the documentary should be considered the definitive recounting of one of the most influential activist groups in American history.

name: The Janes
review: Directors Tia Lessin and Emma Pildes permeate "The Janes" with unforced wry humor that adds a triumphant glow to a story that other filmmakers may have presented as a grim struggle.

name: The Janes
review: “The Janes” tells an important story of women who fought unjust laws by becoming criminals themselves, putting themselves on the line for what they knew was right.

name: The Janes
review: What really resonates are the memories of women helping women by talking openly about the specific economic and health concerns that the male-dominated establishment typically ignored.

name: The Janes
review: Even if you’re well versed in the history of Roe v. Wade, this film will likely shock you. Especially given that half a century later, the cultural, religious and political war over abortion still rages.

name: The Janes
review: ...  an inspiring call to arms as history is poised to repeat itself.

name: The Janes
review: The movie remains compassionate and uplifting even as it gently tugs at difficult threads, with a message of solidarity that overcomes differences.

name: The Janes
review: The Janes takes needful steps in presenting an unflinching portrait of what a country without Roe looks like. In short: Catastrophic for all bodies capable of pregnancy, but especially for poor and working-class people of color.

name: The Janes
review: Cookie-cutter though it is, “The Janes” does have something going for it: its interview subjects, the former Janes, who all speak about their beliefs and shared past with striking clarity.

name: The Janes
review: The documentary The Janes asks: do we not share an obligation to disrespect a law that disrespects women?

name: The Janes
review: It’s a gripping historical document, regardless of where one stands on the central argument.

name: The Janes
review: Lessin and Pildes do a masterful job of putting the Janes in historical context, seeing how their desire to offer safe abortions grew out of the revolutionary ’60s and yet how women’s issues were often deemed secondary to male-led efforts.

name: The Janes
review: This is a beyond-timely look at the past, with an eye very much on the near future.

name: The Janes
review: Not only a crucial part of the historical record but a searingly contemporary film about the power of mutual aid and collective action.

name: The Janes
review: It’s a very fine film, and Chicago history that joined a long history of Chicago dissent.

name: The Janes
review: It's so good and unfortunately more timely than ever.

name: The Janes
review: Regardless of how people feel about abortion, The Janes documentary is not only a history lesson about what life in America was like before Roe v. Wade but it's also a compelling reminder of what’s at stake in reproductive rights and family planning.

name: The Janes
review: Those telling their stories aren’t from a completely alien era, and the knowledge that they share, in tones frank and thoughtful by turn, is incredibly valuable.

name: The Janes
review: As a look back on the last 50 years ... Lessin and Pildes’s "The Janes" is like Cassandra, the priestess of Apollo, screaming from the past to remember what it was like when a woman’s individual right to choose was dictated by others.

name: The Janes
review: A disarmingly cool and matter-of-fact yet utterly crucial documentary about some of the most daring, radical, and largely unsung heroes ever put onscreen.

name: The Janes
review: This provides valuable information on a group that go around anti-choice legislation.

name: The Janes
review: Tia Lessin and Emma Pildes’ documentary about the women activists who helped thousands of people access abortions before they were legal offers a chilling look at what’s possibly to come.

name: The Janes
review: An important film to see as Roe v. Wade is under threat, the ‘The Janes’ shows the danger that women on the frontlines of safe abortions were up against.

name: The Janes
review: A powerful portrait of strength and resilience.

name: The Janes
review: Newspaper headlines, old footage of political/social marches and clips of the younger women back in the day fill in the details of these strong-willed advocates.

name: The Janes
review: Tia Lessin and Emma Pildes’s well-researched documentary...

name: The Janes
review: It serves its purpose well: to ensure everyone knows that these incredible women existed and have a bona fide place in history.

name: The Janes
review: The documentary proved to be the far-better film, one that recounts the fascinating story in a way that helps viewers to understand the very real dangers that these people went through to help women.

name: The Janes
review: I could listen to these warriors for justice speak for hours, and I left the film longing for more of their stories. I also didn't expect a beautiful story of humanity to emerge from a documentary about underground abortionists.

name: The Janes
review: The Janes marks an essential act of recovery. This doc takes a past movement known only through word of mouth and makes it present.

name: The Janes
review: Featuring interviews with surviving members ... the movie makes the critical case for why "The Janes" were necessary and how they operated.

name: The Janes
review: The candor of the Janes and their obvious, continuing pride in the work they did means this is a documentary that will be referred to for a long time.

name: The Janes
review: While the movie's narrative stops in 1973, when Roe v. Wade made the Jane network unneeded, the undertone of this vital chronicle is that history is on the verge of repeating itself.

name: The Janes
review: It’s hard not to come away a little bit in love with the now 60- and 70-something women of Jane, who give this documentary its backbone through lively, sharp talking head interviews about the risky yet empowering work that defined their young lives.

name: The Janes
review: These women were outlaws. They were also heroes, and it's high time more people recognized them as such. The Janes is a great start.

name: The Janes
review: A peppy history lesson of [the JANE Collective's] heroism.

name: The Janes
review: Co-directors Tia Lessin and Emma Pildes remind viewers of the importance of knowing our collective history in order to avoid repeating it.

name: The Janes
review: There isn't an unmemorable interview in the film.

name: The Janes
review: "The Janes" is too smart to be self-congratulatory, but the omission of any mention of the current state of affairs feels like a missed opportunity, a celebration of the past that shies away from looking at the present and future.

name: The Janes
review: Lessin and Pildes' educative, eye-opening documentary raises awareness of a fight that, for some, is ongoing.

name: The Janes
review: Lessin and Pildes give a worthy account of some crazily courageous young women, who testify now before their camera as to what they did - and why.

name: The Janes
review: Many of the stories and subjects that round out the film could easily spawn their own documentaries and series, but The Janes stands as a compelling look at their work that should educate and enthrall curious audiences.

name: The Janes
review: As one of the Janes recalls with a sigh about the passage of Roe v. Wade, "We were thrilled. And we thought it was over." The knowledge that it wasn't, and still isn't, is a charge that runs through the entire film.

name: The Janes
review: In sticking to the facts, it remains plenty rousing.

name: The Duke
review: English comedies seem to have more than their share of eccentric characters in the very distinct British style of humor. Here, British actor Jim Broadbent fills the bill perfectly, playing a real life British eccentric, Kempton Bunton.

name: The Duke
review: Designed as a crowd pleaser for the silver screen generation, it can feel a little paint by numbers at times. However thanks to the terrific central performances, colourful caper The Duke proves life certainly ain’t grim up north.

name: The Duke
review: It just doesn’t feel like anybody is on their A-game. ... It's not a grand finale to [Michell's] career; it's like an encore where he plays an endearing crowdpleaser with a simple chorus about making the world a better place, one we can sing along to.

name: The Duke
review: Gloriously witty, and comic... wonderful film.

name: The Duke
review: Basically a David and Goliath tale in which the sling and stone are replaced by a cheery attitude and an open heart.

name: The Duke
review: Directed by the late Roger Michell, this dramatization of the true-life caper of a working-class pensioner stealing a famous portrait and holding it for ransom in exchange for free TV licenses is a simple but charming cup of Northern goodness.

name: The Duke
review: Director Roger Michell's final movie is a charming comedy/drama set in 1961 depicting the infamously true story of how Goya's portrait of the Duke of Wellington was stolen from the National Gallery by an unlikely thief.

name: The Duke
review: Little is too shaken or stirred, but it all goes down smoothly and delightfully — and with some bite.

name: The Duke
review: ...easy to overlook, but a lot of fun for those who invest their time.

name: The Duke
review: It’s an old-school British caper in the Ealing Studios tradition, modestly but glowingly crafted and beautifully acted by old pros — and you leave it both buoyant and a little sad. Making that feel easy is hard.

name: The Duke
review: There are strains of the old Ealing Studios comedies — whimsical tales of plucky Brits taking on the system — running through “The Duke,” a based-on-a-true-story tale that’s enlivened by the pairing of Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren.

name: The Duke
review: You won’t catch anyone accusing Roger Michell of being edgy or innovative. But in his last film, the late director pushes an audiences’ buttons with crowd-pleasing precision.

name: The Duke
review: The overall feel proves cheery and enjoyable, a likable nod to people with ideas worth sharing.

name: The Duke
review: The acting is world-class and Oscar-worthy portraying endearingly eccentric characters who sustain an enduring, but slightly demented, relationship. The result is delightful, moving, and richly satisfying...

name: The Duke
review: “Torn from the headlines” usually indicates a tragedy in the offing. In case of Kempton Bunton it means head-shaking delights.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is more than just a traditionally made movie about a man who goes on trial for stealing a valuable painting from London's National Gallery. It's also a witty and emotional drama about a family coping with grief.

name: The Duke
review: Jim Broadbent delivers a performance that is exactly how we want to see a quirky chap behave. His comic timing is flawless. Helen Mirren has less to do, but she does it brilliantly.

name: The Duke
review: Thankfully, The Duke is a middle-of-the-road confection that stays nice and rosy thanks to durable Oscar winners Broadbent and Mirren.

name: The Duke
review: ‘The Duke’ is the final film for prolific stage/screen/TV director Roger Michell, a man who gave jobs to Daniel Craig long before the actor did his 007 thing. Naturally, then, the final shot might leave you nicely stirred while probably not shaken.

name: The Duke
review: Michell keeps it all moving at a brisk pace, taking an improbable story and adding a few unexpected twists and turns. The Duke is easy to like because of its seemingly effortless charm.

name: The Duke
review: “The Duke” won’t blow the doors off the multiplex the way “Doctor Strange” will this weekend, but as a good-natured salute to the Kempton Buntons of the world, it’s very satisfying. We need them now more than ever.

name: The Duke
review: The music, the cinematography, the directing by Roger Michell and the consumate performances all harken back to kinder, more sentimental times when cinema focused on story, character and relationships, and got it all in under two hours.

name: The Duke
review: Michell adds just enough zippy early-1960s style to evoke the period, without ever distracting from the carefully crafted characters and warm, lived-in performances.

name: The Duke
review: Ultimately, some may want a bit more from it, but it does have the chance to steal your heart — gone like a painting snatched in the night.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke may superficially seem like old hat, but in its comfortable ways there’s still a strong message.

name: The Duke
review: Above all, Dolly and Kempton’s exchanges add true-to-life sparkle. Kristina Hetherington’s editing is inventive, George Fenton’s music has energy, and Mike Eley’s cinematography adds the period ambiance and droll humor of 1950s Ealing comedies.

name: The Duke
review: Jim Broadbent gives a twinkly, charismatic performance as an obscure Brit raconteur who stole a famous painting, with Helen Mirren as his long-suffering wife.

name: The Duke
review: A charming, understated and completely enjoyable frolic about how ordinary people can do extraordinary things that seems doubly startling because, while seeming implausible, it also happens to be absolutely true.

name: The Duke
review: Heartwarming, beautifully shot and more English than a basket of fish and chips with a side of mushy peas, it’s an easy-to-watch, easy-to-love crowd-pleaser.

name: The Duke
review: The duo of Broadbent and Mirren are magnificent to watch together; I appreciated Mirren's restraint as she allowed Broadbent to shine in this excellent heartwarming true story.

name: The Duke
review: The film has charm to spare, much of that provided by screen veteran Jim Broadbent who’s able to portray Bunton, an eccentric with a heart of gold, without making him look like a fool.

name: The Duke
review: Its a fizzy, fun little film that I hope isnt forgotten.

name: The Duke
review: A simple, sentimental story told with panache and cast to perfection

name: The Duke
review: An irresistible comedy anchored by wonderful performances from Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren.

name: The Duke
review: Stealing from museums may normally be no laughing matter, but here the entire affair is played to the comic hilt, even as it explores more serious issues of income inequality, social class, prejudice, and grief.

name: The Duke
review: Suffice to say that Broadbent is flawless and lovable, and has the good sense to act as straight man when Helen Mirren, as his beyond fed-up wife Dorothy, hilariously lets rip at him.

name: The Duke
review: 'The Duke' isn't a regal biopic, but it's a lovely one.

name: The Duke
review: The movie qualifies as a solid -- if small -- entertainment that gives Broadbent a showcase role.

name: The Duke
review: ... an amusing true-life portrait that balances quirky charm with a more serious examination of sociopolitical issues facing British seniors during the 1960s.

name: The Duke
review: Far from a great film, it still captures a time, place and group of attitudes to a degree that I found refreshing and thoroughly delightful.

name: The Duke
review: It turns out that watching Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren costar in this real-life comedy-drama is genuine fun.

name: The Duke
review: 'The Duke' is a crowd-pleasing, sweet, sentimental and a little messy story about an individual's responsibility to his neighbor, even if the cost is more than he can pay.

name: The Duke
review: Michell deftly balances the drama and comedy in this bizarre true story... the screenwriters, actors and director collaborated splendidly to craft an ultimately uplifting story tinged with real-life pathos.

name: The Duke
review: It’s a daft, lovely story, and it opens up like a flower – the final half hour is deeply and unexpectedly moving.

name: The Duke
review: In the tradition of British heist comedies, and that it really happened, once again proves that truth is as entertaining as fiction. Broadbent is hilarious as the eccentric and very British dreamer, hilarious in the later courtroom scenes. Priceless!

name: The Duke
review: THE DUKE is the quintessential British movie --- charming, hilarious and informative.

name: The Duke
review: With old pros Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren heading the cast, along with a smart screenplay, this story fits deservedly into the "feel good" genre.

name: The Duke
review: It's a combination of situational humor, political commentary, and character study -- all of it equally understated and clever...

name: The Duke
review: the filmmakers do a solid job in telling a true-life tale that no one heard about. Well, now you do and it is a good one for us seniors.

name: The Duke
review: [The Duke] sometimes gets overly sentimental and rose-colored about its “simpler” early 60s milieu, but Broadbent more than carries this homage to the triumph of a little man.

name: The Duke
review: This messing around with chronology could feel manipulative if the stakes of "The Duke" were higher but, instead, it's like each revelation is a little gift.

name: The Duke
review: A delicious crowd-pleaser in the old Ealing mode, a fact-based dramedy about a little man with a dream who bests the system by sheer pluck.

name: The Duke
review: Broadbent always seems to work with a twinkle in his eye and a spring in his step, and his scenes with Helen Mirren make "The Duke" just barely bearable.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is appealing and wayward, too, if also given to both slickness (split screens? really?) and more than a dollop of sentimentality.

name: The Duke
review: It's all very sweet and light, with a message about the importance of standing up for one's beliefs at its center. Nothing wrong with that at all.

name: The Duke
review: Ultimately, “The Duke” tells an enjoyable real-life story.

name: The Duke
review: If you want pinpoint accuracy, watch a documentary. If you want to see top-notch actors inhabit characters in genuine and ultimately moving ways, The Duke is a much better option.

name: The Duke
review: Even though it seems like lighter fare, the story has a way of sneaking up on you.

name: The Duke
review: It will put a smile on your face, and while its conclusion might feel simplistic, The Duke never promised to tell the truth. It’s got higher aspirations than that.

name: The Duke
review: Broadbent brilliantly plays an endearing character you can't help caring about.

name: The Duke
review: A sweet package made sweeter by two of England’s finest actors.

name: The Duke
review: This is a great story, beautifully told, combining a do-gooder with a heart of gold with the only theft in the history of the National Gallery.

name: The Duke
review: Despite its wizened subject and courtroom setting, this comedy-drama has the breezy air of a director in the bloom of youthor of a seasoned artist determined to prove hes still got it. Reader: he does.

name: The Duke
review: A carefree way to spend 90 minutes, The Duke won't feel like a theft of any precious family viewing time.

name: The Duke
review: A British period film that deals with working class characters and that actually has a protagonist attempting to wrestle with social issues and effect change is refreshing. Worth watching for Broadbent and Whitehead's performances.

name: The Duke
review: In the tradition of his earlier work, Michell has elegantly interspersed the intrigue of The Duke with snippets of humor that give everything a laid-back feel.

name: The Duke
review: While there’s nothing innately wrong with The Duke, it’s merely an old-fashioned flavor of a film, nothing more.

name: The Duke
review: As he did throughout his illustrious filmography, in RogerMichell...again peels back the layers of British culture and class, introducing us to characters who are comfortable with the nations stubbornly staid ways and those chafing against it.

name: The Duke
review: There are times I look up at the big screen during a film featuring Jim Broadbent and I simply smile. The Duke is one of those times.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke caps Michells career in a gently enjoyable manner.

name: The Duke
review: Though it lags slightly in the middle, The Duke is an overall delightful depiction of a remarkable true story led by heartwarming performances.

name: The Duke
review: This is an unmistakably British import. Its quiet charm stakes a claim for mature viewers but dont mistake "offbeat" for "bland." Theres nothing banal or predictable about this lighthearted tale, which is based on a true story.

name: The Duke
review: "The Duke" is completely agreeable, and pleasant, but it could have been more arch or cynical. This film ends up being as likable as its puckish hero, who gets by on his good will.

name: The Duke
review: One of the pleasures -- even privileges -- of watching a film like this is seeing what superb actors are able to do with material that doesn’t aspire to greatness. The story is charming, the performances are exceptional.

name: The Duke
review: Happily, Michell is more interested in the grifter than the grift. And Broadbent, expanding luxuriously into his ideal leading role, is absolutely delightful.

name: The Duke
review: Their touching chemistry does the trick, and Broadbent is darned near perfect as a man whose Robin Hood-like principles won out in the most unlikely of scenarios.

name: The Duke
review: Bunton is a rabble-rouser and a compelling hero for this film by the director Roger Michell, who died in September after a career of humanist charmers including "Notting Hill" and "Venus." It is a pity that the script mires Bunton in a soggy family drama

name: The Duke
review: The theft itself, and the subsequent (overdone) trial scene that functions as its prologue and aftermath, are in many ways secondary to the film’s humane charms. What’s best about The Duke are its witty grace notes.

name: The Duke
review: It's a perfect rainy day film that your parents and grandparents will likely love. Something I'm sure the late Roger Mitchell would be very proud of.

name: The Duke
review: Solid entertainment, with Michell finding a tonal balance that keeps the story afloat and the fine acting prominent, making his best film in nearly two decades.

name: The Duke
review: With a story as absurd as this one, Michells characteristic restraint flourishes the materials, and his understated direction willingly takes a backseat to let his actors performances run the show.

name: The Duke
review: Probably one of Michells stronger movies, so its even sadder that its also his final film.

name: The Duke
review: If the film isn’t quite as complicated as one might sometimes wish it to be, that isn’t to say that this unassuming version of its decidedly strange true tale is anything other than agreeable on its own terms.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is a heartwarming film that deftly tackles classism, coming to terms with grief, and the indignity of racial slights. Jim Broadbent delights as an irrepressible dreamer. The Duke is a ray of cinematic light.

name: The Duke
review: You almost have to wonder how a story this crazy needed sixty years to finally get a big screen adaptation, but I'm glad it did since I don't think anyone could have filled Bunton's shoes quite like the affable Broadbent.

name: The Duke
review: A crowd-pleasing, funny and charming throwback to Ealing Studios' classic British comedies. It will make you stand up and cheer. Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren are terrific.

name: The Duke
review: The film confirms that one of Michell’s enduring themes was exasperation—an unglamorous emotion, familiar to us all but, unlike rage, seldom given its cinematic due.

name: The Duke
review: Old-fashioned it may be, but the revolutionary spirit of this gloriously absurd comedy about a masterpiece that was borrowed for the greater good, a crime caper with roots in British social realism and in Ealing classic comedies, will sit well at any time

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is the kind of film that Hollywood, for better or worse, doesn't make anymore: smart, character-driven, a mischievous twinkle in the eye -- a movie that can comfortably entertain an entire family without a glimpse of spandex.

name: The Duke
review: Academy Award winner Jim Broadbent relishes the chance to play such a fun character and that same vibe will rub off on audiences.

name: The Duke
review: There's always space in this world for a gentle, affable dramedy starring Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren.

name: The Duke
review: Casting Jim Broadbent as the lovable but hopeless Kempton is the film’s first good decision. No one is more comfortable in the role of an average British bloke, especially one from the lower middle or working classes.

name: The Duke
review: It is funny, sweet and sentimental without ever feeling overly saccharine or heavy-handed, even when it increasingly panders to expectations and pushes credibility to the point that it is clearly taking massive liberties with the details.

name: The Duke
review: While it wont exactly steal your heart, The Duke is a royal treat.

name: The Duke
review: A geriatric Oceans Eleven, if you will, The Duke pits the incomparable Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren together as the ageing, unwilling thief and his put-upon wife, respectively, consistently elevating the already marvellous material throughout.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is a fabulous showcase for one of the seemingly forgotten greats of British acting in Jim Broadbent and fitting fictional swansong by the brilliant director Roger Michell.

name: The Duke
review: sails pretty close to parody, and it is as sentimental as all get out, but it is irresistible at the same time.

name: The Duke
review: A fluffy crowdpleaser with just enough spark (and an endearing lead turn by Broadbent) to cap Michell's career.

name: The Duke
review: The kind of bouncy yarn that British cinema does so well, its a gentle and accomplished farewell to a British cinema great.

name: The Duke
review: Enticing viewers to chuckle or guffaw can be hard, though the best comic actors make it look deceptively simple.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is a thoroughly enjoyable piece of British whimsy.

name: The Duke
review: With The Duke, director Roger Michell (who sadly died ahead of the film’s release) carves an amiable cinematic tale out of a bonkers true story that, thanks to an irresistible turn from Broadbent, works better than it should.

name: The Duke
review: It's with no pleasure to report that while perfectly entertaining, largely inoffensive and very occasionally rousing, The Duke consistently lacks the bite needed to offset its sense of sleepy comfort.

name: The Duke
review: If Jim Broadbent ever felt inclined to commit a high-stakes art heist, The Duke is proof that he would probably get away with it. He’s that disarmingly winsome.

name: The Duke
review: Warm-hearted, funny and unexpectedly touching, too.

name: The Duke
review: [A] hilarious, rousing and wonderfully old-fashioned underdog drama.

name: The Duke
review: How long does it take to realise that Jim Broadbent has, in Roger Michell’s The Duke, happened upon one of his greatest screen roles? About five seconds.

name: The Duke
review: Jovially neutral fare, preferring to frame its story as an unashamedly old-fashioned underdog tale – an absurdist struggle of the little man against monolithic bureaucracy.

name: The Duke
review: This is one of those snappy, well-formed Brit-coms that one expects to see reworked as a Full Monty- or Kinky Boots-style Broadway show.

name: The Duke
review: The Duke is a searingly funny, quintessentially British comedy with some truly joyous performances from Jim Broadbent and Dame Helen Mirren.

name: The Duke
review: The pacing is superb, and there isn’t a single wasted frame. Broadbent as Bunton is impossible to dislike and inevitably leaves the viewer with a smile.

name: The Duke
review: Jim Broadbent is priceless in this canny, tender British comedy, based on a real-life art heist that bamboozled the police, as well as the scriptwriters of Bond adventure Dr. No.

name: The Duke
review: Simply wonderful.

name: The Duke
review: There is lots of fun to be had in a gentle Ealing-style comedy that reveals the absurdity of life.

name: The Duke
review: The kind of heist movie that will steal your affections from under your nose. An Ealing-esque comedy with its heart exactly in the right place, it proves a fitting farewell for the multitalented director, Roger Michell.

name: The Duke
review: This is a fitting tribute to Michell, who died last year, and who directs with a light touch throughout, while Broadbent and Mirren are, needless to say, terrific.

name: The Duke
review: Funny, silly and just a damn good time at the pictures.

name: The Duke
review: With his apologetic lankiness and his look of befuddled alarm, Broadbent is a joy as the idealistic amateur playwright Kempton Bunton.

name: The Duke
review: The one sadness is that this is Michell’s last fiction film, the director having died last year. He left us this warm and quietly subversive movie; a sweet surprise package.

name: The Duke
review: [A] sweet-natured and genial comedy in the spirit of Ealing, which bobs up like a ping pong ball on a water-fountain.

name: The Duke
review: A pleasantly polished bit of whimsy, with a sly twist ending.

name: The Duke
review: An undeniable crowd-pleaser, The Duke is a delight with more than the occasional nod in the direction of Ealing. It's impossible not to warm to Kempton Bunton, as played by Jim Broadbent, in this endearing fanfare for the common man.

name: The Duke
review: ...The Duke is a comedy, but a comedy with some heart...

name: The Duke
review: Jim Broadbent could play a vicious despot and still make you wish he was your uncle.

name: The Duke
review: Thievery and courtroom theatrics rule the roost when a British senior cit stands up for his self-perceived rights.

name: The Duke
review: A lively and engaging account of the unusual 1961 theft of Francisco Goya's portrait of the Duke of Wellington from London's National Gallery and the eccentric do-gooder at the center of it all.

name: The Duke
review: A sprightly, well-handled comedy with the distinction of a very amusing courtroom sequence...The film also plays with stereotypes of the English, wherein Bunton is the loveable suburban eccentric rubbing up against the prim-and-proper establishment.

name: The Duke
review: Roger Michell and his cast keep it briskly entertaining.

name: The Duke
review: The tale is sillier than a '60s Ealing﻿ Studios comedy, and will warm you like a perfect cup of English tea.

name: The Duke
review: The film misses an opportunity to delve particularly deeply into the keenly relevant issues of inequality and social disconnection that so animate its protagonist.

name: The Duke
review: This stranger-than-fiction heist yarn has now been made into a loveable comedy drama directed by Roger Michell...

name: The Duke
review: There's nothing mind-blowing in the serene storytelling, but as enjoyable as the film can be, what's not to like about observing the Buntons' dynamics?

name: The Duke
review: This spry and sometimes sentimental caper from Roger Michell (Notting Hill) is an unabashed crowd-pleaser, with a real-life Robin Hood at its centre.

name: The Duke
review: Britain hasn't lost the ability to make films like this after all. We've had it stashed in the back of the wardrobe all along.

name: The Duke
review: Bring your mum and your gran (or anyone's gran if yours is not available) preferably to a matinee, and you'll have a delightful time and be home, whistling cheerfully, in time for tea.

name: The Duke
review: Throughout everything Broadbent is astounding, both foolish and infuriating, but also deeply sympathetic.

name: The Duke
review: The script by Richard Bean and Clive Coleman is full of delightfully droll dialogue, and director Roger Michell keeps things as light and sharp as lemon soufflé.

name: The Duke
review: Gloriously entertaining, with Broadbent and Mirren on excellent form. A quintessentially British film which, while it doesn't reinvent the cinematic experience, is sure to be enjoyed by many.

name: The Duke
review: It's a quirky but stirring tale, beautifully scripted by Richard Bean and Clive Coleman, while director Roger Michell brings the same sureness of comedic touch he applied to the likes of Notting Hill and Venus.

name: The Duke
review: Clever from the title on down.

name: The Duke
review: Broadbent's considerable charisma as a prototype social justice warrior is just about enough to pull the rag-and-bone cart home on a film which becomes more defiantly contrived as it goes on.

name: The Duke
review: What a lovely, rousing, finally moving film this is.

name: The Duke
review: A perfectly nimble, kind-hearted bit of teatime entertainment - ideally tailored to Jim Broadbent in one of his most appealing big-screen roles.

name: The Duke
review: This is the kind of British film with international appeal: the venerable cast, genial tone, inspirational story, and mischievous English eccentricity are all present and correct. Settle in, preferably with a nice cup of tea to hand, and enjoy.

name: X
Rating: R (Gore|Drug Use|Strong Sexual Content|Graphic Nudity|Language|Strong Bloody Violence)

name: X
review: A gruesome slasher reminiscent of classic horror.

name: X
review: Ends with a wholly satisfying finale and avoids the pitfalls of frustrating the audience, as so many independent horror films seem to do. It’s a slower burn for sure, but what a bloody, gory, rewarding ride.

name: X
review: I can give X the benefit of the doubt [with hindsight], accepting it as an entrypoint into a much larger world regardless of how incomplete it ultimately feels on its own.

name: X
review: X was true to its name, explicit sexual scenes, horrify scenarios & every more on the stories backdrop. But as a horror film Ti West nails it with his touch on horror story telling and worst case scenario perspective for every character it’s a insane ride

name: X
review: It’s crass and ghastly, with an on-the-nose premise fit for the often- sensationalist slasher genre and the salacious X-rated cinema embedded in this story.

name: X
review: The film itself goes beyond being merely a ‘blood and guts killer time’ with an array of porn star characters. It feeds into your adrenaline and spikes it up to ten.

name: X
review: If you're looking for a slow burn horror flick with plenty of atmosphere and faux-grindhouse aesthetics then X gon' give it to you!

name: X
review: The characters are fleshed-out and kooky — you’ll mourn when they meet their inevitable slaughter. And for a slasher, the acting is remarkably good: Jenna Ortega and Mia Goth in particular are scene-stealers.

name: X
review: X reanimates perennial fears of aging, older women, and one’s fading relevance.

name: X
review: X is a daring slasher, filled with unexpected twists that leave viewers stewing in uncomfortable moments and horrifying realizations.

name: X
review: X is a bold horror film that might just be the best dirty movie you’ve seen all year.

name: X
review: If you go into this with your eyes open, it delivers a well-crafted slasher horror on all counts, even if its finale and body-count are hardly a surprise.

name: X
review: Ti West skillfully blends style with substance in A24’s X, delivering a riff on The Texas Chain Saw Massacre with a few subversive – and sexy – twists.

name: X
review: Whatever West is trying here doesn’t ultimately land, maybe because West himself doesn’t seem to care about any of these people.

name: X
review: Raw, emotional, upsetting, and unafraid to take its audiences to grotesque places, X is one of the very best films of the year.

name: X
review: X manages to tap into the nostalgic style of 70's horror while being a breath of fresh air for the genre. Ti West shows through his masterful directing, while winking at the audience, that you can put a ton of artistic flair into a "dirty movie."

name: X
review: Ti West’s “X” is an unashamed ode to slasher movies that manages to capture what makes the good ones good while still being hampered by what makes the bad ones bad.

name: X
review: It pays homage to the adult film industry of the 70s, but I'm afraid it loses its guts by going through the easy and boring paths of conventional exploitation slasher. [Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review: Now this is the modern-day answer to The Texas Chain Saw Massacre we’ve been waiting for!

name: X
review: There's lashings of sex and gore, plus a few surprises along the way.

name: X
review: Smart, savvy and spectacularly staged while straddling and embracing that fine line between pleasure and pain.

name: X
review: Pure fun, X intelligently exploits the genre's codes without transgressing and incorporating small doses of humor for the seasoned viewer. [Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review: An exquisite filmic anachronism that, disguised as the usual slasher, develops a discourse that gets under the skin and that, ultimately, elevates it as one of the greatest and riskiest titles of 2022.

name: X
review: The impressive direction and delightful performances, anchored by a terrific central turn from Goth, make this an enthralling horror entry that can satisfy the hunger for exciting spectacle and more sophisticated storytelling.

name: X
review: West's best film to date: a gooey, ebullient orgy of the lewd and the learned, the squalid and the sumptuous.

name: X
review: There’s nothing original about West’s highly stylized film, it’s just a down and dirty horror jam with a decent batch of jump-scares.

name: X
review: ... A film tribute to 70's B-movies, particularly Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Deep Throat.

name: X
review: There's more sincerity in a good porn film... [Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review: X, first hour of the film is an homage to 70s psycho-sexual-film making and the last 45 minutes is a psycho-biddy/slasher. It's interesting to say the least but at no point was this a scary film.

name: X
review: A real delight, a genius within the genre that while paying homage to the classics, applies a rolling pin to expand the plot towards the unexpected. [Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review: While certainly creepy and provocative at times, X stumbles from the pretentious pedestal this “elevated” horror film has propped itself upon.

name: X
review: It's Mia Goth's show. The English-Brazilian actress is building a fine repertoire in the horror genre as someone who likes to dive into the deep end of psychotic-tinged stories with a human element coercing through it.

name: X
review: Overall, X is an entertaining and vivid throwback horror, with a mesmerizing performance from Goth, even if it doesn't slash quite as deep as it intends.

name: X
review: A lubricated and bloody nightmare where desire, pain, coitus, and murder are inseparable parts of the same basic act, animal and profoundly human. [Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review: ... a slightly unfocused twist on the sex-and-death genre.

name: X
review: Equally entertains and frightens… a genuine cinephile's feast. [Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review:
A quality horror film. 
[Full review in Spanish]

name: X
review: Aside from its throwback grindhouse visual aesthetic, the film provides only hit-or-miss laughs and thrills, relying on stock characters and gratuitous gore rather than refreshing the formula.

name: X
review: West's return to horror is beautifully shot and features several stand-out female performances. The relationship between porn and horror isn't as novel as critics made it out to be, but the innovative "stutter cuts" alone make X worth checking out

name: X
review: Think of this as The Texas Chainsaw Massacre meets Deep Throat. Ti West makes it perfectly clear that hes paying homage to these iconic films as he fills the movie with the meta commentary and tropes of this era in filmmaking.

name: X
review: Endorsing the patterns of several classics but endowing them with unbridled new audacity, this shocker also provides substantial gore.

name: X
review: Sometimes in life, you just want a simple slasher movie that checks the boxes and then some, X is that movie. Mixing great tension, kills, brutality, and solid characters, X delivers one of the better horror movies of recent years.

name: X
review: Ty West directs a horror that moves beyond simple slaughter. He expands into a broader discussion of religion, sexuality, and gender, thereby making X a slasher joyride with something more to say.

name: X
review: Making an artful horror movie is like making an avant-garde porno film: Whatever creative touches you want to include in it, ultimately the filmmaker has to show the people what they came to see.

name: X
review: There's tension, proper fleshiness that makes the audience wince, and the actors seem to be really enjoying themselves. Entertaining and repugnant, in a good way.

name: X
review: Still gives me shivers

name: X
review: It was entertaining. It stuck with me. i didn't know what to expect... I feel like this was a new angle for a slasher flick.

name: X
