review: It's not my favorite take on Batman or Bruce Wayne, but done well enough that I have more positives than negatives. A good to great film.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman proves to be monotonous murk.

name: The Batman
review: Rarely do I use the word "perfect", but I wouldn't change a thing about "The Batman". It's an absolute "must-see more than once".

name: The Batman
review: Wants to be critical of Batman as a vigilante who uses excessive force and use the Riddler to comment on white male radicalization, which may actually feel newly relevant after the freedom convoy, but the points don't land as hard as Batman's fists.

name: The Batman
review: The standout performer among the cast is Kravitz, whose Catwoman is constantly keeping all the men in The Batman on their toes.

name: The Batman
review: Beneath the rubber ears, he’s all granite-chinned and haunted eyes. Off duty, he’s a tragic, wan, raccoon-eyed Bruce Wayne. He hurts. He suffers. And that’s OK, because his Batman is the tense center of a whirl of well-cast characters.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves delightfully returns this property to the realm of adult sensibilities as far as mood, tone and characterization are concerned.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a smart and uncompromising work that makes the familiar seems fresh and which does have more on its mind than simply extending a valuable [intellectual property].

name: The Batman
review: Although it does disappointingly go over the top on occasion, there’s just too much depth and style to The Batman for it to be anything other than a success.

name: The Batman
review: ... Just because it's grim doesn't mean it's a drag: this is exhilarating filmmaking on every level.

name: The Batman
review: It occurred to me that The Batman feels, in atmosphere and pretensions, exactly like what was so sublimely spoofed by 2017's The Lego Batman Movie. It isn't every day that the target of a parody shows up five years after the parody itself.

name: The Batman
review: The shame of it is Reeves' hewing to all those established norms negates the elements of the film that do feel more revelatory, creating a kind of mish-mash of ideas rather than an engaging whole.

name: The Batman
review: Pattinson deserves another two movies to grow into the character. He looks great in the suit, and he's got the broodiness of Batman down pat. He just needs more time to be the man under the mask and remind audiences he's human.

name: The Batman
review: In an era of superhero gluttony, in which these familiar stories, characters, and visuals tend to bleed together, The Batman holds the rare distinction of creating and embracing its own identity.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves strikes closer to the core of Batmans ethos than any other live-action depiction, a noir mystery ripe for Gothams murky confines.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman just gets darker and more oppressive. This is the pandemic caped crusader, and he has a personality disorder.

name: The Batman
review: My reaction may be mixed but there's lots to love about Mat Reeves' The Batman. It owes more to the likes of Zodiac or Road To Perdition than to common heroes-in-tights fodder ... here's my video take!

name: The Batman
review: ... so bleak and cynical that it too often forgets to be fun, which would be forgivable if the central mystery was more compelling or if the films thematic complexity matched its technical ambitions.

name: The Batman
review: THE BATMAN is not a superhero movie. Reeves eerie tone and subject matter plays more like a horror movie. Matt Reeves has crafted a different cinematic interpretation in THE BATMAN that merits a place in the DCEU with Robert Pattinson as the vigilante.

name: The Batman
review: The capable cast all inhabit their roles with panache, but some of the film's potency is lost with certain unconvincing narrative twists and a few characters who feel stale.

name: The Batman
review: Only more time under the cowl will confirm it, but based on this performance alone, Robert Pattinson may be the best live-action version of The Dark Knight yet.

name: The Batman
review: The question is not whether or not The Batman is smart and well put together; undeniably, it is. The question is whether or not you want this particular film about this particular character.

name: The Batman
review: While its action is appropriately theatrical and its mystery appropriately intriguing, in the end this is a film that lives and thrives on its thematic resonance. It lives in the brain instead of passing through it.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman takes the best of what we have read, watched, and listened to for the better part of a century, and crafted one of the greatest depictions of the character on the big screen to date.

name: The Batman
review: If this film effectively repurposes our shared trauma into something more palpable and satisfying, then maybe Matt Reeves finds something that eludes most Batman films of the past. He makes him relevant.

name: The Batman
review: While The Batman might tread familiar ground... there’s enough that’s distinctive here to ensure it makes good on its promise.

name: The Batman
review: Pattinson makes a great Batman, but he makes an even better Bruce Wayne.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves has a strong artistic vision that's worth seeing for fans of the Dark Knight. The movie is not a home run, though.

name: The Batman
review: This is a redemptive view of a superhero as sociopath, trying to balance moral courage against a society that believes youre a chump if you do so. Riddle me this  what society does that sound like? Theater tip ... an empty bladder  full experience.

name: The Batman
review: Batman Begins, again.

name: The Batman
review: Pattinson's one-note performance isn't the fundamental problem. The problem is that it attempts to embody the current ethos of deconstructing systems we once believed represented the common good  and that includes the system that created Batman.

name: The Batman
review: A rock-solid building block that re-establishes the hero for its next decade or so of direction.

name: The Batman
review: 'The Batman' runs too long and could use a Pow, Bam, Whamm, Thwapp, Biff, and Zok, but this is a worthy superhero-detective story.

name: The Batman
review: Pattinson shares several (although too few) scenes with Kravitz, and their flirty chemistry enlivens every one of them.

name: The Batman
review: W hat’s wacky, woke and cast like an indie movie? Answer: this Batman reboot.

name: The Batman
review: This is only the beginning of a run of new Batman tales. The best thing is, it makes us want to see what happens next in this dark and angry place.

name: The Batman
review: I didn’t want a retread of the past or another origin story. Instead, I got something different.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves’ bold and enthralling The Batman marks a radical shift in direction, even from Christopher Nolan’s (comparatively) more grounded trilogy.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a standalone film that packs in all the ingredients for a delectably dark mindbender featuring the caped crusader, who is more human than ever.

name: The Batman
review: The film has some exceptional qualities. Its biggest issues are a bloated, unrefined script and a misguided final act.

name: The Batman
review: While the film's runtime leads to some bloat, Reeves' noir-influence The Batman stands out as the darkest and most visually inventive film starring the caped crusader.

name: The Batman
review: At three hours, THE BATMAN flew by. Warner Bros. will have a huge hit at the box office.

name: The Batman
review: I went into our screening expecting a bloated, too-heavy-on-the-action, overly violent, 175-minute ho-hum affair. THE BATMAN is none of these.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman both feels like a terrific achievement given the comic book saturated climate we live in, and a disappointment for it struggles to retain its identity and flex more than a few muscles.

name: The Batman
review: When the villain here says 'we're not so different', it actually carries weight. Pattinson's Batman is a despondent, disturbed, destructive presence.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is as good as a Batman movie has ever been, or possibly ever can be.

name: The Batman
review: [The Batman] is very long, relentlessly intense, murmured more often than spoken, and photographed, by Greig Fraser, with a glowering gorgeousness that must be seen to be felt. It’s also enthralling and tailored to our time.

name: The Batman
review: The Dark Knight continues to get darker and darker.

name: The Batman
review: Even with multiple sequels and spin-offs planned, there likely wont be another superhero movie that looks and feels like this for quite some time.

name: The Batman
review: Visually, Reeves’ film is spectacular, full of graphic tableaux and painterly touches. It never rains but it pours in his Gotham, a city mired in grey, abandoned by the sun.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves innovative makeover reimagines The Batman as a modern-day noir murder mystery, abandoning the action genre.

name: The Batman
review: Lacking in light and shade, and definitely overlong, The Batman is nonetheless a compelling and well-performed detective story that, yeah, happens to star a man in a batsuit.

name: The Batman
review: What carries the film are the sly intricacies of The Riddler’s misdeed... and the stunning set designs that range from the crowded, rain-slicked streets of Gotham to the gaping Batcave and an Edward Hopper-styled diner lit in green neon.

name: The Batman
review: A compelling hard-boiled mystery with a detective who just happens to wear a cape and cowl.

name: The Batman
review: That willingness to play with the pop art of it all, even as it’s very much doing a modern, grim-and-gritty blockbuster thing, is the truest joy of The Batman.

name: The Batman
review: Not that The Batman doesn't have its moments. It's just that it only has about 90 of them. I actually liked Robert Pattinson's smoldering broody routine (the first 20 times I saw it).

name: The Batman
review: The 'most anticipated film of the year' proves to have been worth the wait. Peeling a big black onion for almost three hours -- that's what you're getting with The Batman.

name: The Batman
review: The grittiest, gloomiest, and most pitch-black of the entire Caped Crusader canon, The Batman expands the compelling mythology with a neo-noir approach and very gothic Gotham look.

name: The Batman
review: There's an awful lot going on in "The Batman," maybe three movies worth. But Reeves is a capable storyteller, and the actors are good enough to keep the momentum going.

name: The Batman
review: Even as it may neglect or deviate from aspects of canon in minor ways, it pulls off a few essential new tricks. Perhaps the most essential? It's actually a movie about Batman.

name: The Batman
review: There is shuddering set-piece after set-piece with nothing innovative of note. Usually you do, at least, get (lame) jokes between the action sequences but this is so humourless and deadly serious you don’t even get that.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves made good on his promise to deliver a fierce and suspenseful Batman detective noir. The film is deliberately somber but not an entirely joyless affair, filled with stunning shots and thrilling action.

name: The Batman
review: One of the strongest elements of the film is how much new ground and fresh ideas permeate The Batman with little or no retread of the character history

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is an amazing world of Gotham. I want to see more from this world of Gotham.

name: The Batman
review: Dropsical with self-importance, and setting a bold new standard in joylessness...

name: The Batman
review: Reeves nails Batman's raison d'etre. The personal grievance, married to intimate violence, is satisfying.

name: The Batman
review: When Christopher Nolan was directing the Dark Knight trilogy, he tore into the Batman mythos with fervor, whereas Reeves just seems to be lackadaisically marinating in misery.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman -- the man, the film -- is so hard-boiled it's nigh on turned to stone. Alas, the writing is nowhere near strong enough to support this weight.

name: The Batman
review: This caped crusader is young, tortured, and frightening in a way that the character has never been.

name: The Batman
review: This very special episode of 'CSI: Gotham' tries to mimic all the moves from David Fincher's 'Seven,' but has a lot more in common with junky '90s knockoffs like 'The Bone Collector' and 'Kiss The Girls.'

name: The Batman
review: Relentless, dark, diabolic, and dynamic is Director Michael Reeves iteration with Robert Pattinson as a subdued Caped Crusader uncovering sordid clues from each characters past, and it works.

name: The Batman
review: A grim, gloomy, lugubrious, violent tale of vigilantism in a dystopian city mired in corruption and cynicism...There are plenty of praiseworthy elements in 'The Batman,' but as a whole it comes across as extremely depressing and self-indulgently labored.

name: The Batman
review: It’s the kind of superhero movie that, along with something like Spider-Verse, should be the standard-bearer for the genre going forward.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves finally gives us the first Batman movie ABOUT Batman, with no villain stealing his spotlight. A captivating film noir in which Gotham is filtered through the mood and aesthetic of Se7en.

name: The Batman
review: We've become so used to superhero movies with a few good sequences sandwiched between lackluster stuff that I wonder if moviegoers are ready for a beautifully constructed one with a beginning, middle and end. That would be "The Batman."

name: The Batman
review: With a sweeping soundtrack, actual detective work, and a surprising turn by a capable Pattinson leading a great cast, this Caped Crusader is learning to be better than he was yesterday in a city losing hope... a reconstruction of the superhero genre?

name: The Batman
review: Robert Pattison, following up performances in The Lighthouse (2019), Tenet (2020), and The Devil All the Time (2021), continues to expertly plumb the depths of men with nothing left but anger, vengeance, and violence

name: The Batman
review: The problem is that the movie, which hampers its value with a bloated running time of 176-minutes, never feels fresh, original, or essential.

name: The Batman
review: 176 minutes is a long time to go without laughs. And once you've settled into Matt Reeves universe of Gotham, you kind of brace yourself for whatever might be around the corner, its definitely not a joke.

name: The Batman
review: Batman is officially a buzz kill ...

name: The Batman
review: If previous Batman movies were a tad too upbeat, festive, short, and well-lit for you...

name: The Batman
review: Is this Batman THE Batman? Hard to know this early, but Im sure Reeves and Pattinson will be back for more. Theyve accomplished something special here, a Bat with a real brain.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a boiled down detective noir that scales back the theatrics of previous versions to concentrate on Bruce Waynes personal issues and gritty action scenes.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves cleverly subverts the obvious inklings of an origin story in exchange for a brooding and bleak bat-noir that reinvigorates the cape crusader.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman movie youve been waiting for.. Pattinson is great

name: The Batman
review: There is something triumphant about Reeves The Batman, and I do like where the film leaves the character before the screen fades to black. But so many aspects dont come together, each refusing to resonate no matter how much I wished otherwise.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is the first live action Noir Detective Batman narrative. An excellently paced ride with captivating shots, great action, an intense/terrify tone, where Collin immerses, Paul owns, Robert Slays, & Zoe delivers! An amazing superhero thriller!

name: The Batman
review: The latest iteration, The Batman, cranks the dial hard towards the darker end of the bat-spectrum and gives us a pretty cool (if unnecessarily overlong) take on the citizens of Gotham City.

name: The Batman
review: Robert Pattinsons Batman sinks his teeth into terminal misery in a dystopian wodge of a movie from Cloverfield director Matt Reeves.

name: The Batman
review: Though Matt Reeves The Batman is very entertaining ... its yet another in a long line of films about fractured heroes thats targeted at appealing to an older crowd at the expense of greater audience inclusivity.

name: The Batman
review: A solid story, great performances, and intriguing ideas about where to go from here. If you're demanding The Dark Knight from every Batman movie, you're going to be disappointed a lot.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves has managed to create perhaps the perfect Batman movie. Never before has it felt like the Gotham Knight has jumped right from the page to real life as he has here.

name: The Batman
review: If nothing else, The Batman helps shift Batman back to being a hero for the people.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves had a vision. He wanted to push the limits and do something we haven't seen done with Batman. He succeeded.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman works on many levels, from the actors to the action to its detective storyline. Well just have to wait and see if this version of Batman sticks around for a while.

name: The Batman
review: The filmmakers take a simple but somewhat ambitious approach to their storytelling here. They strip the character of anything unessential, redundant, or gimmicky.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman has more in common with Chinatown than The Avengers. Its a pulpy and violent serial killer story in the vein of Fincher thrillers like Seven and Zodiac.

name: The Batman
review: After gobs of Marvel Cinematic Universe cotton candy, it's refreshing to get a superhero movie with this much attitude, vision and thematic command.

name: The Batman
review: Again, so much of this is about shock value rather than anything actually scary, since The Batman is handcuffed by its family-friendly PG rating, the result being something like a Saw movie made for Disney+.

name: The Batman
review: This interpretation is po-faced to the extreme, but Reeves’s commitment to the material and Pattinson’s preternatural grumpiness in the role make The Batman sing -- though the ballad is undeniably emo.

name: The Batman
review: Its a rather highly-polished and extremely well-directed mainstream affair, but the ideas that Reeves infuses his film with, the substance, so to speak, is familiar and feels almost artificial.

name: The Batman
review: Giacchinos score is the standout aesthetic element of The Batman...

name: The Batman
review: Lacks a particular freshness key to making a zeitgeist-capturing phenomenon like the films from Tim Burton or Christopher Nolan, but the effort to bring in a certain kind of soulfulness amid a creepy mystery leads to some often stunning results.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a journey through the seedy underbelly of Gotham filled with epic action, unmatched cast chemistry, and maniacal villains. Everything that DC fans have wanted, and more.

name: The Batman
review: Pattinson is a perfect fit for the cowl and cape in this gritty, pacy and achingly stylish adventure

name: The Batman
review: Reeves is one of the more thoughtful blockbuster filmmakers out there, but here he never quite manages to transcend his influences.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves brings a real sense of motivation to his re-telling of the character and his why is clear. Even in its stumbles, The Batman doesn’t feel like a money grab.

name: The Batman
review: Yet another lugubrious, laboriously grim slog masquerading as a fun comic book movie.

name: The Batman
review: An ambitious and very dark thriller that takes its hero back to his noirish roots.

name: The Batman
review: The first Batman movie to feel not just dark but diseased, like something unclean teetering on the edge of an apocalypse. This is what makes it interesting and, in a number of places, very good.

name: The Batman
review: 'The Batman' soars with action and atmosphere.

name: The Batman
review: The most artistic Batman movie ever made...Pattinson leaves his mark on the Bat-legacy as a "broken" Bruce Wayne...but this is another case of a director's ambition getting in the way of his own work...demanding so much patience without actual payoff.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is, quite simply, a ponderous bore.

name: The Batman
review: Semi-novel spin on the done-to-death Dark Knight routine ("What if Bruce Wayne was kind of BAD at being Batman at first?") and welcome attempts to address uglier aspects of the vigilante fantasy get overwhelmed by an overplotted script franchise demands.

name: The Batman
review: It takes nearly three hours for The Batman to tell its story and that story, while familiar, is the Batman story I've been waiting for my whole life.

name: The Batman
review: This is a moody, atmospheric and at times genuinely creepy flick, with some top shelf performances and a couple of surprising and quite subversive moments in the final act.

name: The Batman
review: Creating enough points of difference to distinguish itself from the successful Christopher Nolan-helmed Batman trilogy, The Batman is dark, interesting and a little frustrating.

name: The Batman
review: Echoes with the doubled resonance of the best myths, at once a thrilling adventure and a cautionary tale.

name: The Batman
review: This Batman, played by Robert Pattinson, is our goth Bruce Wayne, more disaffected youth than playboy billionaire, and that allows Reeves, as a director, to play with all kinds of grimy imagery, and as a writer, to grapple with the real function of Batman

name: The Batman
review: At a time when many comic book franchises are seeking to go bigger, with cosmic beings and multiverses, The Batman’s down-to-earth approach offers a welcome reprieve.

name: The Batman
review: For those of you who wondered if another reboot could find itself an audience after Christopher Nolan did such a fine job with his trilogy, please wonder no more.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a needless collage of not only better movies, but more egregiously of better Batman movies as director/co-writer Matt Reeves and co-writer Peter Craig create an utterly inferior and infuriating vision of the Dark Knight.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves excellent new film introduces us to the fourth live-action cinematic incarnation of the Dark Knight.

name: The Batman
review: I can’t say I had a good time, but I did end up somewhere I didn’t expect to be: looking forward to the next chapter.

name: The Batman
review: Even the doubters wondering if there’s anything more to say about Batman will find this reboot in a league of its own, even if Christopher Nolan’s trilogy remains hard to beat.

name: The Batman
review: Robert Pattinson puts an emo spin on the Worlds Greatest Detective in gritty, engrossing thriller "The Batman."

name: The Batman
review: This is a Batman movie that really embraces something the comics have done, which is Batman is the true identity and Bruce Wayne is a facade.

name: The Batman
review: Nolan’s legacy still can’t be shaken off. But the tweaks are something.

name: The Batman
review: Director Matt Reeves and brooding star Robert Pattinson see the Caped Crusader as more film-noir detective than comic-book hero in their mesmerizing mindbender that aims high even when it misses the mark. Its a grenade of pure cinema ready to blow.

name: The Batman
review: 'The Batman' fires on all cylinders and commits to its darkest impulses without losing sight of the light at the core of its protagonist.

name: The Batman
review: We've seen the man become the bat plenty of times. In Matt Reeves The Batman, we see the bat become a man again.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is its own, mostly very effective, strain of gorgeous and thoughtful blockbuster filmmaking.

name: The Batman
review: Visually speaking, this is where The Batman excels the most. Matt Reeves has certainly gone all out to make his film looks meticulous with the help of Greig Frasers stunning nighttime cinematography.

name: The Batman
review: I don’t know if we needed “The Batman,” but Reeves and company certainly elevated it.

name: The Batman
review: Once your ears get attuned, and your eyes too, for that matter, since daylight hardly ever encroaches, there is plenty to relish in The Batman.

name: The Batman
review: While it could be cut by at least 45 minutes, there’s plenty of ‘Kapow!’ to keep audiences entertained in this scary and sadistic trip to Gotham city.

name: The Batman
review: Underlit and overblown is a formidable combination, though not necessarily in the way Reeves intends.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a thrilling, cerebral drama that gives us one of the most realistic portrayals of the caped crusader to date.

name: The Batman
review: Puts sthe Batman characters into a forgettable, B-minus serial killer thriller, one with a needlessly convoluted plot, too many characters, unconvincing twists, and a terrible villain.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is an OK film that thinks its excellent. It's also so inspired by Fincher's two exceptional pictures about serial killers that I'm surprised it didn't call itself The Ba7man. (Full review in Portuguese.)

name: The Batman
review: It's good but not great, with the emphasis on drama and a pretty complicated plot that is involving, decidedly heavy and, to be frank, not all that exciting. Director Matt Reeves takes his time with the pacing that is big on character, short on action.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves' contribution to the latest caped crusader tale is hypnotic with dazzlingly dark visuals and a Se7en/The Crow inspired detective story. It's not as focused as the Nolan trilogy, but boasts a strong start for future Batman detective stories.

name: The Batman
review: It all adds up to an epic vision of an age-old tale

name: The Batman
review: Here, Batmans default state is pure misery, and while that may be something many viewers can empathise with, this is a Batman few would want to be.

name: The Batman
review: A magnificently dark vision that resets expectations about the character and his place in the world.

name: The Batman
review: This is an excellent first chapter in what I hope will be several more to come.

name: The Batman
review: Despite its flaws... Reeves and Pattinson do offer something new and quite exciting with their interpretation of the DC superhero. Die-hard fans will have plenty to chew over, while more casual viewers can admire the exceptional cast and the characters.

name: The Batman
review: Even with missteps, The Batman is an impressive movie. It’s not the rousing, over-the-top exciting superhero version of the character we remember from Tim Burton or Christopher Nolan, but it shouldn’t be. This is Matt Reeves' Batman.

name: The Batman
review: What it does do, quite effectively, is tell a solid Batman story, with the most soulful and vulnerable Batman to ever grace the big screen. And that much, at least, is new.

name: The Batman
review: Not your typical superhero film, The Batman is dark in all aspects. Kudos to Reeves for a different stylization and noir, but the story lacks in originality. Still not kid friendly.

name: The Batman
review: Make no mistake, this iteration is here to stay and is only getting started with reminding moviegoers just how phenomenal unadulterated comic book stories can be on the big screen.

name: The Batman
review: It didn't have to be nearly three hours, and the disaster-film last act comes right out of the blue. But there's a film noir soul in this one somewhere.

name: The Batman
review: In Matt Reeves confident hands, everything is breathtakingly alive and new.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman doesn't quite rise above its ubiquitous genre in the way that it maybe hopes to, but when it stays street level it's a tantalizingly creepy mystery, anchored by Robert Pattinson's eerie take on the Caped Crusader.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves is aiming for a film noir-like Batman story, but the Dark Knight, supposedly the worlds greatest detective, does very little detecting of his own  mostly relying on others to unearth clues and pass them on to him.

name: The Batman
review: What makes this film most interesting is the way Bruce Wayne struggles to justify the consequences that The Batman has had on Gotham, and the surprising side of hero worship.

name: The Batman
review: I left it still humming that Nirvana song and wondering what this messed-up new Bruce Wayne, cape streaming moodily behind him as he rode away on his bat-motorcycle, would get up to next.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman emerges from a movie universe, now becoming ubiquitous, where a phony funereal worldview is the only thing that can confer depth.

name: The Batman
review: There's a powerful tone and atmosphere created here, one drenched in a pulpy and occasionally terrifying exploration of this iconic character and those that cross him. The Batman is a bold and brilliant examination of a young Dark Knight.

name: The Batman
review: I wish they had taken the time to develop Bruce as a real person with feelings and emotions. Even in a dark and brooding film noir, there still should be moments where the characters breathe and connect.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is Matt Reeves most ambitious film yet. The jump from a tense detective story to thrilling action to melancholic romance to disaster film is a massive feat, but yes, Reeves has managed to pick up Nolans mantle where others have failed before.

name: The Batman
review: Its challenging to sit with this level of moody darkness for so long, but what an unforgettable take on one of the DCEUs most popular characters.

name: The Batman
review: "The Batman" certainly mirrors the dismal state of the world today. Any breaks from that dreariness will have to come at a different bat time on a different bat channel.

name: The Batman
review: The fact the titular character can't solve a series of simple clues is one of the many problems with this flawed but intriguing take on the pop culture icon.

name: The Batman
review: The reality is that there is probably nothing truly novel to be done with Batman at this point... Try as Reeves and his co-screenwriter Peter Craig might, they can’t squeeze much higher-meaning blood out of a fatally depleted stone.

name: The Batman
review: Pattinson and Kravitz make for a compelling Bat and Cat while Dano's Riddler terrifies. The Batman is an ambitious, scorching thriller that brings the hero's detective side into the light. Its third act reaches staggering, stunning highs

name: The Batman
review: Scaling down beautifully from the silly operatics of the DCEU, Matt Reeves has crafted a movie which stands cape-to-cape with The Dark Knight, perhaps even surpassing it as a forensic study of Gotham’s most famous protector.

name: The Batman
review: While very much beholden to Nolan's grounded trilogy, Matt Reeves pulls from several comic and cinematic influences to give THE BATMAN a flavor all its own.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is such a grandiose cinematic achievement, crafted with a filmmakers skill and Reeves daring to do it his own way.

name: The Batman
review: The riddles of The Riddler, with their dime-store greeting-card histrionics, are about as frightening as a frown drawn on a detached baby-doll-head. Truly cornball stuff

name: The Batman
review: Richly layered in dark intrigue, The Batman takes viewers deeper into Batman/Bruce Wayne's mind than previous Batman films have ever ventured. This top-notch superhero film makes pointed social commentaries along with plenty of stunning action sequences.

name: The Batman
review: More of a detective mystery than previous Bat-flicks, borrowing in particular from David Fincher's serial killer chillers Seven and Zodiac... Most of all, though, The Batman is a horror movie.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves understands he can't rewrite the status quo on the worlds most bankable hero, but he can try to tweak the formula and audiences expectations. For better or worse, that's something his "The Batman" does incredibly well.

name: The Batman
review: Impossibly entertaining and ultimately very compelling.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a competently-constructed film with its most significant flaw being it's too darned serious. That grim one-note approach for two hours would be tough. At three hours it gets to be a bit much.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves’ The Batman is an impressive exploration of the character’s Year Two, a visually stunning, violent and believably gritty detective film to please the purists and introduce casual fans to a different version of the Bat.

name: The Batman
review: “The Batman” is impressively made. The acting is first rate, and the chemistry between Pattinson and Kravitz is magnetic. It’s meant to be an important statement. It’s just not a lot of, you know, fun.

name: The Batman
review: I’m as surprised as anyone to say that, after watching Pattinson in action, I’m calling on the industry to bring on all its many Batmen, Batwomen, Batbats. Keep ‘em coming hot and ready until we choke on a cowl.

name: The Batman
review: Within the confines of its PG-13 rating, The Batman is much more unnerving than previous Batman installments ... The trouble is grafting a somber pastiche onto a superhero base coat can sometimes feel more exhausting than rewarding.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves throws us back into Gotham with a New and Refreshing take on the Caped Crusader which taps into the Detective aspect of the character that has been long looked over! Robert Pattinson and Paul Dano shine.

name: The Batman
review: Imagine if David Fincher made a Batman movie but it was censored to air on televisions at Walmart.

name: The Batman
review: The mix of great and subpar makes it a challenge for me, but there is more good than bad...barely. Plus points for reminding me of The Crow.

name: The Batman
review: With his labyrinthine plotting and tragically human ensemble of characters, Reeves has crafted a richly realized Gotham City where there may be heroes and villains, but no one is innocent.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a gritty stylized police procedural that suffers from some pacing issues, but offers a fresh standalone take on the Batman mythos.

name: The Batman
review: This is high art at the intersection of blockbuster entertainment. If ever a superhero movie were to be considered for big awards, 'The Batman' is it. See it soar.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman ushers the Gotham crime fighter out of the shadows, to bring justice into a broken world, in this epic new installment. This is undoubtedly the best Batman yet.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a must-see edge-of-your-seat addition to the catalog of Batman films.

name: The Batman
review: I'll take 2 hours plus of the best Batman movie ever made with a little extra fat. I'll take that deal anytime.

name: The Batman
review: Batman nearly dissolves into the night, overwhelmed by and acquiescent to his films own noirish ambitions.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves' The Batman is an invigorating balm for superhero fatigue.

name: The Batman
review: The performances are as complex as the colour palette (ie not very).

name: The Batman
review: What works about The Batman is Reeves and cowriter Peter Craig’s ability to weave suspense in with characters we know from the world of Gotham and make them all feel like a cohesive unit.

name: The Batman
review: The darkness of The Batman is somehow both richly textured and flimsy–a painting done up on newsprint.

name: The Batman
review: The film succeeds as both a narrative and visual product.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a very good Batman film. To think of it as anything more only leads to delusion or disappointment.

name: The Batman
review: That rare beast: a neatly self-contained contemporary blockbuster. Still too long though.

name: The Batman
review: From start to finish, “The Batman” is mostly just a collection of bad ideas.

name: The Batman
review: Depressing, dark and endless. I don’t know about you, but this particular time in history does not seem like the moment for a movie that will leave you a) miserable and b) wondering why nobody in Gotham City seems to have heard of light bulbs.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman feels like a turning point for the Caped Crusader.

name: The Batman
review: There’s an unshakable feeling here of “What’s the point?” Not to mention the nearly three-hour length. Holy runtime!

name: The Batman
review: Though not a totally radical refit of the Nolan/Snyder era, it establishes a Gotham City we would keenly want a return visit to.

name: The Batman
review: The first 2/3rds of the movie are so phenomenal, it doesn't matter that the final act is weak. Matt Reeves delivers the best Batman movie to date, and Robert Pattinson the best Batman. Mind-blowingly good.

name: The Batman
review: To create a Batman film able to compete with  or maybe even eclipse  Christopher Nolans Dark Knight trilogy takes some doing. Matt Reeves has done that with The Batman.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves loves these dead-end apocalyptic environments, and delights in tales that toy with the moral calculus of typical hero narratives. He has given us a Batman that he himself can believe in, not to mention a Batman that feels right for our times.

name: The Batman
review: It falls on Pattinson's leather-cased Batman to be the hero we need, or deserve.

name: The Batman
review: It’s a movie of alternately promising and frustrating half-measures, in which Reeves’ shrewd storytelling instincts and the usual franchise-filmmaking imperatives repeatedly fight to a draw.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves has delivered The Batman we have earned. Bleak, yet hopeful, true to its origins while being very much of our times. And wait till you see that car chase!

name: The Batman
review: A gripping, grimy and sensational street-level detective story, the Dark Knight’s triumphant return is exactly the fresh start needed after a decade of diminishing returns.

name: The Batman
review: If dark, rain-soaked superhero flick sounds done to death, this latest Batman may not be for you.

name: The Batman
review: As a reboot, The Batman is a very good re-introduction of the Batman movie franchise, but one that feels like a victim of circumstance.

name: The Batman
review: Director Matt Reeves delivers a gritty action thriller reminiscent of "Se7en" and "Zodiac" that finally makes "the world's greatest detective" deserving of the title.

name: The Batman
review: As grim as the Burton, Nolan and Snyder films were, Reeves and his team have fashioned their own distinctive and stylish variety of grimness, and they commit to it for three whole hours. Frankly, it's amazing that they got away with it.

name: The Batman
review: Loved every single aspect of this film; the cinematography, that score!!, performances and the story. Easily one of the BEST Batman iterations.

name: The Batman
review: A combination of Pattinsons faultless delivery and an engaging storyline from Reeves and Craig give this new interpretation the edge over Zack Snyders overly stylised representation of the DC hero. I just wish it had been slightly shorter.

name: The Batman
review: Inevitably, night falls on the latest Batman iteration with the cloudy sense that – of course – nothing has really been at stake. A classy turn from Pattinson, however, as the crime fighter with an injured soul.

name: The Batman
review: Robert Pattinson is a perfect fit for the cowl, but this bloated effort lacks focus.

name: The Batman
review: Director Matt Reeves’ ambitious and excellently crafted The Batman more than justifies its existence as a world-building wonder that slathers a realistic grime across its Gotham City.

name: The Batman
review: A superhero-infused take on the noir genre, with Robert Pattinson diving deep into the Dark Knights state of mind.

name: The Batman
review: A masterful and heady introspection on vigilantism, told with foreboding grit and intensity atypical of the genre.

name: The Batman
review: The film sounds even better, thanks to a remarkable Michael Giacchino score that alternates minimalist strums and imperial marches; it’s somehow in the same league as the operatic themes Danny Elfman once lent the franchise.

name: The Batman
review: Epic

name: The Batman
review: This epic (nearly three-hour) new chapter in the evolution of the superhero is a new milestone for Pattinson, ranking among the best Batman movies and truly marking his re-entry into the big-ticket, movie mainstream.

name: The Batman
review: Gotham's never been grimmer than in R-Batz's moody but mesmerising detective thriller

name: The Batman
review: At its best, The Batman is a helluva tough-guy yarn -- an entertaining pulp-fiction epic under the guise of sure-thing blockbuster. At its worst, it’s the cinematic equivalent of a mixtape.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is an epic masterpiece.

name: The Batman
review: A Caped Crusader adventure with a purpose thankfully more meaningful than taking funny-book characters seriously for a fast buck.

name: The Batman
review: A towering achievement... Its exactly what the Batman franchise needed to be... This is the Batman movie weve been waiting for.

name: The Batman
review: Dark, grungy & hugely atmospheric, Matt Reeves The Batman is potentially the most true to the DCs greatest detective yet. This is a gripping noir-esque detective tale.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a dark, chilling, and compelling interpretation of Batman and Gotham's corrupt underbelly.

name: The Batman
review: “The Batman” is darkly dour stuff — potent but erratic.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is frustratingly safe, a movie full of potential for more and settling for less. It preaches to the choir, reinforcing the same ideas trodden over and over again across five movies.

name: The Batman
review: A Gothic opera version of the Batman legend, full of dark portents with Robert Pattinson as less ego-driven version of the character. A bit long and drags around the two-hour mark, but the first half and finale more than make up for it.

name: The Batman
review: A sprawling and sinuous urban detective thriller, with the intricately unhinged red-wool-on-corkboard plotting of classic film noir.

name: The Batman
review: Arguably the moodiest and most intense the character has ever been portrayed in live-action, 'The Batman' is a strong debut for Robert Pattinson in the cowl and more than lives up to the legacy of the character.

name: The Batman
review: The reward for such an extreme run time is full immersion in the mental health war that is the Batman experience, with Reeves nailing the brutality and awakening of this complicated dark knight.

name: The Batman
review: A sprawling, complex neo-noir thriller that shares more in common with the filmography of David Fincher than with most other superhero movies. Matt Reeves delivers an experience thats unpredictable, unexpected  and perhaps even definitive.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a reinvention of the iconic vigilante with a powerhouse cast at the forefront, providing a masterclass of visual storytelling at the hands of Matt Reeves. I could've watched five hours of this.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is soggy, gloomy, dank, rank, filthy, and forbidding. And so I really liked it. It’s not quite as searing or unsettling as Joker, but it pushes further in that direction than any big-budget comic-book movie yet.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves delivers a spectacularly striking, remarkable vision, ringing as an echo of previous Batman-centered features, reverberating long after the end credits finish their scroll.

name: The Batman
review: It’s a soulful nocturne of corruption and chaos, and as much as I longed for a few more glimmers of humor, at no point during the hefty three-hour run time did my attention wander.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves has taken on the challenge of producing a fresh take for this comic book icon as well and comes up with the novel twist of turning it into a detective story.

name: The Batman
review: Zo Kravitz entered the scene, and two minutes into her first sequence I was already thinking: Couldnt this have been The Catwoman instead of The Batman?

name: The Batman
review: With exhilarating action scenes, a layered story & poignant, in-depth characterization, The Batman is a worthy addition to the live-action DC slate.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a gripping, gorgeous, and, at times, genuinely scary psychological crime thriller that gives Bruce Wayne the grounded detective story he deserves.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman features terrible pacing, a much too long runtime, a story that seems to think it's being original while it isn't, and a combination of a score and cinematography that leads to an uncomfortable viewing experience.

name: The Batman
review: This isnt quite like any previous version of Batman, and thats a good thing; Reeves and Pattinson have fashioned a grim, desperate super-hero thats largely in line with todays hardscrabble times.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves has outdone Christopher Nolan in presenting a realistic take on the source material without appearing ashamed of its comic book origins. It is the most like a "real movie" any comic book adaptation has felt in ages.

name: The Batman
review: The Matt Reeves directed The Batman is almost oppressive. The Batman creates an unsettling world that keeps the audience on edge as Batman navigates an overwhelming Gotham City one clue at a time.

name: The Batman
review: That it doesn’t come off as a parody of a parody is a testament to both the holistic nature of Reeves’ vision and the eagerness with which Pattinson buys into it.

name: The Batman
review: While so many comic book movies feel like variations on the same ideas, and the same formal execution of them, Reeves has made something distinct and fully realized.

name: The Batman
review: A movie that wants to be shrouded in mystery, but its principle one is how a film can create such a compelling Batman while seeming so disinterested in the character.

name: The Batman
review: Registers among the best of the genre, even if — or more aptly, because — what makes the film so great is its willingness to dismantle and interrogate the very concept of superheroes.

name: The Batman
review: A less gripping redo of previous Batman films and television shows, with a lethargic pace that drains the film of tension and suspense.

name: The Batman
review: As new chapters go, it's a strong beginning; if only it had known when to end.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves The Batman should tell audiences that other superhero movies are possible, and yet more, they can be exist outside the formulaic tentpoles filling theaters today.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is an utterly mesmerizing detective story with electrifying execution.

name: The Batman
review: It seems we get the Batman movie for our times And so now, in 2022, we get the darkest Batman yet, one that pictures a Gotham City so drenched in corruption, Bruce Wayne (Robert Pattinson) finds himself looking into his own family history.

name: The Batman
review: A slow-burn noir detective thriller, 'The Batman' may not be the film you're anticipating, but it just might be precisely what this franchise needs.

name: The Batman
review: Batman works in the shadows, and the intensity of Reeves action sequences work well there over three hours that never feel bloated or unnecessary.

name: The Batman
review: This isnt just a new take on a popular comic book character, its a fully realized vision for a world. One like weve never gotten before.

name: The Batman
review: Reeves weaves a complex narrative that forces the audience to pay attention and helps his cause when, by the time Kyle appears, that attention shakes a bit.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is the stellar start of a new era of the cinema character. Something that works for the most diehard DC comics fans and those who love the character in the movies. Its an excellent time for film.

name: The Batman
review: 'The Batman' is a captivating take on the franchise and is in a league of its own. The pacing is consistent throughout its nearly 3-hour long running time, and the ending leaves you craving for more.

name: The Batman
review: This riveting take on Batman is, refreshingly, more of a detective story than an action spectacle -- although it does offer that element, too, as well as complex characters and relevant themes.

name: The Batman
review: This just might be for diehard fans alone; less faithful viewers will surely wonder what has happened to all of the standard exhilaration and the general sense of fun.

name: The Batman
review: An epic crime saga which more than justifies its epic length, "The Batman" aspires to a grandeur few of its superhero-cinema contemporaries can match.

name: The Batman
review: Paul Danos incredible performance as The Riddler will send a chill down your spine.

name: The Batman
review: This is the Batman that Ive always wanted to see since I was a boy, and a Batman for the ages.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman triumphs as a reinvention of one of cinema's most enduring comic book heroes. Matt Reeves has crafted a bleak, brutal new vision of Gotham City and its tormented protector.

name: The Batman
review: "The Batman" plays brilliantly like a murder horror mystery for 2h15, and then like a boring superhero movie for the last 30m. Thankfully the great vastly overwhelms the choppy.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves takes Batman on a dark knight of the soul and rediscovers a hero.

name: The Batman
review: In terms of tone and scope and storyline, Matt Reeves’ reboot of the ever-fruitful franchise is more of a film noir than a fable about fantastic flying creatures, more Zodiac and Seven than Guardians of the Galaxy or Eternals.

name: The Batman
review: While The Batman is far from the best or most consistent cinematic outing for the caped crusader, the film is still undeniably strong with one of the more poignant reflections seen regarding the character and his impact.

name: The Batman
review: The material here isnt exactly Agatha Christie, but its refreshing to see a superhero film in which the characters take time to think the plot through and in which the plot is worth thinking about.

name: The Batman
review: "The Batman is a darker knight than ever before. Reeves movie, wholly entertaining and full of surprises, features Twilight star Robert Pattinson as the youngest Bruce Wayne ever.

name: The Batman
review: The most well thought-through outing for the caped crusader since Christopher Nolans durable The Dark Knight from 2008.

name: The Batman
review: This is an incredibly well-made film. The score is otherworldly, the action scenes are perfectly crafted, and it captures tone better than most DC movies.

name: The Batman
review: The harsh, grimy atmosphere that Matt Reeves has created leans further in to the noirish disposition his narrative delights in entertaining, with his dangerous, violently-minded Gotham serving as the perfect hunting ground for Pattinsons Batman

name: The Batman
review: Reeves has made the best Batman film since The Dark Knight, with a captivating and rich world that reinvigorates characters weve already seen on screen over and over again.

name: The Batman
review: What impresses most about The Batman is its deep well of interiority, the way it uses the innately mythic nature of comic book storytelling to zero in on the wants and needs of its characters.

name: The Batman
review: Do we really need yet another Batman reboot? The answer, after watching Matt Reeves' tremendous The Batman, is apparently a resounding yes.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman presents us truly for the first time with a cinematic interpretation of The Worlds Greatest Detective. This version of the character is as much a sleuth as a superhero. Its a new feel for this type of film, giving it an added weight.

name: The Batman
review: A spectacular, thrilling, and impressive interpretation of the character with a stirring story to tell.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves has delivered a hypnotic and thrilling adventure, helped by his stellar cast and many smart decisions along the way. This Batman may share ideas and themes with its cinematic forebears but it is its own fearsome, extraordinary beast.

name: The Batman
review: It's intense, brutal, dark, gloomy, and very much a neo-noir offering. A few issues aside, this delivers on most aspects and Pattinson is excellent as the Caped Crusader - I thought it was great.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a tour de force cinematic experience that will engulf you utterly.  Raise your expectations to the stratosphere.  The Batman is stupefyingly awesome.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is epic. Pattinsons grasp of this character is apparent from the first scene, and Reeves builds a layered mystery around him. Giacchinos masterful score cements this as one of the best Batman movies ever.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is a dark and gritty detective noir and as good as origin stories get.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is really just a series of well-made, nice-to-look at vignettes that just barely connect to each other or lead into each other with the energy and propulsion audiences crave from big-budget action spectacle movies at this level.

name: The Batman
review: I appreciated Reeves ambitions and his willingness to do something that wasnt just more of the same old Batman.

name: The Batman
review: ...a heart pounding action and spectacle that adds up to one of the best comic book action movies weve gotten in the last two decades.

name: The Batman
review: One of the greatest Batman stories ever told on film. Full review in Spanish

name: The Batman
review: Robert Pattinson gives a restrained, yet sometimes unbridled and explosive performance as Batman.

name: The Batman
review: A dull and dreary rehash of better bat-films

name: The Batman
review: An epic piece of film mastery that transcends its comic book origins, making it a movie that should elevate Matt Reeves to his well-deserved visionary status.

name: The Batman
review: But what is vengeance but an endless cycle of violence? This is where Reeves and co-writer Peter Craig ("The Town") find their voice, their unique perspective on The Bat, creating "The Batman" for a new generation.

name: The Batman
review: Direction and Pattinsons interpretation make this Batman movie one that will appeal to the masses.

name: The Batman
review: An ultra-dark crime and corruption story, both visually and thematically. Full review in French

name: The Batman
review: Delivering the definitive take on the Worlds Greatest Detective, The Batman is a sweeping, cinematic masterpiece thats both DCs best film and one of the most captivating, relentless, and unforgettable comic book movies ever made.

name: The Batman
review: Batman (1989) walked so The Dark Knight could run, and now The Batman flies its way into the pantheon of comic book film transcendence.

name: The Batman
review: he Batman is an enthralling, chilling and fresh new take on the iconic DC hero that'll leave you desperate for another visit to this impeccably-crafted world.

name: The Batman
review: "The Batman" has the teeth to impress any of the opposition and eat their hearts out in the process.

name: The Batman
review: Matt Reeves delivers a standout Batman movie. It's a dark, alluring mystery that digs deep into Bruce Wayne's trauma, how it's shaped him and how he's choosing to move forward.

name: The Batman
review: The film stands apart for thoughtfully suggesting that Batman might actually one day make Gotham a better place, and not merely a safer one.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman brings the Caped Crusader back to Earth for a coming-of-age procedural delivering real thrills, a terrifically creepy villain, and a fresh start for a classic hero.

name: The Batman
review: The Batman is bold, brutal and oozes in gothic aesthetic. In a superhero movie climate where cameos and CGI-heavy sequences are commonplace, Matt Reeves answers back with cinema. Simply one of the best DC films of all time.

name: The Batman
review: While it may go on a bit too long, it provides a gripping detective story and fleshed out Gotham which compliments the other great Batman films nicely.

name: The Batman
review: While retaining requisite elements of blockbuster action cinema...decidedly shifts the focus to pulp fiction...The Batman feels more like a Batman story than a Batman movie, and that's an achievement in itself.

name: Happening
review: [Never] gives into the powerful didactic or melodramatic forces … with director Audrey Diwan retaining a measured, unflinching focus. That carries over into [Anamaria] Vartolomei's understated performance.

name: Happening
review: Happening is a movie that dispenses with the pleasantries of deep side characters or even growth for its lead role. It’s a vivid, unsettling depiction of abortion in a place and time, sordidly familiar right now...

name: Happening
review: Artful and socially resonant, Happening is one of the most poignant and moving films of the year.

name: Happening
review: A film of international importance, told with empathy, sincerity and anger.

name: Happening
review: Vartolmei delivers a remarkable performance, underplaying Anne’s emotional responses in a way that makes them register all the more strongly on the viewer.

name: Happening
review: Happening unsubtly and successfully acts as a reminder of the importance of abortion rights at a moment when reactionary creeps the world over are pushing back.

name: Happening
review: Happening plays at a surprisingly quick pace, wrapping us up in the suffocating, terrifying totality of the situation. It's only Diwan’s second film, but it feels like veteran work -- so engrossing, so carnal, so full of empathy that it hurts to look at.

name: Happening
review: The most-need-to-be-seen feature of the year . . . . In this grippingly honest, no-holds-barred film, a 23-year-old lit student seeks an abortion in 1963 France, an act for which she, her doctor, and anyone else who aids her can be sent to prison.

name: Happening
review: When Diwan has to choose between reckoning the protagonist or impacting the audience, she chooses the latter. And for a few minutes, everything falls apart... almost impeccable otherwise. Almost. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Happening
review: It’s brutal in spots, but especially vital to watch right now.

name: Happening
review: the film, calibrated in passing weeks, closely tracks Anne’s efforts – greatly circumscribed and increasingly desperate – to choose her own future.

name: Happening
review: No, it's not an upbeat subject. But perhaps now, with Roe overturned and people experiencing the consequences of abortion bans, it's time to watch this movie.

name: Happening
review: Diwan relies on a raw and daring mise-en-scène, and avoids becoming a pamphlet. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Happening
review: Happening is an honest, harrowing, frighteningly timely, moving, and powerful experience.

name: Happening
review: Anamaria Vartolomei’s lead performance is necessarily and intensely physical—and subject to some harrowing bodily choreography in the homestretch—but what binds us to her is a sense of the perceptive, gifted writer trapped behind weary, terrified eyes.

name: Happening
review: Happening presenta con firmeza cómo la experiencia traumática no radica en el acto del aborto en sí, sino en el terror que genera un embarazo forzado por falta de apoyo médico adecuado.

name: Happening
review: Happening is haunting and shattering, immaculately crafted, unwavering in its honesty, and as confronting as it needs to be, and it wields all of the above with passion and purpose.

name: Happening
review: One of the most talked-about movies from this year’s Sundance Film Festival is about to get a whole lot more attention.

name: Happening
review: Vartolomei gives a wonderfully nuanced performance, showcasing the emotional turmoil and exhaustion Anne goes through by herself...

name: Happening
review: A few times I had to look away from the screen, even if the theater was empty. It moved me. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Happening
review: Not a moment feels didactic, and Anne never seems like a case study. Instead, the film thrums with the practical resolve of a young woman desperate to begin her own life before creating another.

name: Happening
review: A stunning, realist and visceral achievement.

name: Happening
review: Happening brings compassion to a story many women have faced, and many have been forced to endure.

name: Happening
review: There’s the constant sense of someone poised, ready to run, alert and frightened. But since the battle she is facing is an unwanted pregnancy, there is no possibility of physically removing herself from the situation.

name: Happening
review: Based on a true story, the realistic drama Happening shows without judgment what a college student in 1963 France experienced when she wanted to terminate an unplanned pregnancy, at a time when abortion was illegal in France.

name: Happening
review: Anne’s journey nears its end with one of the most unsettling scenes a movie is likely to produce this year. It graphically depicts what pro-abortion rights advocates say with regularity: That laws to ban abortions will only outlaw medically safe ones.

name: Happening
review: Couldn’t be more harrowing -- or timely -- as it unflinchingly confronts a woman’s right to choose.

name: Happening
review: With Happening, Diwan has crafted a horror story that is becoming a haunting and very real possibility.

name: Happening
review: This is a film, about abortion, that’s arriving with impeccable timing.

name: Happening
review: Happening is a drama in the classic French screen idiom of eschewing tonal hyperbole and over-explicit messaging in favor of a more low-key, naturalistic approach. But the rising panic Anne struggles to suppress from public view is palpable, nonetheless.

name: Happening
review: Carefully captures the nightmare that befalls the protagonist, with images that combine intimacy and everyday life while the drama -along with [her] gestation- grows. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Happening
review: At the moment there is not a more important and more challenging piece of cinema at the theaters than Happening.

name: Happening
review:
Taking place in 1963, its harrowing story feels immediate and personal – and relevant.
Tightly shot, with an unflinching intimacy that showcases Romanian-born actress Anamaria Vartolomei’s brave performance...

name: Happening
review: A shocking drama deftly handling its plot, with a wonderful performance by Vartolomei, combining vulnerability and strength. One of the most powerful experiences I've ever had in a movie theater. Full review in Spanish.

name: Happening
review: Still, Happening deserves to be assessed on its own merits, rather than how it lands in proximity to U.S. politics.

name: Happening
review: Happening tackles the difficult subject of illegal abortion in 1960’s France with restraint and compassion.

name: Happening
review: Despite its decades-ago setting, Happening has never been more relevant, particularly for audiences in America. Diwan’s drama serves as a warning of what people may experience if Roe is overturned.

name: Happening
review: The story of "Happening" is what happens in secret when the right to choose is eliminated. The how of "Happening" is that none of this should be secret.

name: Happening
review: The no-holds-barred approach to the abortion procedure and its aftermath is the kind of interpretation of real life that great cinema does best.

name: Happening
review: It directly captures the crippling barbarism of a system that cares not a bit about human beings, as well as men whose limited vision allows them to only see Anne in one of two ways.

name: Happening
review: Happening goes further as a beautiful coming-of-age story, where Anne’s long pursuit to end the pregnancy is also one of self-discovery.

name: Happening
review: Happening is both powerful and, in this fraught moment, necessary.

name: Happening
review: Films don't get any more timely than this French drama about an unwanted pregnancy. Anamaria Vartolomei is a revelation.

name: Happening
review: Diwan's film seems to explore several genres.  A tick-tock thriller, an espionage picture, and a horror show, but most of all, this distressing abortion drama feels contemporary, even though it’s set almost 60 years in the past.  A must-see!

name: Happening
review: There’s nothing cautionary about this brutal, deeply empathetic movie; it is a horror film rooted in everyday reality.

name: Happening
review: Happening isn't particularly political, at least not in the sense that it proffers a particular agenda. It's a deeply personal episode from a particular life told in a straightforward manner without a lot of moralizing.

name: Happening
review: Happening is a beautifully shot film, and Vartolomei gives a fantastic performance of a woman unaware of where to turn, or to whom.

name: Happening
review: More thoughtful and visually sophisticated than what Hollywood tends to produce, Diwan’s film nevertheless has few ideas of its own—a disappointment, considering the conceptual experimentation (and knotty objectives) of the source novel.

name: Happening
review: “Happening” is a nightmarish exploration of a controversial subject.

name: Happening
review: Director Diwan...gives her young star, Anamaria Vartolomei, plenty of running room to create a stunning character study about a strong-willed young woman who risks prison to try to control her own fate and body.

name: Happening
review: Whether you condone this film or condemn it, “Happening” presents a brutal reality.

name: Happening
review: Happening is an introduction to an intriguing new director, but as the abortion debate consumes our nation once again, it’s also much more than that.

name: Happening
review: Heartfelt, heartbreaking, heart wrenching.

name: Happening
review:
Diwan's film denotes the perfect portrait of a nightmare.
[Full review in Spanish]

name: Happening
review: "Happening" isn't a political movie, it's a horror movie.

name: Happening
review: A sobering reminder that the consequences of limiting access to safe medical care aren’t just theoretical but existential.

name: Happening
review: Audrey Diwan’s film recreates a woman’s isolating, wrenching efforts to get an abortion in France in the 1960s.

name: Happening
review: Poignant, pressing and important.

name: Happening
review: A smart, engaging, and well-made film.

name: Happening
review: The empathy shown for Anne’s predicament extends beyond the pregnancy; it addresses questions of personal desire, sexuality, and agency over her body and the events that determine the rest of her life.

name: Happening
review: The urgency of Happening’s message comes across loud and clear as a timely warning, and Vartolomei’s laconic performance drives home the despair and highlights the moral courage it takes for Anne to resist.

name: Happening
review: Vartolomei’s performance is amazing. The way her face registers everything she endures, from grim determination to frustration to mental and physical agony, seems genuine, authentic.

name: Happening
review: As the world gets darker and tougher for birthing bodies, unflinching stories about what’s at stake will only become more precious and more powerful. Happening is an exceptional example of just such a story.

name: Happening
review: A movie of chilling honesty...

name: Happening
review: A potent drama filled with anger and rage… [Full review in Spanish]

name: Happening
review: It feels like it was made for this moment... Eerily prescient.

name: Happening
review: The film has a dispassionate air about it -- which makes it even scarier -- but sometimes it goes a little overboard in its semi-documentary direction. But it's quite a powerful experience.

name: Happening
review: It manages to build a feminist story, which shows us how little progress we have made in the last sixty years regarding abortion and the rights that women have in relation to said procedure. Full review in Spanish.

name: Happening
review: As a film this is well-crafted art but take others to watch it for what the story has to say.

name: Happening
review: Obviously, it’s far more timely now, and I’ll be curious whether I’d feel differently about it if I watched it for the first time now.

name: Happening
review: Shot by Diwan in unflinching realism, the horror of Happening is specific to Anne, but also serves as a universal warning if abortion once again becomes illegal.

name: Happening
review: A timely, unflinching masterpiece.

name: Happening
review: With her sophomore feature, the director opts for minimality, slowly closing the window of a young woman’s freedom, shooting each scene with a tender and realitist lens.

name: Happening
review: Happening remains an incredibly powerful film that drives home the fact that outlawing abortions will not prevent people from getting them—it just means they will go to more dangerous lengths in order to do so.

name: Happening
review: An intense, intimate tale of historical illegal abortion, with a central performance of focused terror; a harrowing body horror that looms again. I cannot overstate the absolute urgency of this film.

name: Happening
review: The film’s unflinching approach makes certain scenes difficult to watch. Yet bolstered by Vartolomei’s audaciously committed portrayal, it’s even harder to ignore.

name: Happening
review: Absolutely not for the faint of heart, the movie catalogs the horrors Anne experiences while trying to terminate the pregnancy so that she can stay the course as a scholar and chart her own fate. Happening could not be more staggering, or timely.

name: Happening
review: If Happening often feels like a punch to the solar plexus, that's exactly what it should be.

name: Happening
review: In a part that asks a lot of her, Vartolomei masters the art of silence, somehow managing to react, consider, and protest, often without a saying single word.

name: Happening
review: [A] tense and quietly radical film...

name: Happening
review: If you find “Happening” too distressing for words, think of “Happening” writ large.

name: Happening
review: I’d say it’s not for the squeamish, but you know what? It is for the squeamish, especially those who hold power over women’s bodies in this country but don’t trust them to make decisions on their own behalf.

name: Happening
review: [T]he message is only as effective as it is because the film exists solely in the realm of the personal.

name: Happening
review: An engrossing, honest and gripping emotional journey. It's just as powerful as Vera Drake and 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days.

name: Happening
review: Vartolomei is revelatory in the role. She toes the line between tragic and empowering in a way that makes it hard to believe the Romanian actor has so few credits to her name beyond short films.

name: Happening
review: A realist thriller that morphs, sans sentimentality or platitudes, into a quietly affecting portrait of female solidarity.

name: Happening
review: Throughout, Diwan’s gaze remains clear, direct, fearless. She shows you a part of life that the movies rarely do.

name: Happening
review: It’s the type of movie that deserves praise and your undivided attention no matter when it comes to theaters near you.

name: Happening
review: Diwan’s fly-on-the-wall direction, echoed by Laurent Tangy’s ultra-tight cinematography and the production’s naturalistic lighting and sound, draws us into the suffocating immediacy of every passing day.

name: Happening
review: In an ideal world, “Happening” would simply be a lesson about a dark history. Instead, it might be a chilling portent of our future.

name: Happening
review: ...intensely within Anne’s point of view, “Happening” envisions her circumstance as a claustrophobic, ever-tightening vise.  It is impossible to watch this horrifying, true story from 1963 France without contemplating the U.S. in 2022.

name: Happening
review: What distinguishes Happening, Diwan’s second feature film, is, overwhelmingly, her and Laurent Tangy’s tightly composed cinematography and Vartolomei’s riveting, steely performance.

name: Happening
review: Racked with emotional tension and visceral turmoil, it paints a painful portrait of how women have suffered—and will, sadly, continue to suffer—for the ability to make their own precious choices.

name: Happening
review: A simultaneously infuriating and rousing portrait of female resolve and bravery in the face of misogynistic hardship.

name: Happening
review: No matter where you come down on the abortion issue, Happening is a film worthy of your time and consideration.

name: Happening
review: Happening is that rare, unflinching, suffocatingly harrowing autobiographical story that must be seen and mandated as part of school curriculums worldwide

name: Happening
review: A specific tale of the 1960s, this story of an unwanted pregnancy could not echo more profoundly than it does today.

name: Happening
review: From girls' nights out to the music of rock and rollers, to the incidental, confronting compositions in its later stages, this is both a desperate search for an illegal abortion in 1960s France and a quest for personal freedom, and it is really impressive

name: Happening
review: It is a relief, then, that Diwan’s Happening avoids, for the most part, a sensationalist or spectacular approach.

name: Happening
review: Its a visceral experience that, unabashedly, takes the podium for this particular topic, alongside European contemporary classics such as Vera Drake and 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days.

name: Happening
review: This candid, intimate drama is a tough watch, but an important one.

name: Happening
review: Because the story unfolds without flourishes, each scene plays out with a grim authenticity, turning the audience into voyeurs.

name: Happening
review: Like 2020s harrowing Pieces of A Woman, Happening is a film that might require a post-screening drink to digest everything that youve just experienced. But subtle acting and fearless direction make for a period piece that speaks to modern issues.

name: Happening
review: The relentless clockwork of human biology lends it an awful tension. The actors give in to no cheap options.

name: Happening
review: France is a female dystopia in Audrey Diwan’s immersive illegal abortion drama, set in 1963 and based on Annie Ernaux’s autobiographical novel.

name: Happening
review: Easy to admire but hard to recommend.

name: Happening
review: Happening is a naturalistic, heart-breaking and relentless account of the multiple traumas and injustices that cascade when women are denied their basic bodily autonomy.

name: Happening
review: The film's real power comes... from the emotional connection that Diwan deftly creates between Anne and an audience that finds itself living her trauma rather than just watching it.

name: Happening
review: Audrey Diwan’s film is an in-depth portrait of a woman standing her ground.

name: Happening
review: The challenging watch will make your heart race.

name: Happening
review: More than a biopic or period-piece, this is a stylish time capsule reaching into the present with unnerving clarity. Abortion care is still so hard — this film makes that fact sink into your bones.

name: Happening
review: Sublime, in the truest sense of the word, it offers a take on the swinging 60s that contains images as gorgeous an anything in a Monet painting, as well as details so ugly you may keep forgetting to breathe.

name: Happening
review: What lives with you is the vulnerability, desperation and resilience conveyed, mostly silently, by Vartolomei.

name: Happening
review: Diwan handles all this with great sensitivity and robust honesty.

name: Happening
review: An impeccably produced movie, faintly old-fashioned in its vehement emotional message, adapted from an autobiographical novel by Annie Ernaux.

name: Happening
review: Plays out like a grim ticking-clock thriller about the bleak reality of life for young women in a country where legalised abortion is still more than decade away.

name: Happening
review: It's a very good, if rather gruelling film that, like many other fine films dealing with abortion -   4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days; Never Rarely Sometimes Always  - carries an unsettling topical resonance.

name: Happening
review: Happening may be looking back almost 60 years, but it’s no period piece. Adapted from a novel-cum-memoir by the French author Annie Ernaux, who was a contender for last year’s Nobel Prize for Literature, it’s all about intimacy and immediacy.

name: Happening
review: Director and co-writer Audrey Dwan’s adaptation of Anne Ernaux’s autobiographical book is a triumph of immersive and emotion-filled storytelling.

name: Happening
review: Director Audrey Diwans award-winning abortion drama is whisper-quiet and carries a walloping stick.

name: Happening
review: There are some fairly graphic scenes in the film, especially in the later stages, but the director and her wonderful lead actor bring such honesty and passion to the project that the confronting images seem entirely justified.

name: Happening
review: Joins the other movies of its kind on the tougher side of the ledger: more 4 Months, Three Weeks and Two Days than Never Rarely Sometimes Always.

name: Happening
review: Harrowing yet powerful and compelling. Anamaria Vartolomei is excellent as the resolute Anne, in a film that has little interest in its period setting, because of the sad modern relevance of its themes.

name: Happening
review: Happening is a thoughtful, searing, confident and angry exploration of the ways that women are isolated by the patriarchy.

name: Happening
review: Happening is thought-provoking, making you wonder how far we’ve come on destigmatizing...

name: Happening
review: The boxy aspect ratio is near-suffocating as [Diwan] soberly charts the imposed risk of female desire, the impossibility of lust when so much punishment might ensue.

name: Happening
review: HAPPENING is a powerful drama about a young woman who is determined to do everything in her powers in order to be able to lead a free and self-determined life.

name: Happening
review: Deftly adapted by director Audrey Diwan from a novella, Happening is a period piece, but it’s acted and shot with a shivery immediacy.

name: Happening
review: Getting right up in the face of a globally contentious issue, Audrey Diwan's harrowing and masterfully executed sophomore film shows the terrible consequences of denying a woman her right to choose.

name: Happening
review: With its unflinching presentation of the very real consequences of denying women reproductive freedom, Happening is more terrifying than any horror film

name: Happening
